quoteText:
My dear Mr. Bennet, have you heard that
Netherfield Park is let at last?
subQuotationList: ['My dear Mr. Bennet,', 'have you heard that\nNetherfield Park is let at last?']
speaker: Mrs. Bennet

quoteText:
But it is, for Mrs. Long has just been here, and she
told me all about it.
subQuotationList: ['But it is,', 'for Mrs. Long has just been here, and she\ntold me all about it.']
speaker: Mrs. Bennet

quoteText: Do not you want to know who has taken it?
subQuotationList: ['Do not you want to know who has taken it?']
speaker: Mrs. Bennet

quoteText: _You_ want to tell me, and I have no objection to hearing it.
subQuotationList: ['_You_ want to tell me, and I have no objection to hearing it.']
speaker: Mr. Bennet

quoteText:
Why, my dear, you must know, Mrs. Long says that Netherfield is taken
by a young man of large fortune from the north of England; that he came
down on Monday in a chaise and four to see the place, and was so much
delighted with it that he agreed with Mr. Morris immediately; that he is
to take possession before Michaelmas, and some of his servants are to be
in the house by the end of next week.
subQuotationList:
['Why, my dear, you must know, Mrs. Long says that Netherfield is taken
by a young man of large fortune from the north of England; that he came
down on Monday in a chaise and four to see the place, and was so much
delighted with it that he agreed with Mr. Morris immediately; that he is
to take possession before Michaelmas, and some of his servants are to be
in the house by the end of next week.']
speaker: Mrs. Bennet
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. Bennet'], ['Mr. Bennet'], ['Mrs. Long'], ['Bingley'], ['Mr. Bingley'], ['Mr. Bingley'], ['Mr. Morris'], ['Mr. Bingley'], ['Mr. Bingley']]]

quoteText: What is his name?
subQuotationList: ['What is his name?']
speaker: Mr. Bennet

quoteText: Bingley.
subQuotationList: ['Bingley.']
speaker: Mrs. Bennet

quoteText: Is he married or single?
subQuotationList: ['Is he married or single?']
speaker: Mr. Bennet

quoteText:
Oh! single, my dear, to be sure! A single man of large fortune; four
or five thousand a year. What a fine thing for our girls!
subQuotationList: ['Oh! single, my dear, to be sure! A single man of large fortune; four\nor five thousand a year. What a fine thing for our girls!']
speaker: Mrs. Bennet

quoteText: How so? how can it affect them?
subQuotationList: ['How so? how can it affect them?']
speaker: Mr. Bennet

quoteText:
My dear Mr. Bennet, how can you be so tiresome! You
must know that I am thinking of his marrying one of them.
subQuotationList: ['My dear Mr. Bennet,', 'how can you be so tiresome! You\nmust know that I am thinking of his marrying one of them.']
speaker: Mrs. Bennet

quoteText: Is that his design in settling here?
subQuotationList: ['Is that his design in settling here?']
speaker: Mr. Bennet

quoteText:
Design! nonsense, how can you talk so! But it is very likely that he
_may_ fall in love with one of them, and therefore you must visit him as
soon as he comes.
subQuotationList: ['Design! nonsense, how can you talk so! But it is very likely that he\n_may_ fall in love with one of them, and therefore you must visit him as\nsoon as he comes.']
speaker: Mrs. Bennet

quoteText:
I see no occasion for that. You and the girls may go, or you may send
them by themselves, which perhaps will be still better, for as you are
as handsome as any of them, Mr. Bingley might like you the best of the
party.
subQuotationList:
['I see no occasion for that. You and the girls may go, or you may send
them by themselves, which perhaps will be still better, for as you are
as handsome as any of them, Mr. Bingley might like you the best of the
party.']
speaker: Mr. Bennet

quoteText:
My dear, you flatter me. I certainly _have_ had my share of beauty, but
I do not pretend to be any thing extraordinary now. When a woman has
five grown up daughters, she ought to give over thinking of her own
beauty.
subQuotationList:
['My dear, you flatter me. I certainly _have_ had my share of beauty, but
I do not pretend to be any thing extraordinary now. When a woman has
five grown up daughters, she ought to give over thinking of her own
beauty.']
speaker: Mrs. Bennet

quoteText: In such cases, a woman has not often much beauty to think of.
subQuotationList: ['In such cases, a woman has not often much beauty to think of.']
speaker: Mr. Bennet

quoteText:
But, my dear, you must indeed go and see Mr. Bingley when he comes into
the neighbourhood.
subQuotationList: ['But, my dear, you must indeed go and see Mr. Bingley when he comes into\nthe neighbourhood.']
speaker: Mrs. Bennet

quoteText: It is more than I engage for, I assure you.
subQuotationList: ['It is more than I engage for, I assure you.']
speaker: Mr. Bennet

quoteText:
But consider your daughters. Only think what an establishment it would
be for one of them. Sir William and Lady Lucas are determined to go,
merely on that account, for in general you know they visit no new
comers. Indeed you must go, for it will be impossible for _us_ to visit
him, if you do not.
subQuotationList:
['But consider your daughters. Only think what an establishment it would
be for one of them. Sir William and Lady Lucas are determined to go,
merely on that account, for in general you know they visit no new
comers. Indeed you must go, for it will be impossible for _us_ to visit
him, if you do not.']
speaker: Mrs. Bennet
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mary', 'Elizabeth', 'Lydia', 'Kitty', 'Jane'], ['Mary', 'Elizabeth', 'Lydia', 'Kitty', 'Jane'], ['Sir William Lucas'], ['Lady Lucas'], ['Mr. Bennet'], ['Sir William Lucas', 'Lady Lucas'], ['Mr. Bennet'], ['Mary', 'Elizabeth', 'Lydia', 'Mrs. Bennet', 'Kitty', 'Jane'], ['Mr. Bennet']]]

quoteText:
You are over scrupulous surely. I dare say Mr. Bingley will be very
glad to see you; and I will send a few lines by you to assure him of my
hearty consent to his marrying which ever he chuses of the girls; though
I must throw in a good word for my little Lizzy.
subQuotationList:
['You are over scrupulous surely. I dare say Mr. Bingley will be very
glad to see you; and I will send a few lines by you to assure him of my
hearty consent to his marrying which ever he chuses of the girls; though
I must throw in a good word for my little Lizzy.']
speaker: Mr. Bennet
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mrs. Bennet'], ['Mr. Bingley'], ['Mary', 'Elizabeth', 'Lydia', 'Mrs. Bennet', 'Kitty', 'Jane'], ['Mary', 'Elizabeth', 'Lydia', 'Mrs. Bennet', 'Kitty', 'Jane'], ['Mr. Bingley'], ['Mr. Bingley'], ['Mr. Bingley'], ['Mary', 'Elizabeth', 'Lydia', 'Kitty', 'Jane'], ['Elizabeth']]]

quoteText:
I desire you will do no such thing. Lizzy is not a bit better than the
others; and I am sure she is not half so handsome as Jane, nor half so
good humoured as Lydia. But you are always giving _her_ the
preference.
subQuotationList:
['I desire you will do no such thing. Lizzy is not a bit better than the
others; and I am sure she is not half so handsome as Jane, nor half so
good humoured as Lydia. But you are always giving _her_ the
preference.']
speaker: Mrs. Bennet

quoteText:
They have none of them much to recommend them, they are
all silly and ignorant like other girls; but Lizzy has something more of
quickness than her sisters.
subQuotationList: ['They have none of them much to recommend them,', 'they are\nall silly and ignorant like other girls; but Lizzy has something more of\nquickness than her sisters.']
speaker: Mr. Bennet

quoteText:
Mr. Bennet, how can you abuse your own children in such a way? You take
delight in vexing me. You have no compassion on my poor nerves.
subQuotationList: ['Mr. Bennet, how can you abuse your own children in such a way? You take\ndelight in vexing me. You have no compassion on my poor nerves.']
speaker: Mrs. Bennet

quoteText:
You mistake me, my dear. I have a high respect for your nerves. They
are my old friends. I have heard you mention them with consideration
these twenty years at least.
subQuotationList: ['You mistake me, my dear. I have a high respect for your nerves. They\nare my old friends. I have heard you mention them with consideration\nthese twenty years at least.']
speaker: Mr. Bennet

quoteText: Ah! you do not know what I suffer.
subQuotationList: ['Ah! you do not know what I suffer.']
speaker: Mrs. Bennet

quoteText:
But I hope you will get over it, and live to see many young men of four
thousand a year come into the neighbourhood.
subQuotationList: ['But I hope you will get over it, and live to see many young men of four\nthousand a year come into the neighbourhood.']
speaker: Mr. Bennet

quoteText:
It will be no use to us, if twenty such should come since you will not
visit them.
subQuotationList: ['It will be no use to us, if twenty such should come since you will not\nvisit them.']
speaker: Mrs. Bennet

quoteText:
Depend upon it, my dear, that when there are twenty, I will visit them
all.
subQuotationList: ['Depend upon it, my dear, that when there are twenty, I will visit them\nall.']
speaker: Mr. Bennet

quoteText: I hope Mr. Bingley will like it Lizzy.
subQuotationList: ['I hope Mr. Bingley will like it Lizzy.']
speaker: Mr. Bennet

quoteText: We are not in a way to know _what_ Mr. Bingley likes, since we are not to visit.
subQuotationList: ['We are not in a way to know _what_ Mr. Bingley likes,', 'since we are not to visit.']
speaker: Mrs. Bennet

quoteText:
But you forget, mama, that we shall meet him at the
assemblies, and that Mrs. Long has promised to introduce him.
subQuotationList: ['But you forget, mama,', 'that we shall meet him at the\nassemblies, and that Mrs. Long has promised to introduce him.']
speaker: Elizabeth
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mrs. Bennet'], ['Mrs. Bennet']], [['Mary', 'Elizabeth', 'Lydia', 'Mrs. Bennet', 'Kitty', 'Jane', 'Mr. Bennet'], ['Mr. Bingley'], ['Mrs. Long'], ['Mr. Bingley']]]

quoteText:
I do not believe Mrs. Long will do any such thing. She has two nieces
of her own. She is a selfish, hypocritical woman, and I have no opinion
of her.
subQuotationList: ['I do not believe Mrs. Long will do any such thing. She has two nieces\nof her own. She is a selfish, hypocritical woman, and I have no opinion\nof her.']
speaker: Mrs. Bennet

quoteText:
No more have I, and I am glad to find that you do
not depend on her serving you.
subQuotationList: ['No more have I,', 'and I am glad to find that you do\nnot depend on her serving you.']
speaker: Mr. Bennet

quoteText:
Don't keep coughing so, Kitty, for heaven's sake! Have a little
compassion on my nerves. You tear them to pieces.
subQuotationList: ["Don't keep coughing so, Kitty, for heaven's sake! Have a little\ncompassion on my nerves. You tear them to pieces."]
speaker: Mrs. Bennet
referringExpression: Mrs Bennet deigned not to make any reply but unable to contain herself began scolding one of her daughters

quoteText:
Kitty has no discretion in her coughs, she times
them ill.
subQuotationList: ['Kitty has no discretion in her coughs,', 'she times\nthem ill.']
speaker: Mr. Bennet

quoteText: I do not cough for my own amusement,
subQuotationList: ['I do not cough for my own amusement,']
speaker: Kitty

quoteText: To-morrow fortnight.
subQuotationList: ['To-morrow fortnight.']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
Aye, so it is, and Mrs. Long does not come back
till the day before; so, it will be impossible for her to introduce him,
for she will not know him herself.
subQuotationList: ['Aye, so it is,', 'and Mrs. Long does not come back\ntill the day before; so, it will be impossible for her to introduce him,\nfor she will not know him herself.']
speaker: Mrs. Bennet

quoteText:
Then, my dear, you may have the advantage of your friend, and introduce
Mr. Bingley to _her_.
subQuotationList: ['Then, my dear, you may have the advantage of your friend, and introduce\nMr. Bingley to _her_.']
speaker: Mr. Bennet

quoteText:
Impossible, Mr. Bennet, impossible, when I am not acquainted with him
myself; how can you be so teazing?
subQuotationList: ['Impossible, Mr. Bennet, impossible, when I am not acquainted with him\nmyself; how can you be so teazing?']
speaker: Mrs. Bennet

quoteText:
I honour your circumspection. A fortnight's acquaintance is certainly
very little. One cannot know what a man really is by the end of a
fortnight. But if _we_ do not venture, somebody else will; and after
all, Mrs. Long and her nieces must stand their chance; and therefore, as
she will think it an act of kindness, if you decline the office, I will
take it on myself.
subQuotationList:
["I honour your circumspection. A fortnight's acquaintance is certainly
very little. One cannot know what a man really is by the end of a
fortnight. But if _we_ do not venture, somebody else will; and after
all, Mrs. Long and her nieces must stand their chance; and therefore, as
she will think it an act of kindness, if you decline the office, I will
take it on myself."]
speaker: Mr. Bennet
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mary', 'Elizabeth', 'Lydia', 'Mrs. Bennet', 'Kitty', 'Jane', 'Mr. Bennet'], ['Mrs. Long'], ['Mrs. Long'], ['Mrs. Long'], ['Mrs. Long'], ['Mrs. Bennet']]]

quoteText:
Nonsense,
nonsense!
subQuotationList: ['Nonsense,\nnonsense!']
speaker: Mrs. Bennet

quoteText:
What can be the meaning of that emphatic exclamation? Do
you consider the forms of introduction, and the stress that is laid on
them, as nonsense? I cannot quite agree with you _there_. What say you,
Mary? for you are a young lady of deep reflection I know, and read great
books, and make extracts.
subQuotationList:
['What can be the meaning of that emphatic exclamation?', 'Do
you consider the forms of introduction, and the stress that is laid on
them, as nonsense? I cannot quite agree with you _there_. What say you,
Mary? for you are a young lady of deep reflection I know, and read great
books, and make extracts.']
speaker: Mr. Bennet

quoteText:
While Mary is adjusting her ideas, let us return to Mr.
Bingley.
subQuotationList: ['While Mary is adjusting her ideas,', 'let us return to Mr.\nBingley.']
speaker: Mr. Bennet

quoteText: I am sick of Mr. Bingley,
subQuotationList: ['I am sick of Mr. Bingley,']
speaker: Mrs. Bennet

quoteText:
I am sorry to hear _that_; but why did not you tell me so before? If I
had known as much this morning, I certainly would not have called on
him. It is very unlucky; but as I have actually paid the visit, we
cannot escape the acquaintance now.
subQuotationList:
['I am sorry to hear _that_; but why did not you tell me so before? If I
had known as much this morning, I certainly would not have called on
him. It is very unlucky; but as I have actually paid the visit, we
cannot escape the acquaintance now.']
speaker: Mr. Bennet

quoteText:
How good it was in you, my dear Mr. Bennet! But I knew I should
persuade you at last. I was sure you loved your girls too well to
neglect such an acquaintance. Well, how pleased I am! and it is such a
good joke, too, that you should have gone this morning, and never said
a word about it till now.
subQuotationList:
['How good it was in you, my dear Mr. Bennet! But I knew I should
persuade you at last. I was sure you loved your girls too well to
neglect such an acquaintance. Well, how pleased I am! and it is such a
good joke, too, that you should have gone this morning, and never said
a word about it till now.']
speaker: Mrs. Bennet

quoteText: Now, Kitty, you may cough as much as you chuse,
subQuotationList: ['Now, Kitty, you may cough as much as you chuse,']
speaker: Mr. Bennet

quoteText:
What an excellent father you have, girls, I do not know how you will ever make him amends for his kindness;
or me either, for that matter. At our time of life, it is not so
pleasant I can tell you, to be making new acquaintance every day; but
for your sakes, we would do any thing. Lydia, my love, though you _are_
the youngest, I dare say Mr. Bingley will dance with you at the next
ball.
subQuotationList:
['What an excellent father you have, girls,', 'I do not know how you will ever make him amends for his kindness;
or me either, for that matter. At our time of life, it is not so
pleasant I can tell you, to be making new acquaintance every day; but
for your sakes, we would do any thing. Lydia, my love, though you _are_
the youngest, I dare say Mr. Bingley will dance with you at the next
ball.']
speaker: Mrs. Bennet
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mary', 'Elizabeth', 'Lydia', 'Kitty'], ['Mary', 'Elizabeth', 'Lydia', 'Kitty']], [['Mary', 'Elizabeth', 'Lydia', 'Kitty'], ['Mr. Bennet'], ['Mr. Bennet'], ['Mr. Bennet', 'Mrs. Bennet'], ['Mary', 'Elizabeth', 'Lydia', 'Kitty'], ['Elizabeth', 'Lydia', 'Kitty', 'Mary'], ['Mr. Bennet', 'Mrs. Bennet'], ['Lydia'], ['Lydia'], ['Lydia'], ['Mr. Bingley'], ['Lydia']]]

quoteText:
Oh! I am not afraid; for though I _am_ the
youngest, I'm the tallest.
subQuotationList: ['Oh!', "I am not afraid; for though I _am_ the\nyoungest, I'm the tallest."]
speaker: Lydia

quoteText:
If I can but see one of my daughters happily settled at Netherfield, and all the others equally well
married, I shall have nothing to wish for.
subQuotationList: ['If I can but see one of my daughters happily settled at Netherfield,', 'and all the others equally well\nmarried, I shall have nothing to wish for.']
speaker: Mrs. Bennet
referringExpression: said Mrs Bennet to her husband

quoteText:
Come, Darcy, I must have you dance. I hate to see you
standing about by yourself in this stupid manner. You had much better
dance.
subQuotationList: ['Come, Darcy,', 'I must have you dance. I hate to see you\nstanding about by yourself in this stupid manner. You had much better\ndance.']
speaker: Mr. Bingley

quoteText:
I certainly shall not. You know how I detest it, unless I am
particularly acquainted with my partner. At such an assembly as this, it
would be insupportable. Your sisters are engaged, and there is not
another woman in the room, whom it would not be a punishment to me to
stand up with.
subQuotationList:
['I certainly shall not. You know how I detest it, unless I am
particularly acquainted with my partner. At such an assembly as this, it
would be insupportable. Your sisters are engaged, and there is not
another woman in the room, whom it would not be a punishment to me to
stand up with.']
speaker: Mr. Darcy

quoteText:
I would not be so fastidious as you are, for a
kingdom! Upon my honour, I never met with so many pleasant girls in my
life, as I have this evening; and there are several of them you see
uncommonly pretty.
subQuotationList:
['I would not be so fastidious as you are,', 'for a
kingdom! Upon my honour, I never met with so many pleasant girls in my
life, as I have this evening; and there are several of them you see
uncommonly pretty.']
speaker: Mr. Bingley

quoteText: _You_ are dancing with the only handsome girl in the room,
subQuotationList: ['_You_ are dancing with the only handsome girl in the room,']
speaker: Mr. Darcy

quoteText:
Oh! she is the most beautiful creature I ever beheld! But there is one
of her sisters sitting down just behind you, who is very pretty, and I
dare say, very agreeable. Do let me ask my partner to introduce you.
subQuotationList: ['Oh! she is the most beautiful creature I ever beheld! But there is one\nof her sisters sitting down just behind you, who is very pretty, and I\ndare say, very agreeable. Do let me ask my partner to introduce you.']
speaker: Mr. Bingley

quoteText:
Which do you mean? She is tolerable; but not handsome enough to tempt _me_; and I am in no
humour at present to give consequence to young ladies who are slighted
by other men. You had better return to your partner and enjoy her
smiles, for you are wasting your time with me.
subQuotationList:
['Which do you mean?', 'She is tolerable; but not handsome enough to tempt _me_; and I am in no
humour at present to give consequence to young ladies who are slighted
by other men. You had better return to your partner and enjoy her
smiles, for you are wasting your time with me.']
speaker: Mr. Darcy
referringExpression: he withdrew his own and coldly said

quoteText: Oh! my dear Mr. Bennet,
subQuotationList: ['Oh! my dear Mr. Bennet,']
speaker: Mrs. Bennet

quoteText:
we have had a most
delightful evening, a most excellent ball. I wish you had been there.
Jane was so admired, nothing could be like it. Every body said how well
she looked; and Mr. Bingley thought her quite beautiful, and danced with
her twice. Only think of _that_ my dear; he actually danced with her
twice; and she was the only creature in the room that he asked a second
time. First of all, he asked Miss Lucas. I was so vexed to see him stand
up with her; but, however, he did not admire her at all: indeed, nobody
can, you know; and he seemed quite struck with Jane as she was going
down the dance. So, he enquired who she was, and got introduced, and
asked her for the two next. Then, the two third he danced with Miss
King, and the two fourth with Maria Lucas, and the two fifth with Jane
again, and the two sixth with Lizzy, and the Boulanger----
subQuotationList:
['we have had a most
delightful evening, a most excellent ball. I wish you had been there.
Jane was so admired, nothing could be like it. Every body said how well
she looked; and Mr. Bingley thought her quite beautiful, and danced with
her twice. Only think of _that_ my dear; he actually danced with her
twice; and she was the only creature in the room that he asked a second
time. First of all, he asked Miss Lucas. I was so vexed to see him stand
up with her; but, however, he did not admire her at all: indeed, nobody
can, you know; and he seemed quite struck with Jane as she was going
down the dance. So, he enquired who she was, and got introduced, and
asked her for the two next. Then, the two third he danced with Miss
King, and the two fourth with Maria Lucas, and the two fifth with Jane
again, and the two sixth with Lizzy, and the Boulanger----']
speaker: Mrs. Bennet
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mary', 'Elizabeth', 'Lydia', 'Mrs. Bennet', 'Kitty', 'Jane'], ['Mr. Bennet'], ['Jane'], ['Jane'], ['Mr. Bingley'], ['Jane'], ['Jane'], ['Mr. Bennet'], ['Mr. Bingley'], ['Jane'], ['Jane'], ['Mr. Bingley'], ['Mr. Bingley'], ['Charlotte Lucas'], ['Mr. Bingley'], ['Charlotte Lucas'], ['Mr. Bingley'], ['Charlotte Lucas'], ['Mr. Bennet'], ['Mr. Bingley'], ['Jane'], ['Jane'], ['Mr. Bingley'], ['Jane'], ['Jane'], ['Mr. Bingley'], ['Maria'], ['Jane'], ['Elizabeth']]]

quoteText:
If he had had any compassion for _me_, he would not have danced half so much! For God's sake, say no more of
his partners. Oh! that he had sprained his ancle in the first dance!
subQuotationList: ['If he had had any compassion for _me_,', "he would not have danced half so much! For God's sake, say no more of\nhis partners. Oh! that he had sprained his ancle in the first dance!"]
speaker: Mr. Bennet

quoteText:
Oh! my dear, I am quite delighted with him. He
is so excessively handsome! and his sisters are charming women. I never
in my life saw any thing more elegant than their dresses. I dare say the
lace upon Mrs. Hurst's gown----
subQuotationList:
['Oh! my dear,', "I am quite delighted with him. He
is so excessively handsome! and his sisters are charming women. I never
in my life saw any thing more elegant than their dresses. I dare say the
lace upon Mrs. Hurst's gown----"]
speaker: Mrs. Bennet
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. Bennet']], [['Mr. Bingley'], ['Mr. Bingley'], ['Miss Bingley', 'Mrs. Hurst'], ['Miss Bingley', 'Mrs. Hurst'], ['Mrs. Hurst']]]

quoteText:
But I can assure you, that Lizzy does not lose much by not
suiting _his_ fancy; for he is a most disagreeable, horrid man, not at
all worth pleasing. So high and so conceited that there was no enduring
him! He walked here, and he walked there, fancying himself so very
great! Not handsome enough to dance with! I wish you had been there, my
dear, to have given him one of your set downs. I quite detest the man.
subQuotationList:
['But I can assure you,', 'that Lizzy does not lose much by not
suiting _his_ fancy; for he is a most disagreeable, horrid man, not at
all worth pleasing. So high and so conceited that there was no enduring
him! He walked here, and he walked there, fancying himself so very
great! Not handsome enough to dance with! I wish you had been there, my
dear, to have given him one of your set downs. I quite detest the man.']
speaker: Mrs. Bennet
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. Bennet']], [['Elizabeth'], ['Mr. Darcy'], ['Mr. Darcy'], ['Mr. Darcy'], ['Mr. Darcy'], ['Mr. Darcy'], ['Mr. Bennet'], ['Mr. Bennet'], ['Mr. Darcy'], ['Mr. Darcy']]]

quoteText:
He is just what a young man ought to be, sensible, good
humoured, lively; and I never saw such happy manners!--so much ease,
with such perfect good breeding!
subQuotationList: ['He is just what a young man ought to be,', 'sensible, good\nhumoured, lively; and I never saw such happy manners!--so much ease,\nwith such perfect good breeding!']
speaker: Jane

quoteText:
He is also handsome, which a young man ought
likewise to be, if he possibly can. His character is thereby complete.
subQuotationList: ['He is also handsome,', 'which a young man ought\nlikewise to be, if he possibly can. His character is thereby complete.']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
I was very much flattered by his asking me to dance a second time. I
did not expect such a compliment.
subQuotationList: ['I was very much flattered by his asking me to dance a second time. I\ndid not expect such a compliment.']
speaker: Jane

quoteText:
Did not you? _I_ did for you. But that is one great difference between
us. Compliments always take _you_ by surprise, and _me_ never. What
could be more natural than his asking you again? He could not help
seeing that you were about five times as pretty as every other woman in
the room. No thanks to his gallantry for that. Well, he certainly is
very agreeable, and I give you leave to like him. You have liked many a
stupider person.
subQuotationList:
['Did not you? _I_ did for you. But that is one great difference between
us. Compliments always take _you_ by surprise, and _me_ never. What
could be more natural than his asking you again? He could not help
seeing that you were about five times as pretty as every other woman in
the room. No thanks to his gallantry for that. Well, he certainly is
very agreeable, and I give you leave to like him. You have liked many a
stupider person.']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText: Dear Lizzy!
subQuotationList: ['Dear Lizzy!']
speaker: Jane

quoteText:
Oh! you are a great deal too apt you know, to like people in general.
You never see a fault in any body. All the world are good and agreeable
in your eyes. I never heard you speak ill of a human being in my life.
subQuotationList: ['Oh! you are a great deal too apt you know, to like people in general.\nYou never see a fault in any body. All the world are good and agreeable\nin your eyes. I never heard you speak ill of a human being in my life.']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
I would wish not to be hasty in censuring any one; but I always speak
what I think.
subQuotationList: ['I would wish not to be hasty in censuring any one; but I always speak\nwhat I think.']
speaker: Jane

quoteText:
I know you do; and it is _that_ which makes the wonder. With _your_
good sense, to be so honestly blind to the follies and nonsense of
others! Affectation of candour is common enough;--one meets it every
where. But to be candid without ostentation or design--to take the good
of every body's character and make it still better, and say nothing of
the bad--belongs to you alone. And so, you like this man's sisters too,
do you? Their manners are not equal to his.
subQuotationList:
["I know you do; and it is _that_ which makes the wonder. With _your_
good sense, to be so honestly blind to the follies and nonsense of
others! Affectation of candour is common enough;--one meets it every
where. But to be candid without ostentation or design--to take the good
of every body's character and make it still better, and say nothing of
the bad--belongs to you alone. And so, you like this man's sisters too,
do you? Their manners are not equal to his."]
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
Certainly not; at first. But they are very pleasing women when you
converse with them. Miss Bingley is to live with her brother and keep
his house; and I am much mistaken if we shall not find a very charming
neighbour in her.
subQuotationList:
['Certainly not; at first. But they are very pleasing women when you
converse with them. Miss Bingley is to live with her brother and keep
his house; and I am much mistaken if we shall not find a very charming
neighbour in her.']
speaker: Jane
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Miss Bingley', 'Mrs. Hurst'], ['Miss Bingley', 'Mrs. Hurst'], ['Miss Bingley'], ['Mr. Bingley'], ['Mr. Bingley'], ['Elizabeth', 'Jane'], ['Miss Bingley']]]

quoteText: _You_ began the evening well, Charlotte, _You_ were Mr. Bingley's first choice.
subQuotationList: ['_You_ began the evening well, Charlotte,', "_You_ were Mr. Bingley's first choice."]
speaker: Mrs. Bennet
referringExpression: said Mrs Bennet with civil selfcommand to Miss Lucas

quoteText: Yes;--but he seemed to like his second better.
subQuotationList: ['Yes;--but he seemed to like his second better.']
speaker: Charlotte Lucas

quoteText:
Oh!--you mean Jane, I suppose--because he danced with her twice. To be
sure that _did_ seem as if he admired her--indeed I rather believe he
_did_--I heard something about it--but I hardly know what--something
about Mr. Robinson.
subQuotationList:
['Oh!--you mean Jane, I suppose--because he danced with her twice. To be
sure that _did_ seem as if he admired her--indeed I rather believe he
_did_--I heard something about it--but I hardly know what--something
about Mr. Robinson.']
speaker: Mrs. Bennet

quoteText:
Perhaps you mean what I overheard between him and Mr. Robinson; did not
I mention it to you? Mr. Robinson's asking him how he liked our Meryton
assemblies, and whether he did not think there were a great many pretty
women in the room, and _which_ he thought the prettiest? and his
answering immediately to the last question--Oh! the eldest Miss Bennet
beyond a doubt, there cannot be two opinions on that point.
subQuotationList:
["Perhaps you mean what I overheard between him and Mr. Robinson; did not
I mention it to you? Mr. Robinson's asking him how he liked our Meryton
assemblies, and whether he did not think there were a great many pretty
women in the room, and _which_ he thought the prettiest? and his
answering immediately to the last question--Oh! the eldest Miss Bennet
beyond a doubt, there cannot be two opinions on that point."]
speaker: Charlotte Lucas
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mrs. Bennet'], ['Mr. Bingley'], ['Mr. Robinson\xa0'], ['Mrs. Bennet'], ['Mr. Robinson\xa0'], ['Mr. Bingley'], ['Mr. Bingley'], ['Mr. Bingley'], ['Mr. Bingley'], ['Bingley'], ['Jane']]]

quoteText:
Upon my word!--Well, that was very decided indeed--that does seem as
if----but however, it may all come to nothing you know.
subQuotationList: ['Upon my word!--Well, that was very decided indeed--that does seem as\nif----but however, it may all come to nothing you know.']
speaker: Mrs. Bennet

quoteText:
_My_ overhearings were more to the purpose than _yours_, Eliza, Mr. Darcy is not so well worth listening to as his friend,
is he?--Poor Eliza!--to be only just _tolerable_.
subQuotationList: ['_My_ overhearings were more to the purpose than _yours_, Eliza,', 'Mr. Darcy is not so well worth listening to as his friend,\nis he?--Poor Eliza!--to be only just _tolerable_.']
speaker: Charlotte Lucas

quoteText:
I beg you would not put it into Lizzy's head to be vexed by his
ill-treatment; for he is such a disagreeable man that it would be quite
a misfortune to be liked by him. Mrs. Long told me last night that he
sat close to her for half an hour without once opening his lips.
subQuotationList:
["I beg you would not put it into Lizzy's head to be vexed by his
ill-treatment; for he is such a disagreeable man that it would be quite
a misfortune to be liked by him. Mrs. Long told me last night that he
sat close to her for half an hour without once opening his lips."]
speaker: Mrs. Bennet
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Charlotte Lucas'], ['Elizabeth'], ['Mr. Darcy'], ['Mr. Darcy'], ['Mrs. Long'], ['Mr. Darcy'], ['Mrs. Long'], ['Mr. Darcy']]]

quoteText: Are you quite sure, Ma'am?--is not there a little mistake? I certainly saw Mr. Darcy speaking to her.
subQuotationList: ["Are you quite sure, Ma'am?--is not there a little mistake?", 'I certainly saw Mr. Darcy speaking to her.']
speaker: Jane

quoteText:
Aye--because she asked him at last how he liked Netherfield, and he
could not help answering her;--but she said he seemed very angry at
being spoke to.
subQuotationList: ['Aye--because she asked him at last how he liked Netherfield, and he\ncould not help answering her;--but she said he seemed very angry at\nbeing spoke to.']
speaker: Mrs. Bennet
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mrs. Long'], ['Mr. Darcy'], ['Mr. Darcy'], ['Mr. Darcy'], ['Mrs. Long'], ['Mrs. Long'], ['Mr. Darcy']]]

quoteText: Miss Bingley told me,
subQuotationList: ['Miss Bingley told me,']
speaker: Jane

quoteText:
that he never speaks much unless
among his intimate acquaintance. With _them_ he is remarkably
agreeable.
subQuotationList: ['that he never speaks much unless\namong his intimate acquaintance. With _them_ he is remarkably\nagreeable.']
speaker: Jane

quoteText:
I do not believe a word of it, my dear. If he had been so very
agreeable he would have talked to Mrs. Long. But I can guess how it was;
every body says that he is ate up with pride, and I dare say he had
heard somehow that Mrs. Long does not keep a carriage, and had come to
the ball in a hack chaise.
subQuotationList:
['I do not believe a word of it, my dear. If he had been so very
agreeable he would have talked to Mrs. Long. But I can guess how it was;
every body says that he is ate up with pride, and I dare say he had
heard somehow that Mrs. Long does not keep a carriage, and had come to
the ball in a hack chaise.']
speaker: Mrs. Bennet
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Jane'], ['Mr. Darcy'], ['Mr. Darcy'], ['Mrs. Long'], ['Mr. Darcy'], ['Mr. Darcy'], ['Mrs. Long']]]

quoteText:
I do not mind his not talking to Mrs. Long, but I
wish he had danced with Eliza.
subQuotationList: ['I do not mind his not talking to Mrs. Long,', 'but I\nwish he had danced with Eliza.']
speaker: Charlotte Lucas

quoteText:
Another time, Lizzy, I would not dance with _him_,
if I were you.
subQuotationList: ['Another time, Lizzy,', 'I would not dance with _him_,\nif I were you.']
speaker: Mrs. Bennet

quoteText: I believe, Ma'am, I may safely promise you _never_ to dance with him.
subQuotationList: ["I believe, Ma'am, I may safely promise you _never_ to dance with him."]
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
His pride, does not offend _me_ so much as pride
often does, because there is an excuse for it. One cannot wonder that so
very fine a young man, with family, fortune, every thing in his favour,
should think highly of himself. If I may so express it, he has a _right_
to be proud.
subQuotationList:
['His pride,', 'does not offend _me_ so much as pride
often does, because there is an excuse for it. One cannot wonder that so
very fine a young man, with family, fortune, every thing in his favour,
should think highly of himself. If I may so express it, he has a _right_
to be proud.']
speaker: Charlotte Lucas

quoteText:
That is very true, and I could easily forgive
_his_ pride, if he had not mortified _mine_.
subQuotationList: ['That is very true,', 'and I could easily forgive\n_his_ pride, if he had not mortified _mine_.']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
Pride, is a very common failing I believe. By all that I have
ever read, I am convinced that it is very common indeed, that human
nature is particularly prone to it, and that there are very few of us
who do not cherish a feeling of self-complacency on the score of some
quality or other, real or imaginary. Vanity and pride are different
things, though the words are often used synonimously. A person may be
proud without being vain. Pride relates more to our opinion of
ourselves, vanity to what we would have others think of us.
subQuotationList:
['Pride,', 'is a very common failing I believe. By all that I have
ever read, I am convinced that it is very common indeed, that human
nature is particularly prone to it, and that there are very few of us
who do not cherish a feeling of self-complacency on the score of some
quality or other, real or imaginary. Vanity and pride are different
things, though the words are often used synonimously. A person may be
proud without being vain. Pride relates more to our opinion of
ourselves, vanity to what we would have others think of us.']
speaker: Mary

quoteText:
If I were as rich as Mr. Darcy, I should not care how proud I was. I would keep a pack of
foxhounds, and drink a bottle of wine every day.
subQuotationList: ['If I were as rich as Mr. Darcy,', 'I should not care how proud I was. I would keep a pack of\nfoxhounds, and drink a bottle of wine every day.']
speaker: A Young Lucas

quoteText:
Then you would drink a great deal more than you ought, and if I were to see you at it I should take away your bottle
directly.
subQuotationList: ['Then you would drink a great deal more than you ought,', 'and if I were to see you at it I should take away your bottle\ndirectly.']
speaker: Mrs. Bennet
mentionEntitiesList: [[['A Young Lucas'], ['A Young Lucas']], [['A Young Lucas'], ['A Young Lucas']]]

quoteText:
It may perhaps be pleasant, to be able to impose
on the public in such a case; but it is sometimes a disadvantage to be
so very guarded. If a woman conceals her affection with the same skill
from the object of it, she may lose the opportunity of fixing him; and
it will then be but poor consolation to believe the world equally in the
dark. There is so much of gratitude or vanity in almost every
attachment, that it is not safe to leave any to itself. We can all
_begin_ freely--a slight preference is natural enough; but there are
very few of us who have heart enough to be really in love without
encouragement. In nine cases out of ten, a woman had better shew _more_
affection than she feels. Bingley likes your sister undoubtedly; but he
may never do more than like her, if she does not help him on.
subQuotationList:
['It may perhaps be pleasant,', 'to be able to impose
on the public in such a case; but it is sometimes a disadvantage to be
so very guarded. If a woman conceals her affection with the same skill
from the object of it, she may lose the opportunity of fixing him; and
it will then be but poor consolation to believe the world equally in the
dark. There is so much of gratitude or vanity in almost every
attachment, that it is not safe to leave any to itself. We can all
_begin_ freely--a slight preference is natural enough; but there are
very few of us who have heart enough to be really in love without
encouragement. In nine cases out of ten, a woman had better shew _more_
affection than she feels. Bingley likes your sister undoubtedly; but he
may never do more than like her, if she does not help him on.']
speaker: Charlotte Lucas

quoteText:
But she does help him on, as much as her nature will allow. If _I_ can
perceive her regard for him, he must be a simpleton indeed not to
discover it too.
subQuotationList: ['But she does help him on, as much as her nature will allow. If _I_ can\nperceive her regard for him, he must be a simpleton indeed not to\ndiscover it too.']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText: Remember, Eliza, that he does not know Jane's disposition as you do.
subQuotationList: ["Remember, Eliza, that he does not know Jane's disposition as you do."]
speaker: Charlotte Lucas

quoteText:
But if a woman is partial to a man, and does not endeavour to conceal
it, he must find it out.
subQuotationList: ['But if a woman is partial to a man, and does not endeavour to conceal\nit, he must find it out.']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
Perhaps he must, if he sees enough of her. But though Bingley and Jane
meet tolerably often, it is never for many hours together; and as they
always see each other in large mixed parties, it is impossible that
every moment should be employed in conversing together. Jane should
therefore make the most of every half hour in which she can command his
attention. When she is secure of him, there will be leisure for falling
in love as much as she chuses.
subQuotationList:
['Perhaps he must, if he sees enough of her. But though Bingley and Jane
meet tolerably often, it is never for many hours together; and as they
always see each other in large mixed parties, it is impossible that
every moment should be employed in conversing together. Jane should
therefore make the most of every half hour in which she can command his
attention. When she is secure of him, there will be leisure for falling
in love as much as she chuses.']
speaker: Charlotte Lucas

quoteText:
Your plan is a good one, where nothing is in
question but the desire of being well married; and if I were determined
to get a rich husband, or any husband, I dare say I should adopt it. But
these are not Jane's feelings; she is not acting by design. As yet, she
cannot even be certain of the degree of her own regard, nor of its
reasonableness. She has known him only a fortnight. She danced four
dances with him at Meryton; she saw him one morning at his own house,
and has since dined in company with him four times. This is not quite
enough to make her understand his character.
subQuotationList:
['Your plan is a good one,', "where nothing is in
question but the desire of being well married; and if I were determined
to get a rich husband, or any husband, I dare say I should adopt it. But
these are not Jane's feelings; she is not acting by design. As yet, she
cannot even be certain of the degree of her own regard, nor of its
reasonableness. She has known him only a fortnight. She danced four
dances with him at Meryton; she saw him one morning at his own house,
and has since dined in company with him four times. This is not quite
enough to make her understand his character."]
speaker: Elizabeth
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Charlotte Lucas']], [['Jane'], ['Jane'], ['Jane'], ['Jane'], ['Jane'], ['Mr. Bingley'], ['Jane'], ['Mr. Bingley'], ['Jane'], ['Mr. Bingley'], ['Mr. Bingley'], ['Mr. Bingley'], ['Jane'], ['Mr. Bingley']]]

quoteText:
Not as you represent it. Had she merely _dined_ with him, she might
only have discovered whether he had a good appetite; but you must
remember that four evenings have been also spent together--and four
evenings may do a great deal.
subQuotationList:
['Not as you represent it. Had she merely _dined_ with him, she might
only have discovered whether he had a good appetite; but you must
remember that four evenings have been also spent together--and four
evenings may do a great deal.']
speaker: Charlotte Lucas

quoteText:
Yes; these four evenings have enabled them to ascertain that they both
like Vingt-un better than Commerce; but with respect to any other
leading characteristic, I do not imagine that much has been unfolded.
subQuotationList: ['Yes; these four evenings have enabled them to ascertain that they both\nlike Vingt-un better than Commerce; but with respect to any other\nleading characteristic, I do not imagine that much has been unfolded.']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
Well, I wish Jane success with all my heart; and if
she were married to him to-morrow, I should think she had as good a
chance of happiness, as if she were to be studying his character for a
twelvemonth. Happiness in marriage is entirely a matter of chance. If
the dispositions of the parties are ever so well known to each other, or
ever so similar before-hand, it does not advance their felicity in the
least. They always continue to grow sufficiently unlike afterwards to
have their share of vexation; and it is better to know as little as
possible of the defects of the person with whom you are to pass your
life.
subQuotationList:
['Well,', 'I wish Jane success with all my heart; and if
she were married to him to-morrow, I should think she had as good a
chance of happiness, as if she were to be studying his character for a
twelvemonth. Happiness in marriage is entirely a matter of chance. If
the dispositions of the parties are ever so well known to each other, or
ever so similar before-hand, it does not advance their felicity in the
least. They always continue to grow sufficiently unlike afterwards to
have their share of vexation; and it is better to know as little as
possible of the defects of the person with whom you are to pass your
life.']
speaker: Charlotte Lucas

quoteText:
You make me laugh, Charlotte; but it is not sound. You know it is not
sound, and that you would never act in this way yourself.
subQuotationList: ['You make me laugh, Charlotte; but it is not sound. You know it is not\nsound, and that you would never act in this way yourself.']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
What does Mr. Darcy mean, by listening to my
conversation with Colonel Forster?
subQuotationList: ['What does Mr. Darcy mean,', 'by listening to my\nconversation with Colonel Forster?']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText: That is a question which Mr. Darcy only can answer.
subQuotationList: ['That is a question which Mr. Darcy only can answer.']
speaker: Charlotte Lucas

quoteText:
But if he does it any more I shall certainly let him know that I see
what he is about. He has a very satirical eye, and if I do not begin by
being impertinent myself, I shall soon grow afraid of him.
subQuotationList: ['But if he does it any more I shall certainly let him know that I see\nwhat he is about. He has a very satirical eye, and if I do not begin by\nbeing impertinent myself, I shall soon grow afraid of him.']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
Did not you think, Mr. Darcy, that I expressed myself uncommonly well
just now, when I was teazing Colonel Forster to give us a ball at
Meryton?
subQuotationList: ['Did not you think, Mr. Darcy, that I expressed myself uncommonly well\njust now, when I was teazing Colonel Forster to give us a ball at\nMeryton?']
speaker: Elizabeth
referringExpression: she turned to him and said

quoteText:
With great energy;--but it is a subject which always makes a lady
energetic.
subQuotationList: ['With great energy;--but it is a subject which always makes a lady\nenergetic.']
speaker: Mr. Darcy

quoteText: You are severe on us.
subQuotationList: ['You are severe on us.']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
It will be _her_ turn soon to be teazed, I am going
to open the instrument, Eliza, and you know what follows.
subQuotationList: ['It will be _her_ turn soon to be teazed,', 'I am going\nto open the instrument, Eliza, and you know what follows.']
speaker: Charlotte Lucas

quoteText:
You are a very strange creature by way of a friend!--always wanting me
to play and sing before any body and every body!--If my vanity had taken
a musical turn, you would have been invaluable, but as it is, I would
really rather not sit down before those who must be in the habit of
hearing the very best performers. Very well; if it must be so, it must. There is a fine old saying, which every body here is of
course familiar with--'Keep your breath to cool your porridge,'--and I
shall keep mine to swell my song.
subQuotationList:
['You are a very strange creature by way of a friend!--always wanting me
to play and sing before any body and every body!--If my vanity had taken
a musical turn, you would have been invaluable, but as it is, I would
really rather not sit down before those who must be in the habit of
hearing the very best performers.', 'Very well; if it must be so, it must.', "There is a fine old saying, which every body here is of
course familiar with--'Keep your breath to cool your porridge,'--and I
shall keep mine to swell my song."]
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
What a charming amusement for young people this is, Mr. Darcy!--There
is nothing like dancing after all.--I consider it as one of the first
refinements of polished societies.
subQuotationList: ['What a charming amusement for young people this is, Mr. Darcy!--There\nis nothing like dancing after all.--I consider it as one of the first\nrefinements of polished societies.']
speaker: Sir William Lucas

quoteText:
Certainly, Sir;--and it has the advantage also of being in vogue
amongst the less polished societies of the world.--Every savage can
dance.
subQuotationList: ['Certainly, Sir;--and it has the advantage also of being in vogue\namongst the less polished societies of the world.--Every savage can\ndance.']
speaker: Mr. Darcy

quoteText:
Your friend performs delightfully; and I doubt
not that you are an adept in the science yourself, Mr. Darcy.
subQuotationList: ['Your friend performs delightfully;', 'and I doubt\nnot that you are an adept in the science yourself, Mr. Darcy.']
speaker: Sir William Lucas

quoteText: You saw me dance at Meryton, I believe, Sir.
subQuotationList: ['You saw me dance at Meryton, I believe, Sir.']
speaker: Mr. Darcy

quoteText:
Yes, indeed, and received no inconsiderable pleasure from the sight. Do
you often dance at St. James's?
subQuotationList: ["Yes, indeed, and received no inconsiderable pleasure from the sight. Do\nyou often dance at St. James's?"]
speaker: Sir William Lucas

quoteText: Never, sir.
subQuotationList: ['Never, sir.']
speaker: Mr. Darcy

quoteText: Do you not think it would be a proper compliment to the place?
subQuotationList: ['Do you not think it would be a proper compliment to the place?']
speaker: Sir William Lucas

quoteText: It is a compliment which I never pay to any place if I can avoid it.
subQuotationList: ['It is a compliment which I never pay to any place if I can avoid it.']
speaker: Mr. Darcy

quoteText: You have a house in town, I conclude?
subQuotationList: ['You have a house in town, I conclude?']
speaker: Sir William Lucas

quoteText:
I had once some thoughts of fixing in town myself--for I am fond of
superior society; but I did not feel quite certain that the air of
London would agree with Lady Lucas.
subQuotationList: ['I had once some thoughts of fixing in town myself--for I am fond of\nsuperior society; but I did not feel quite certain that the air of\nLondon would agree with Lady Lucas.']
speaker: Sir William Lucas

quoteText:
My dear Miss Eliza, why are not you dancing?--Mr. Darcy, you must allow
me to present this young lady to you as a very desirable partner.--You
cannot refuse to dance, I am sure, when so much beauty is before you.
subQuotationList: ['My dear Miss Eliza, why are not you dancing?--Mr. Darcy, you must allow\nme to present this young lady to you as a very desirable partner.--You\ncannot refuse to dance, I am sure, when so much beauty is before you.']
speaker: Sir William Lucas
referringExpression: he was struck with the notion of doing a very gallant thing and called out to her
mentionTextsList: [['My dear Miss Eliza', 'you', 'Mr. Darcy', 'you', 'this young lady', 'you', 'You', 'you']]

quoteText:
Indeed, Sir, I have not the least intention of dancing.--I entreat you
not to suppose that I moved this way in order to beg for a partner.
subQuotationList: ['Indeed, Sir, I have not the least intention of dancing.--I entreat you\nnot to suppose that I moved this way in order to beg for a partner.']
speaker: Elizabeth
referringExpression: she instantly drew back and said with some discomposure to Sir William

quoteText:
You excel so much in the dance, Miss Eliza, that it is cruel to deny me
the happiness of seeing you; and though this gentleman dislikes the
amusement in general, he can have no objection, I am sure, to oblige us
for one half hour.
subQuotationList:
['You excel so much in the dance, Miss Eliza, that it is cruel to deny me
the happiness of seeing you; and though this gentleman dislikes the
amusement in general, he can have no objection, I am sure, to oblige us
for one half hour.']
speaker: Sir William Lucas

quoteText: Mr. Darcy is all politeness,
subQuotationList: ['Mr. Darcy is all politeness,']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
He is indeed--but considering the inducement, my dear Miss Eliza, we
cannot wonder at his complaisance; for who would object to such a
partner?
subQuotationList: ['He is indeed--but considering the inducement, my dear Miss Eliza, we\ncannot wonder at his complaisance; for who would object to such a\npartner?']
speaker: Sir William Lucas

quoteText: I can guess the subject of your reverie.
subQuotationList: ['I can guess the subject of your reverie.']
speaker: Miss Bingley

quoteText: I should imagine not.
subQuotationList: ['I should imagine not.']
speaker: Mr. Darcy

quoteText:
You are considering how insupportable it would be to pass many evenings
in this manner--in such society; and indeed I am quite of your opinion.
I was never more annoyed! The insipidity and yet the noise; the
nothingness and yet the self-importance of all these people!--What would
I give to hear your strictures on them!
subQuotationList:
['You are considering how insupportable it would be to pass many evenings
in this manner--in such society; and indeed I am quite of your opinion.
I was never more annoyed! The insipidity and yet the noise; the
nothingness and yet the self-importance of all these people!--What would
I give to hear your strictures on them!']
speaker: Miss Bingley

quoteText:
Your conjecture is totally wrong, I assure you. My mind was more
agreeably engaged. I have been meditating on the very great pleasure
which a pair of fine eyes in the face of a pretty woman can bestow.
subQuotationList: ['Your conjecture is totally wrong, I assure you. My mind was more\nagreeably engaged. I have been meditating on the very great pleasure\nwhich a pair of fine eyes in the face of a pretty woman can bestow.']
speaker: Mr. Darcy

quoteText: Miss Elizabeth Bennet.
subQuotationList: ['Miss Elizabeth Bennet.']
speaker: Mr. Darcy

quoteText:
Miss Elizabeth Bennet! I am all astonishment.
How long has she been such a favourite?--and pray when am I to wish you
joy?
subQuotationList: ['Miss Elizabeth Bennet!', 'I am all astonishment.\nHow long has she been such a favourite?--and pray when am I to wish you\njoy?']
speaker: Miss Bingley

quoteText:
That is exactly the question which I expected you to ask. A lady's
imagination is very rapid; it jumps from admiration to love, from love
to matrimony in a moment. I knew you would be wishing me joy.
subQuotationList: ["That is exactly the question which I expected you to ask. A lady's\nimagination is very rapid; it jumps from admiration to love, from love\nto matrimony in a moment. I knew you would be wishing me joy."]
speaker: Mr. Darcy

quoteText:
Nay, if you are so serious about it, I shall consider the matter as
absolutely settled. You will have a charming mother-in-law, indeed, and
of course she will be always at Pemberley with you.
subQuotationList: ['Nay, if you are so serious about it, I shall consider the matter as\nabsolutely settled. You will have a charming mother-in-law, indeed, and\nof course she will be always at Pemberley with you.']
speaker: Miss Bingley

quoteText:
From all that I can collect by your manner of talking, you must be two
of the silliest girls in the country. I have suspected it some time, but
I am now convinced.
subQuotationList: ['From all that I can collect by your manner of talking, you must be two\nof the silliest girls in the country. I have suspected it some time, but\nI am now convinced.']
speaker: Mr. Bennet

quoteText:
I am astonished, my dear, that you should be so
ready to think your own children silly. If I wished to think slightingly
of any body's children, it should not be of my own however.
subQuotationList: ['I am astonished, my dear,', "that you should be so\nready to think your own children silly. If I wished to think slightingly\nof any body's children, it should not be of my own however."]
speaker: Mrs. Bennet

quoteText: If my children are silly I must hope to be always sensible of it.
subQuotationList: ['If my children are silly I must hope to be always sensible of it.']
speaker: Mr. Bennet

quoteText: Yes--but as it happens, they are all of them very clever.
subQuotationList: ['Yes--but as it happens, they are all of them very clever.']
speaker: Mrs. Bennet

quoteText:
This is the only point, I flatter myself, on which we do not agree. I
had hoped that our sentiments coincided in every particular, but I must
so far differ from you as to think our two youngest daughters uncommonly
foolish.
subQuotationList:
['This is the only point, I flatter myself, on which we do not agree. I
had hoped that our sentiments coincided in every particular, but I must
so far differ from you as to think our two youngest daughters uncommonly
foolish.']
speaker: Mr. Bennet

quoteText:
My dear Mr. Bennet, you must not expect such girls to have the sense of
their father and mother.--When they get to our age I dare say they will
not think about officers any more than we do. I remember the time when I
liked a red coat myself very well--and indeed so I do still at my heart;
and if a smart young colonel, with five or six thousand a year, should
want one of my girls, I shall not say nay to him; and I thought Colonel
Forster looked very becoming the other night at Sir William's in his
regimentals.
subQuotationList:
["My dear Mr. Bennet, you must not expect such girls to have the sense of
their father and mother.--When they get to our age I dare say they will
not think about officers any more than we do. I remember the time when I
liked a red coat myself very well--and indeed so I do still at my heart;
and if a smart young colonel, with five or six thousand a year, should
want one of my girls, I shall not say nay to him; and I thought Colonel
Forster looked very becoming the other night at Sir William's in his
regimentals."]
speaker: Mrs. Bennet
mentionTextsList: [['My dear Mr. Bennet', 'you', 'their father and mother', 'they', 'our ', 'they', 'we', 'my girls', 'Colonel\nForster', 'Sir William']]
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. Bennet'], ['Mr. Bennet'], ['Mrs. Bennet', 'Mr. Bennet'], ['Kitty', 'Lydia'], ['Mr. Bennet', 'Mrs. Bennet'], ['Kitty', 'Lydia'], ['Mr. Bennet', 'Mrs. Bennet'], ['Elizabeth', 'Jane', 'Lydia', 'Kitty', 'Mary'], ['Colonel Forster'], ['Sir William Lucas']]]

quoteText:
Mama, my aunt says that Colonel Forster and Captain
Carter do not go so often to Miss Watson's as they did when they first
came; she sees them now very often standing in Clarke's library.
subQuotationList: ['Mama,', "my aunt says that Colonel Forster and Captain\nCarter do not go so often to Miss Watson's as they did when they first\ncame; she sees them now very often standing in Clarke's library."]
speaker: Lydia
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mrs. Bennet']], [['Colonel Forster'], ['Captain Carter'], ['Miss Watson'], ['Colonel Forster', 'Captain Carter'], ['Colonel Forster', 'Captain Carter'], ['Colonel Forster', 'Captain Carter'], ['Clarke']]]

quoteText:
Well, Jane, who is it from? what is it about? what does he say? Well,
Jane, make haste and tell us; make haste, my love.
subQuotationList: ['Well, Jane, who is it from? what is it about? what does he say? Well,\nJane, make haste and tell us; make haste, my love.']
speaker: Mrs. Bennet

quoteText: It is from Miss Bingley,
subQuotationList: ['It is from Miss Bingley,']
speaker: Jane

quoteText:
With the officers! I wonder my aunt did not tell us of
_that_.
subQuotationList: ['With the officers!', 'I wonder my aunt did not tell us of\n_that_.']
speaker: Lydia

quoteText: Dining out, that is very unlucky.
subQuotationList: ['Dining out,', 'that is very unlucky.']
speaker: Mrs. Bennet

quoteText: Can I have the carriage?
subQuotationList: ['Can I have the carriage?']
speaker: Jane

quoteText:
No, my dear, you had better go on horseback, because it seems likely to
rain; and then you must stay all night.
subQuotationList: ['No, my dear, you had better go on horseback, because it seems likely to\nrain; and then you must stay all night.']
speaker: Mrs. Bennet

quoteText:
That would be a good scheme, if you were sure that
they would not offer to send her home.
subQuotationList: ['That would be a good scheme,', 'if you were sure that\nthey would not offer to send her home.']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
Oh! but the gentlemen will have Mr. Bingley's chaise to go to Meryton;
and the Hursts have no horses to theirs.
subQuotationList: ["Oh! but the gentlemen will have Mr. Bingley's chaise to go to Meryton;\nand the Hursts have no horses to theirs."]
speaker: Mrs. Bennet

quoteText: I had much rather go in the coach.
subQuotationList: ['I had much rather go in the coach.']
speaker: Jane

quoteText:
But, my dear, your father cannot spare the horses, I am sure. They are
wanted in the farm, Mr. Bennet, are not they?
subQuotationList: ['But, my dear, your father cannot spare the horses, I am sure. They are\nwanted in the farm, Mr. Bennet, are not they?']
speaker: Mrs. Bennet

quoteText: They are wanted in the farm much oftener than I can get them.
subQuotationList: ['They are wanted in the farm much oftener than I can get them.']
speaker: Mr. Bennet

quoteText:
But if you have got them to-day, my mother's purpose
will be answered.
subQuotationList: ['But if you have got them to-day,', "my mother's purpose\nwill be answered."]
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText: This was a lucky idea of mine, indeed!
subQuotationList: ['This was a lucky idea of mine, indeed!']
speaker: Mrs. Bennet

quoteText:
Well, my dear, if your daughter should have a dangerous fit of illness, if she
should die, it would be a comfort to know that it was all in pursuit of
Mr. Bingley, and under your orders.
subQuotationList: ['Well, my dear,', 'if your daughter should have a dangerous fit of illness, if she\nshould die, it would be a comfort to know that it was all in pursuit of\nMr. Bingley, and under your orders.']
speaker: Mr. Bennet

quoteText:
Oh! I am not at all afraid of her dying. People do not die of little
trifling colds. She will be taken good care of. As long as she stays
there, it is all very well. I would go and see her, if I could have the
carriage.
subQuotationList:
['Oh! I am not at all afraid of her dying. People do not die of little
trifling colds. She will be taken good care of. As long as she stays
there, it is all very well. I would go and see her, if I could have the
carriage.']
speaker: Mrs. Bennet

quoteText:
How can you be so silly, as to think of such a
thing, in all this dirt! You will not be fit to be seen when you get
there.
subQuotationList: ['How can you be so silly,', 'as to think of such a\nthing, in all this dirt! You will not be fit to be seen when you get\nthere.']
speaker: Mrs. Bennet

quoteText: I shall be very fit to see Jane--which is all I want.
subQuotationList: ['I shall be very fit to see Jane--which is all I want.']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
Is this a hint to me, Lizzy, to send for the
horses?
subQuotationList: ['Is this a hint to me, Lizzy,', 'to send for the\nhorses?']
speaker: Mr. Bennet

quoteText:
No, indeed. I do not wish to avoid the walk. The distance is nothing,
when one has a motive; only three miles. I shall be back by dinner.
subQuotationList: ['No, indeed. I do not wish to avoid the walk. The distance is nothing,\nwhen one has a motive; only three miles. I shall be back by dinner.']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
I admire the activity of your benevolence, but every
impulse of feeling should be guided by reason; and, in my opinion,
exertion should always be in proportion to what is required.
subQuotationList: ['I admire the activity of your benevolence,', 'but every\nimpulse of feeling should be guided by reason; and, in my opinion,\nexertion should always be in proportion to what is required.']
speaker: Mary

quoteText:
If we make haste, perhaps we may
see something of Captain Carter before he goes.
subQuotationList: ['If we make haste,', 'perhaps we may\nsee something of Captain Carter before he goes.']
speaker: Lydia

quoteText:
She has nothing, in short, to recommend her, but being an excellent
walker. I shall never forget her appearance this morning. She really
looked almost wild.
subQuotationList: ['She has nothing, in short, to recommend her, but being an excellent\nwalker. I shall never forget her appearance this morning. She really\nlooked almost wild.']
speaker: Mrs. Hurst
referringExpression: Mrs Hurst thought the same and added

quoteText:
She did indeed, Louisa. I could hardly keep my countenance. Very
nonsensical to come at all! Why must _she_ be scampering about the
country, because her sister had a cold? Her hair so untidy, so blowsy!
subQuotationList: ['She did indeed, Louisa. I could hardly keep my countenance. Very\nnonsensical to come at all! Why must _she_ be scampering about the\ncountry, because her sister had a cold? Her hair so untidy, so blowsy!']
speaker: Miss Bingley

quoteText:
Yes, and her petticoat; I hope you saw her petticoat, six inches deep
in mud, I am absolutely certain; and the gown which had been let down to
hide it, not doing its office.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, and her petticoat; I hope you saw her petticoat, six inches deep\nin mud, I am absolutely certain; and the gown which had been let down to\nhide it, not doing its office.']
speaker: Mrs. Hurst

quoteText:
Your picture may be very exact, Louisa, but this was
all lost upon me. I thought Miss Elizabeth Bennet looked remarkably
well, when she came into the room this morning. Her dirty petticoat
quite escaped my notice.
subQuotationList:
['Your picture may be very exact, Louisa,', 'but this was
all lost upon me. I thought Miss Elizabeth Bennet looked remarkably
well, when she came into the room this morning. Her dirty petticoat
quite escaped my notice.']
speaker: Mr. Bingley

quoteText:
_You_ observed it, Mr. Darcy, I am sure, and I am
inclined to think that you would not wish to see _your sister_ make such
an exhibition.
subQuotationList: ['_You_ observed it, Mr. Darcy, I am sure,', 'and I am\ninclined to think that you would not wish to see _your sister_ make such\nan exhibition.']
speaker: Miss Bingley

quoteText: Certainly not.
subQuotationList: ['Certainly not.']
speaker: Mr. Darcy

quoteText:
To walk three miles, or four miles, or five miles, or whatever it is,
above her ancles in dirt, and alone, quite alone! what could she mean by
it? It seems to me to shew an abominable sort of conceited independence,
a most country town indifference to decorum.
subQuotationList:
['To walk three miles, or four miles, or five miles, or whatever it is,
above her ancles in dirt, and alone, quite alone! what could she mean by
it? It seems to me to shew an abominable sort of conceited independence,
a most country town indifference to decorum.']
speaker: Miss Bingley

quoteText: It shews an affection for her sister that is very pleasing,
subQuotationList: ['It shews an affection for her sister that is very pleasing,']
speaker: Mr. Bingley

quoteText:
I am afraid, Mr. Darcy, that this adventure has rather affected your admiration of her fine
eyes.
subQuotationList: ['I am afraid, Mr. Darcy,', 'that this adventure has rather affected your admiration of her fine\neyes.']
speaker: Miss Bingley

quoteText: Not at all, they were brightened by the exercise.
subQuotationList: ['Not at all,', 'they were brightened by the exercise.']
speaker: Mr. Darcy

quoteText:
I have an excessive regard for Jane Bennet, she is really a very sweet
girl, and I wish with all my heart she were well settled. But with such
a father and mother, and such low connections, I am afraid there is no
chance of it.
subQuotationList:
['I have an excessive regard for Jane Bennet, she is really a very sweet
girl, and I wish with all my heart she were well settled. But with such
a father and mother, and such low connections, I am afraid there is no
chance of it.']
speaker: Mrs. Hurst

quoteText:
I think I have heard you say, that their uncle is an attorney in
Meryton.
subQuotationList: ['I think I have heard you say, that their uncle is an attorney in\nMeryton.']
speaker: Miss Bingley

quoteText: Yes; and they have another, who lives somewhere near Cheapside.
subQuotationList: ['Yes; and they have another, who lives somewhere near Cheapside.']
speaker: Mrs. Hurst

quoteText: That is capital,
subQuotationList: ['That is capital,']
speaker: Miss Bingley

quoteText:
If they had uncles enough to fill _all_ Cheapside, it
would not make them one jot less agreeable.
subQuotationList: ['If they had uncles enough to fill _all_ Cheapside,', 'it\nwould not make them one jot less agreeable.']
speaker: Mr. Bingley

quoteText:
But it must very materially lessen their chance of marrying men of any
consideration in the world,
subQuotationList: ['But it must very materially lessen their chance of marrying men of any\nconsideration in the world,']
speaker: Mr. Darcy

quoteText: Do you prefer reading to cards? that is rather singular.
subQuotationList: ['Do you prefer reading to cards?', 'that is rather singular.']
speaker: Mr. Hurst

quoteText:
Miss Eliza Bennet, despises cards. She is a great
reader and has no pleasure in anything else.
subQuotationList: ['Miss Eliza Bennet,', 'despises cards. She is a great\nreader and has no pleasure in anything else.']
speaker: Miss Bingley

quoteText:
I deserve neither such praise nor such censure, I am
_not_ a great reader, and I have pleasure in many things.
subQuotationList: ['I deserve neither such praise nor such censure,', 'I am\n_not_ a great reader, and I have pleasure in many things.']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
In nursing your sister I am sure you have pleasure, and
I hope it will soon be increased by seeing her quite well.
subQuotationList: ['In nursing your sister I am sure you have pleasure,', 'and\nI hope it will soon be increased by seeing her quite well.']
speaker: Mr. Bingley

quoteText:
And I wish my collection were larger for your benefit and my own
credit; but I am an idle fellow, and though I have not many, I have more
than I ever look into.
subQuotationList: ['And I wish my collection were larger for your benefit and my own\ncredit; but I am an idle fellow, and though I have not many, I have more\nthan I ever look into.']
speaker: Mr. Bingley

quoteText:
I am astonished, that my father should have left
so small a collection of books.--What a delightful library you have at
Pemberley, Mr. Darcy!
subQuotationList: ['I am astonished,', 'that my father should have left\nso small a collection of books.--What a delightful library you have at\nPemberley, Mr. Darcy!']
speaker: Miss Bingley

quoteText:
It ought to be good, it has been the work of many
generations.
subQuotationList: ['It ought to be good,', 'it has been the work of many\ngenerations.']
speaker: Mr. Darcy

quoteText:
And then you have added so much to it yourself, you are always buying
books.
subQuotationList: ['And then you have added so much to it yourself, you are always buying\nbooks.']
speaker: Miss Bingley

quoteText:
I cannot comprehend the neglect of a family library in such days as
these.
subQuotationList: ['I cannot comprehend the neglect of a family library in such days as\nthese.']
speaker: Mr. Darcy

quoteText:
Neglect! I am sure you neglect nothing that can add to the beauties of
that noble place. Charles, when you build _your_ house, I wish it may be
half as delightful as Pemberley.
subQuotationList: ['Neglect! I am sure you neglect nothing that can add to the beauties of\nthat noble place. Charles, when you build _your_ house, I wish it may be\nhalf as delightful as Pemberley.']
speaker: Miss Bingley

quoteText: I wish it may.
subQuotationList: ['I wish it may.']
speaker: Mr. Bingley

quoteText:
But I would really advise you to make your purchase in that
neighbourhood, and take Pemberley for a kind of model. There is not a
finer county in England than Derbyshire.
subQuotationList: ['But I would really advise you to make your purchase in that\nneighbourhood, and take Pemberley for a kind of model. There is not a\nfiner county in England than Derbyshire.']
speaker: Miss Bingley

quoteText: With all my heart; I will buy Pemberley itself if Darcy will sell it.
subQuotationList: ['With all my heart; I will buy Pemberley itself if Darcy will sell it.']
speaker: Mr. Bingley

quoteText: I am talking of possibilities, Charles.
subQuotationList: ['I am talking of possibilities, Charles.']
speaker: Miss Bingley

quoteText:
Upon my word, Caroline, I should think it more possible to get
Pemberley by purchase than by imitation.
subQuotationList: ['Upon my word, Caroline, I should think it more possible to get\nPemberley by purchase than by imitation.']
speaker: Mr. Bingley

quoteText:
Is Miss Darcy much grown since the spring? will
she be as tall as I am?
subQuotationList: ['Is Miss Darcy much grown since the spring?', 'will\nshe be as tall as I am?']
speaker: Miss Bingley

quoteText:
I think she will. She is now about Miss Elizabeth Bennet's height, or
rather taller.
subQuotationList: ["I think she will. She is now about Miss Elizabeth Bennet's height, or\nrather taller."]
speaker: Mr. Darcy

quoteText:
How I long to see her again! I never met with anybody who delighted me
so much. Such a countenance, such manners! and so extremely
accomplished for her age! Her performance on the piano-forte is
exquisite.
subQuotationList:
['How I long to see her again! I never met with anybody who delighted me
so much. Such a countenance, such manners! and so extremely
accomplished for her age! Her performance on the piano-forte is
exquisite.']
speaker: Miss Bingley

quoteText:
It is amazing to me, how young ladies can have patience
to be so very accomplished, as they all are.
subQuotationList: ['It is amazing to me,', 'how young ladies can have patience\nto be so very accomplished, as they all are.']
speaker: Mr. Bingley

quoteText: All young ladies accomplished! My dear Charles, what do you mean?
subQuotationList: ['All young ladies accomplished! My dear Charles, what do you mean?']
speaker: Miss Bingley

quoteText:
Yes, all of them, I think. They all paint tables, cover skreens and net
purses. I scarcely know any one who cannot do all this, and I am sure I
never heard a young lady spoken of for the first time, without being
informed that she was very accomplished.
subQuotationList:
['Yes, all of them, I think. They all paint tables, cover skreens and net
purses. I scarcely know any one who cannot do all this, and I am sure I
never heard a young lady spoken of for the first time, without being
informed that she was very accomplished.']
speaker: Mr. Bingley

quoteText:
Your list of the common extent of accomplishments, has
too much truth. The word is applied to many a woman who deserves it no
otherwise than by netting a purse, or covering a skreen. But I am very
far from agreeing with you in your estimation of ladies in general. I
cannot boast of knowing more than half a dozen, in the whole range of my
acquaintance, that are really accomplished.
subQuotationList:
['Your list of the common extent of accomplishments,', 'has
too much truth. The word is applied to many a woman who deserves it no
otherwise than by netting a purse, or covering a skreen. But I am very
far from agreeing with you in your estimation of ladies in general. I
cannot boast of knowing more than half a dozen, in the whole range of my
acquaintance, that are really accomplished.']
speaker: Mr. Darcy

quoteText: Nor I, I am sure,
subQuotationList: ['Nor I, I am sure,']
speaker: Miss Bingley

quoteText:
Then, you must comprehend a great deal in your
idea of an accomplished woman.
subQuotationList: ['Then,', 'you must comprehend a great deal in your\nidea of an accomplished woman.']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText: Yes; I do comprehend a great deal in it.
subQuotationList: ['Yes; I do comprehend a great deal in it.']
speaker: Mr. Darcy

quoteText:
Oh! certainly, no one can be really
esteemed accomplished, who does not greatly surpass what is usually met
with. A woman must have a thorough knowledge of music, singing, drawing,
dancing, and the modern languages, to deserve the word; and besides all
this, she must possess a certain something in her air and manner of
walking, the tone of her voice, her address and expressions, or the word
will be but half deserved.
subQuotationList:
['Oh! certainly,', 'no one can be really
esteemed accomplished, who does not greatly surpass what is usually met
with. A woman must have a thorough knowledge of music, singing, drawing,
dancing, and the modern languages, to deserve the word; and besides all
this, she must possess a certain something in her air and manner of
walking, the tone of her voice, her address and expressions, or the word
will be but half deserved.']
speaker: Miss Bingley

quoteText:
All this she must possess, and to all this she must yet
add something more substantial, in the improvement of her mind by
extensive reading.
subQuotationList: ['All this she must possess,', 'and to all this she must yet\nadd something more substantial, in the improvement of her mind by\nextensive reading.']
speaker: Mr. Darcy

quoteText:
I am no longer surprised at your knowing _only_ six accomplished women.
I rather wonder now at your knowing _any_.
subQuotationList: ['I am no longer surprised at your knowing _only_ six accomplished women.\nI rather wonder now at your knowing _any_.']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
Are you so severe upon your own sex, as to doubt the possibility of all
this?
subQuotationList: ['Are you so severe upon your own sex, as to doubt the possibility of all\nthis?']
speaker: Mr. Darcy

quoteText:
_I_ never saw such a woman. _I_ never saw such capacity, and taste, and
application, and elegance, as you describe, united.
subQuotationList: ['_I_ never saw such a woman. _I_ never saw such capacity, and taste, and\napplication, and elegance, as you describe, united.']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
Eliza Bennet, is
one of those young ladies who seek to recommend themselves to the other
sex, by undervaluing their own; and with many men, I dare say, it
succeeds. But, in my opinion, it is a paltry device, a very mean art.
subQuotationList:
['Eliza Bennet,', 'is
one of those young ladies who seek to recommend themselves to the other
sex, by undervaluing their own; and with many men, I dare say, it
succeeds. But, in my opinion, it is a paltry device, a very mean art.']
speaker: Miss Bingley

quoteText:
Undoubtedly, there is meanness in _all_ the arts which ladies sometimes condescend
to employ for captivation. Whatever bears affinity to cunning is
despicable.
subQuotationList: ['Undoubtedly,', 'there is meanness in _all_ the arts which ladies sometimes condescend\nto employ for captivation. Whatever bears affinity to cunning is\ndespicable.']
speaker: Mr. Darcy

quoteText:
Indeed I have, Sir, She is a great deal too ill to be
moved. Mr. Jones says we must not think of moving her. We must trespass
a little longer on your kindness.
subQuotationList: ['Indeed I have, Sir,', 'She is a great deal too ill to be\nmoved. Mr. Jones says we must not think of moving her. We must trespass\na little longer on your kindness.']
speaker: Mrs. Bennet

quoteText:
Removed! It must not be thought of. My sister, I am
sure, will not hear of her removal.
subQuotationList: ['Removed!', 'It must not be thought of. My sister, I am\nsure, will not hear of her removal.']
speaker: Mr. Bingley

quoteText:
You may depend upon it, Madam, that Miss Bennet shall receive every possible attention while she
remains with us.
subQuotationList: ['You may depend upon it, Madam,', 'that Miss Bennet shall receive every possible attention while she\nremains with us.']
speaker: Miss Bingley

quoteText:
I am sure, if it was not for such good friends I do not
know what would become of her, for she is very ill indeed, and suffers a
vast deal, though with the greatest patience in the world, which is
always the way with her, for she has, without exception, the sweetest
