temper I ever met with. I often tell my other girls they are nothing to
_her_. You have a sweet room here, Mr. Bingley, and a charming prospect
over that gravel walk. I do not know a place in the country that is
equal to Netherfield. You will not think of quitting it in a hurry I
hope, though you have but a short lease.
subQuotationList:
['I am sure,', 'if it was not for such good friends I do not
know what would become of her, for she is very ill indeed, and suffers a
vast deal, though with the greatest patience in the world, which is
always the way with her, for she has, without exception, the sweetest
temper I ever met with. I often tell my other girls they are nothing to
_her_. You have a sweet room here, Mr. Bingley, and a charming prospect
over that gravel walk. I do not know a place in the country that is
equal to Netherfield. You will not think of quitting it in a hurry I
hope, though you have but a short lease.']
speaker: Mrs. Bennet
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Miss Bingley', 'Mr. Bingley'], ['Jane'], ['Jane'], ['Jane'], ['Jane'], ['Lydia', 'Kitty', 'Elizabeth', 'Mary'], ['Mary', 'Elizabeth', 'Lydia', 'Kitty'], ['Jane'], ['Mr. Bingley'], ['Mr. Bingley'], ['Mr. Bingley'], ['Mr. Bingley']]]

quoteText:
Whatever I do is done in a hurry, and therefore if I
should resolve to quit Netherfield, I should probably be off in five
minutes. At present, however, I consider myself as quite fixed here.
subQuotationList: ['Whatever I do is done in a hurry,', 'and therefore if I\nshould resolve to quit Netherfield, I should probably be off in five\nminutes. At present, however, I consider myself as quite fixed here.']
speaker: Mr. Bingley

quoteText: That is exactly what I should have supposed of you,
subQuotationList: ['That is exactly what I should have supposed of you,']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText: You begin to comprehend me, do you?
subQuotationList: ['You begin to comprehend me, do you?']
speaker: Mr. Bingley

quoteText: Oh! yes--I understand you perfectly.
subQuotationList: ['Oh! yes--I understand you perfectly.']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
I wish I might take this for a compliment; but to be so easily seen
through I am afraid is pitiful.
subQuotationList: ['I wish I might take this for a compliment; but to be so easily seen\nthrough I am afraid is pitiful.']
speaker: Mr. Bingley

quoteText:
That is as it happens. It does not necessarily follow that a deep,
intricate character is more or less estimable than such a one as yours.
subQuotationList: ['That is as it happens. It does not necessarily follow that a deep,\nintricate character is more or less estimable than such a one as yours.']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
Lizzy, remember where you are, and do not run on in
the wild manner that you are suffered to do at home.
subQuotationList: ['Lizzy,', 'remember where you are, and do not run on in\nthe wild manner that you are suffered to do at home.']
speaker: Mrs. Bennet

quoteText:
I did not know before, that you were a
studier of character. It must be an amusing study.
subQuotationList: ['I did not know before,', 'that you were a\nstudier of character. It must be an amusing study.']
speaker: Mr. Bingley

quoteText:
Yes; but intricate characters are the _most_ amusing. They have at
least that advantage.
subQuotationList: ['Yes; but intricate characters are the _most_ amusing. They have at\nleast that advantage.']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
The country, can in general supply but few subjects for
such a study. In a country neighbourhood you move in a very confined
and unvarying society.
subQuotationList: ['The country,', 'can in general supply but few subjects for\nsuch a study. In a country neighbourhood you move in a very confined\nand unvarying society.']
speaker: Mr. Darcy

quoteText:
But people themselves alter so much, that there is something new to be
observed in them for ever.
subQuotationList: ['But people themselves alter so much, that there is something new to be\nobserved in them for ever.']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
Yes, indeed, I assure you there is quite as much of _that_
going on in the country as in town.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, indeed,', 'I assure you there is quite as much of _that_\ngoing on in the country as in town.']
speaker: Mrs. Bennet

quoteText:
I cannot see that London has any great advantage over the country for
my part, except the shops and public places. The country is a vast deal
pleasanter, is not it, Mr. Bingley?
subQuotationList: ['I cannot see that London has any great advantage over the country for\nmy part, except the shops and public places. The country is a vast deal\npleasanter, is not it, Mr. Bingley?']
speaker: Mrs. Bennet

quoteText:
Aye--that is because you have the right disposition. But that
gentleman,
subQuotationList: ['Aye--that is because you have the right disposition. But that\ngentleman,']
speaker: Mrs. Bennet

quoteText:
seemed to think the country was nothing
at all.
subQuotationList: ['seemed to think the country was nothing\nat all.']
speaker: Mrs. Bennet

quoteText:
Indeed, Mama, you are mistaken, You quite mistook Mr. Darcy. He only meant that there were not
such a variety of people to be met with in the country as in town, which
you must acknowledge to be true.
subQuotationList: ['Indeed, Mama, you are mistaken,', 'You quite mistook Mr. Darcy. He only meant that there were not\nsuch a variety of people to be met with in the country as in town, which\nyou must acknowledge to be true.']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
Certainly, my dear, nobody said there were; but as to not meeting with
many people in this neighbourhood, I believe there are few
neighbourhoods larger. I know we dine with four and twenty families.
subQuotationList: ['Certainly, my dear, nobody said there were; but as to not meeting with\nmany people in this neighbourhood, I believe there are few\nneighbourhoods larger. I know we dine with four and twenty families.']
speaker: Mrs. Bennet

quoteText:
Yes, she called yesterday with her father. What an agreeable man Sir
William is, Mr. Bingley--is not he? so much the man of fashion! so
genteel and so easy!--He has always something to say to every
body.--_That_ is my idea of good breeding; and those persons who fancy
themselves very important and never open their mouths, quite mistake the
matter.
subQuotationList:
['Yes, she called yesterday with her father. What an agreeable man Sir
William is, Mr. Bingley--is not he? so much the man of fashion! so
genteel and so easy!--He has always something to say to every
body.--_That_ is my idea of good breeding; and those persons who fancy
themselves very important and never open their mouths, quite mistake the
matter.']
speaker: Mrs. Bennet
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Charlotte Lucas'], ['Sir William Lucas'], ['Sir William Lucas'], ['Mr. Bingley'], ['Sir William Lucas'], ['Sir William Lucas'], ['Sir William Lucas', 'Charlotte Lucas']]]

quoteText: Did Charlotte dine with you?
subQuotationList: ['Did Charlotte dine with you?']
speaker: Mr. Bingley

quoteText:
No, she would go home. I fancy she was wanted about the mince pies. For
my part, Mr. Bingley, _I_ always keep servants that can do their own
work; _my_ daughters are brought up differently. But every body is to
judge for themselves, and the Lucases are very good sort of girls, I
assure you. It is a pity they are not handsome! Not that _I_ think
Charlotte so _very_ plain--but then she is our particular friend.
subQuotationList:
['No, she would go home. I fancy she was wanted about the mince pies. For
my part, Mr. Bingley, _I_ always keep servants that can do their own
work; _my_ daughters are brought up differently. But every body is to
judge for themselves, and the Lucases are very good sort of girls, I
assure you. It is a pity they are not handsome! Not that _I_ think
Charlotte so _very_ plain--but then she is our particular friend.']
speaker: Mrs. Bennet
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Charlotte Lucas'], ['Charlotte Lucas'], ['Mr. Bingley'], ['Mary', 'Elizabeth', 'Lydia', 'Kitty', 'Jane'], ['Lydia', 'Kitty', 'Jane', 'Elizabeth', 'Mary'], ['Charlotte Lucas', 'Sir William Lucas', 'Miss Lucas'], ['Mr. Bingley'], ['Charlotte Lucas', 'Sir William Lucas', 'Miss Lucas'], ['Charlotte Lucas'], ['Charlotte Lucas']]]

quoteText: She seems a very pleasant young woman,
subQuotationList: ['She seems a very pleasant young woman,']
speaker: Mr. Bingley

quoteText:
Oh! dear, yes;--but you must own she is very plain. Lady Lucas herself
has often said so, and envied me Jane's beauty. I do not like to boast
of my own child, but to be sure, Jane--one does not often see any body
better looking. It is what every body says. I do not trust my own
partiality. When she was only fifteen, there was a gentleman at my
brother Gardiner's in town, so much in love with her, that my
sister-in-law was sure he would make her an offer before we came away.
But however he did not. Perhaps he thought her too young. However, he
wrote some verses on her, and very pretty they were.
subQuotationList:
["Oh! dear, yes;--but you must own she is very plain. Lady Lucas herself
has often said so, and envied me Jane's beauty. I do not like to boast
of my own child, but to be sure, Jane--one does not often see any body
better looking. It is what every body says. I do not trust my own
partiality. When she was only fifteen, there was a gentleman at my
brother Gardiner's in town, so much in love with her, that my
sister-in-law was sure he would make her an offer before we came away.
But however he did not. Perhaps he thought her too young. However, he
wrote some verses on her, and very pretty they were."]
speaker: Mrs. Bennet

quoteText:
And so ended his affection, There has
been many a one, I fancy, overcome in the same way. I wonder who first
discovered the efficacy of poetry in driving away love!
subQuotationList: ['And so ended his affection,', 'There has\nbeen many a one, I fancy, overcome in the same way. I wonder who first\ndiscovered the efficacy of poetry in driving away love!']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText: I have been used to consider poetry as the _food_ of love,
subQuotationList: ['I have been used to consider poetry as the _food_ of love,']
speaker: Mr. Darcy

quoteText:
Of a fine, stout, healthy love it may. Every thing nourishes what is
strong already. But if it be only a slight, thin sort of inclination, I
am convinced that one good sonnet will starve it entirely away.
subQuotationList: ['Of a fine, stout, healthy love it may. Every thing nourishes what is\nstrong already. But if it be only a slight, thin sort of inclination, I\nam convinced that one good sonnet will starve it entirely away.']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
I am perfectly ready, I assure you, to keep my engagement; and when
your sister is recovered, you shall if you please name the very day of
the ball. But you would not wish to be dancing while she is ill.
subQuotationList: ['I am perfectly ready, I assure you, to keep my engagement; and when\nyour sister is recovered, you shall if you please name the very day of\nthe ball. But you would not wish to be dancing while she is ill.']
speaker: Mr. Bingley

quoteText:
Oh! yes--it would be much better to
wait till Jane was well, and by that time most likely Captain Carter
would be at Meryton again. And when you have given _your_ ball, I shall insist on their giving one also. I shall tell Colonel
Forster it will be quite a shame if he does not.
subQuotationList:
['Oh! yes--it would be much better to
wait till Jane was well, and by that time most likely Captain Carter
would be at Meryton again. And when you have given _your_ ball,', 'I shall insist on their giving one also. I shall tell Colonel
Forster it will be quite a shame if he does not.']
speaker: Lydia

quoteText: How delighted Miss Darcy will be to receive such a letter!
subQuotationList: ['How delighted Miss Darcy will be to receive such a letter!']
speaker: Miss Bingley

quoteText: You write uncommonly fast.
subQuotationList: ['You write uncommonly fast.']
speaker: Miss Bingley

quoteText: You are mistaken. I write rather slowly.
subQuotationList: ['You are mistaken. I write rather slowly.']
speaker: Mr. Darcy

quoteText:
How many letters you must have occasion to write in the course of the
year! Letters of business too! How odious I should think them!
subQuotationList: ['How many letters you must have occasion to write in the course of the\nyear! Letters of business too! How odious I should think them!']
speaker: Miss Bingley

quoteText: It is fortunate, then, that they fall to my lot instead of to yours.
subQuotationList: ['It is fortunate, then, that they fall to my lot instead of to yours.']
speaker: Mr. Darcy

quoteText: Pray tell your sister that I long to see her.
subQuotationList: ['Pray tell your sister that I long to see her.']
speaker: Miss Bingley

quoteText: I have already told her so once, by your desire.
subQuotationList: ['I have already told her so once, by your desire.']
speaker: Mr. Darcy

quoteText:
I am afraid you do not like your pen. Let me mend it for you. I mend
pens remarkably well.
subQuotationList: ['I am afraid you do not like your pen. Let me mend it for you. I mend\npens remarkably well.']
speaker: Miss Bingley

quoteText: Thank you--but I always mend my own.
subQuotationList: ['Thank you--but I always mend my own.']
speaker: Mr. Darcy

quoteText: How can you contrive to write so even?
subQuotationList: ['How can you contrive to write so even?']
speaker: Miss Bingley

quoteText:
Tell your sister I am delighted to hear of her improvement on the harp,
and pray let her know that I am quite in raptures with her beautiful
little design for a table, and I think it infinitely superior to Miss
Grantley's.
subQuotationList:
["Tell your sister I am delighted to hear of her improvement on the harp,
and pray let her know that I am quite in raptures with her beautiful
little design for a table, and I think it infinitely superior to Miss
Grantley's."]
speaker: Miss Bingley

quoteText:
Will you give me leave to defer your raptures till I write again?--At
present I have not room to do them justice.
subQuotationList: ['Will you give me leave to defer your raptures till I write again?--At\npresent I have not room to do them justice.']
speaker: Mr. Darcy

quoteText:
Oh! it is of no consequence. I shall see her in January. But do you
always write such charming long letters to her, Mr. Darcy?
subQuotationList: ['Oh! it is of no consequence. I shall see her in January. But do you\nalways write such charming long letters to her, Mr. Darcy?']
speaker: Miss Bingley

quoteText:
They are generally long; but whether always charming, it is not for me
to determine.
subQuotationList: ['They are generally long; but whether always charming, it is not for me\nto determine.']
speaker: Mr. Darcy

quoteText:
It is a rule with me, that a person who can write a long letter, with
ease, cannot write ill.
subQuotationList: ['It is a rule with me, that a person who can write a long letter, with\nease, cannot write ill.']
speaker: Miss Bingley

quoteText:
That will not do for a compliment to Darcy, Caroline, because he does _not_ write with ease. He studies too much for
words of four syllables.--Do not you, Darcy?
subQuotationList: ['That will not do for a compliment to Darcy, Caroline,', 'because he does _not_ write with ease. He studies too much for\nwords of four syllables.--Do not you, Darcy?']
speaker: Mr. Bingley
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. Darcy'], ['Miss Bingley']], [['Mr. Darcy'], ['Mr. Darcy'], ['Mr. Darcy'], ['Mr. Darcy']]]

quoteText: My style of writing is very different from yours.
subQuotationList: ['My style of writing is very different from yours.']
speaker: Mr. Darcy

quoteText:
Oh! Charles writes in the most careless way
imaginable. He leaves out half his words, and blots the rest.
subQuotationList: ['Oh!', 'Charles writes in the most careless way\nimaginable. He leaves out half his words, and blots the rest.']
speaker: Miss Bingley

quoteText:
My ideas flow so rapidly that I have not time to express them--by which
means my letters sometimes convey no ideas at all to my correspondents.
subQuotationList: ['My ideas flow so rapidly that I have not time to express them--by which\nmeans my letters sometimes convey no ideas at all to my correspondents.']
speaker: Mr. Bingley

quoteText: Your humility, Mr. Bingley, must disarm reproof.
subQuotationList: ['Your humility, Mr. Bingley,', 'must disarm reproof.']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
Nothing is more deceitful, than the appearance of
humility. It is often only carelessness of opinion, and sometimes an
indirect boast.
subQuotationList: ['Nothing is more deceitful,', 'than the appearance of\nhumility. It is often only carelessness of opinion, and sometimes an\nindirect boast.']
speaker: Mr. Darcy

quoteText: And which of the two do you call _my_ little recent piece of modesty?
subQuotationList: ['And which of the two do you call _my_ little recent piece of modesty?']
speaker: Mr. Bingley

quoteText:
The indirect boast;--for you are really proud of your defects in
writing, because you consider them as proceeding from a rapidity of
thought and carelessness of execution, which if not estimable, you think
at least highly interesting. The power of doing any thing with
quickness is always much prized by the possessor, and often without any
attention to the imperfection of the performance. When you told Mrs.
Bennet this morning that if you ever resolved on quitting Netherfield
you should be gone in five minutes, you meant it to be a sort of
panegyric, of compliment to yourself--and yet what is there so very
laudable in a precipitance which must leave very necessary business
undone, and can be of no real advantage to yourself or any one else?
subQuotationList:
['The indirect boast;--for you are really proud of your defects in
writing, because you consider them as proceeding from a rapidity of
thought and carelessness of execution, which if not estimable, you think
at least highly interesting. The power of doing any thing with
quickness is always much prized by the possessor, and often without any
attention to the imperfection of the performance. When you told Mrs.
Bennet this morning that if you ever resolved on quitting Netherfield
you should be gone in five minutes, you meant it to be a sort of
panegyric, of compliment to yourself--and yet what is there so very
laudable in a precipitance which must leave very necessary business
undone, and can be of no real advantage to yourself or any one else?']
speaker: Mr. Darcy
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. Bingley'], ['Mr. Bingley'], ['Mr. Bingley'], ['Mr. Bingley'], ['Mr. Bingley'], ['Mrs. Bennet'], ['Mr. Bingley'], ['Mr. Bingley'], ['Mr. Bingley'], ['Mr. Bingley']]]

quoteText:
Nay, this is too much, to remember at night all the
foolish things that were said in the morning. And yet, upon my honour, I
believed what I said of myself to be true, and I believe it at this
moment. At least, therefore, I did not assume the character of needless
precipitance merely to shew off before the ladies.
subQuotationList:
['Nay,', 'this is too much, to remember at night all the
foolish things that were said in the morning. And yet, upon my honour, I
believed what I said of myself to be true, and I believe it at this
moment. At least, therefore, I did not assume the character of needless
precipitance merely to shew off before the ladies.']
speaker: Mr. Bingley

quoteText:
I dare say you believed it; but I am by no means convinced that you
would be gone with such celerity. Your conduct would be quite as
dependant on chance as that of any man I know; and if, as you were
mounting your horse, a friend were to say, 'Bingley, you had better stay
till next week,' you would probably do it, you would probably not
go--and, at another word, might stay a month.
subQuotationList:
["I dare say you believed it; but I am by no means convinced that you
would be gone with such celerity. Your conduct would be quite as
dependant on chance as that of any man I know; and if, as you were
mounting your horse, a friend were to say, 'Bingley, you had better stay
till next week,' you would probably do it, you would probably not
go--and, at another word, might stay a month."]
speaker: Mr. Darcy
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. Bingley'], ['Mr. Bingley'], ['Mr. Bingley'], ['Mr. Bingley'], ['Mr. Bingley'], ['Mr. Bingley'], ['Mr. Bingley'], ['Mr. Bingley'], ['Mr. Bingley']]]

quoteText:
You have only proved by this, that Mr. Bingley did
not do justice to his own disposition. You have shewn him off now much
more than he did himself.
subQuotationList: ['You have only proved by this,', 'that Mr. Bingley did\nnot do justice to his own disposition. You have shewn him off now much\nmore than he did himself.']
speaker: Elizabeth
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Mr. Bingley'], ['Mr. Bingley'], ['Mr. Darcy'], ['Mr. Bingley'], ['Mr. Bingley'], ['Mr. Bingley']]]

quoteText:
I am exceedingly gratified, by your converting what my
friend says into a compliment on the sweetness of my temper. But I am
afraid you are giving it a turn which that gentleman did by no means
intend; for he would certainly think the better of me, if under such a
circumstance I were to give a flat denial, and ride off as fast as I
could.
subQuotationList:
['I am exceedingly gratified,', 'by your converting what my
friend says into a compliment on the sweetness of my temper. But I am
afraid you are giving it a turn which that gentleman did by no means
intend; for he would certainly think the better of me, if under such a
circumstance I were to give a flat denial, and ride off as fast as I
could.']
speaker: Mr. Bingley

quoteText:
Would Mr. Darcy then consider the rashness of your original intention
as atoned for by your obstinacy in adhering to it?
subQuotationList: ['Would Mr. Darcy then consider the rashness of your original intention\nas atoned for by your obstinacy in adhering to it?']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
Upon my word I cannot exactly explain the matter, Darcy must speak for
himself.
subQuotationList: ['Upon my word I cannot exactly explain the matter, Darcy must speak for\nhimself.']
speaker: Mr. Bingley

quoteText:
You expect me to account for opinions which you chuse to call mine, but
which I have never acknowledged. Allowing the case, however, to stand
according to your representation, you must remember, Miss Bennet, that
the friend who is supposed to desire his return to the house, and the
delay of his plan, has merely desired it, asked it without offering one
argument in favour of its propriety.
subQuotationList:
['You expect me to account for opinions which you chuse to call mine, but
which I have never acknowledged. Allowing the case, however, to stand
according to your representation, you must remember, Miss Bennet, that
the friend who is supposed to desire his return to the house, and the
delay of his plan, has merely desired it, asked it without offering one
argument in favour of its propriety.']
speaker: Mr. Darcy

quoteText:
To yield readily--easily--to the _persuasion_ of a friend is no merit
with you.
subQuotationList: ['To yield readily--easily--to the _persuasion_ of a friend is no merit\nwith you.']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
To yield without conviction is no compliment to the understanding of
either.
subQuotationList: ['To yield without conviction is no compliment to the understanding of\neither.']
speaker: Mr. Darcy

quoteText:
You appear to me, Mr. Darcy, to allow nothing for the influence of
friendship and affection. A regard for the requester would often make
one readily yield to a request, without waiting for arguments to reason
one into it. I am not particularly speaking of such a case as you have
supposed about Mr. Bingley. We may as well wait, perhaps, till the
circumstance occurs, before we discuss the discretion of his behaviour
thereupon. But in general and ordinary cases between friend and friend,
where one of them is desired by the other to change a resolution of no
very great moment, should you think ill of that person for complying
with the desire, without waiting to be argued into it?
subQuotationList:
['You appear to me, Mr. Darcy, to allow nothing for the influence of
friendship and affection. A regard for the requester would often make
one readily yield to a request, without waiting for arguments to reason
one into it. I am not particularly speaking of such a case as you have
supposed about Mr. Bingley. We may as well wait, perhaps, till the
circumstance occurs, before we discuss the discretion of his behaviour
thereupon. But in general and ordinary cases between friend and friend,
where one of them is desired by the other to change a resolution of no
very great moment, should you think ill of that person for complying
with the desire, without waiting to be argued into it?']
speaker: Elizabeth
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. Darcy'], ['Mr. Darcy'], ['Mr. Darcy'], ['Mr. Bingley'], ['Mr. Darcy', 'Elizabeth'], ['Mr. Darcy', 'Elizabeth'], ['Mr. Bingley'], ['Mr. Darcy']]]

quoteText:
Will it not be advisable, before we proceed on this subject, to arrange
with rather more precision the degree of importance which is to
appertain to this request, as well as the degree of intimacy subsisting
between the parties?
subQuotationList:
['Will it not be advisable, before we proceed on this subject, to arrange
with rather more precision the degree of importance which is to
appertain to this request, as well as the degree of intimacy subsisting
between the parties?']
speaker: Mr. Darcy

quoteText:
By all means, let us hear all the particulars, not
forgetting their comparative height and size; for that will have more
weight in the argument, Miss Bennet, than you may be aware of. I assure
you that if Darcy were not such a great tall fellow, in comparison with
myself, I should not pay him half so much deference. I declare I do not
know a more aweful object than Darcy, on particular occasions, and in
particular places; at his own house especially, and of a Sunday evening
when he has nothing to do.
subQuotationList:
['By all means,', 'let us hear all the particulars, not
forgetting their comparative height and size; for that will have more
weight in the argument, Miss Bennet, than you may be aware of. I assure
you that if Darcy were not such a great tall fellow, in comparison with
myself, I should not pay him half so much deference. I declare I do not
know a more aweful object than Darcy, on particular occasions, and in
particular places; at his own house especially, and of a Sunday evening
when he has nothing to do.']
speaker: Mr. Bingley
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Mr. Darcy', 'Elizabeth', 'Mrs. Hurst', 'Mr. Bingley', 'Mr. Hurst', 'Miss Bingley'], ['Elizabeth'], ['Elizabeth'], ['Mr. Darcy'], ['Mr. Darcy'], ['Mr. Darcy'], ['Mr. Darcy'], ['Mr. Darcy']]]

quoteText:
I see your design, Bingley, You dislike an
argument, and want to silence this.
subQuotationList: ['I see your design, Bingley,', 'You dislike an\nargument, and want to silence this.']
speaker: Mr. Darcy

quoteText:
Perhaps I do. Arguments are too much like disputes. If you and Miss
Bennet will defer yours till I am out of the room, I shall be very
thankful; and then you may say whatever you like of me.
subQuotationList: ['Perhaps I do. Arguments are too much like disputes. If you and Miss\nBennet will defer yours till I am out of the room, I shall be very\nthankful; and then you may say whatever you like of me.']
speaker: Mr. Bingley

quoteText:
What you ask, is no sacrifice on my side; and Mr.
Darcy had much better finish his letter.
subQuotationList: ['What you ask,', 'is no sacrifice on my side; and Mr.\nDarcy had much better finish his letter.']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
Do not you feel a great inclination, Miss Bennet, to seize such an
opportunity of dancing a reel?
subQuotationList: ['Do not you feel a great inclination, Miss Bennet, to seize such an\nopportunity of dancing a reel?']
speaker: Mr. Darcy
referringExpression: Mr Darcy drawing near Elizabeth said to her

quoteText:
Oh! I heard you before; but I could not immediately
determine what to say in reply. You wanted me, I know, to say 'Yes,'
that you might have the pleasure of despising my taste; but I always
delight in overthrowing those kind of schemes, and cheating a person of
their premeditated contempt. I have therefore made up my mind to tell
you, that I do not want to dance a reel at all--and now despise me if
you dare.
subQuotationList:
['Oh!', "I heard you before; but I could not immediately
determine what to say in reply. You wanted me, I know, to say 'Yes,'
that you might have the pleasure of despising my taste; but I always
delight in overthrowing those kind of schemes, and cheating a person of
their premeditated contempt. I have therefore made up my mind to tell
you, that I do not want to dance a reel at all--and now despise me if
you dare."]
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText: Indeed I do not dare.
subQuotationList: ['Indeed I do not dare.']
speaker: Mr. Darcy

quoteText:
I hope, you will give your mother-in-law a few hints, when this
desirable event takes place, as to the advantage of holding her tongue;
and if you can compass it, do cure the younger girls of running after
the officers.--And, if I may mention so delicate a subject, endeavour to
check that little something, bordering on conceit and impertinence,
which your lady possesses.
subQuotationList:
['I hope,', 'you will give your mother-in-law a few hints, when this
desirable event takes place, as to the advantage of holding her tongue;
and if you can compass it, do cure the younger girls of running after
the officers.--And, if I may mention so delicate a subject, endeavour to
check that little something, bordering on conceit and impertinence,
which your lady possesses.']
speaker: Miss Bingley

quoteText: Have you any thing else to propose for my domestic felicity?
subQuotationList: ['Have you any thing else to propose for my domestic felicity?']
speaker: Mr. Darcy

quoteText:
Oh! yes.--Do let the portraits of your uncle and aunt Philips be
placed in the gallery at Pemberley. Put them next to your great uncle
the judge. They are in the same profession, you know; only in different
lines. As for your Elizabeth's picture, you must not attempt to have it
taken, for what painter could do justice to those beautiful eyes?
subQuotationList:
["Oh! yes.--Do let the portraits of your uncle and aunt Philips be
placed in the gallery at Pemberley. Put them next to your great uncle
the judge. They are in the same profession, you know; only in different
lines. As for your Elizabeth's picture, you must not attempt to have it
taken, for what painter could do justice to those beautiful eyes?"]
speaker: Miss Bingley
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mrs. Philips', 'Mr. Philips'], ['Mrs. Philips', 'Mr. Philips'], ['Mr. Darcy'], ['Mr. Darcy'], ['Elizabeth'], ['Mr. Darcy']]]

quoteText:
It would not be easy, indeed, to catch their expression, but their
colour and shape, and the eye-lashes, so remarkably fine, might be
copied.
subQuotationList: ['It would not be easy, indeed, to catch their expression, but their\ncolour and shape, and the eye-lashes, so remarkably fine, might be\ncopied.']
speaker: Mr. Darcy

quoteText: I did not know that you intended to walk,
subQuotationList: ['I did not know that you intended to walk,']
speaker: Miss Bingley

quoteText:
You used us abominably ill, in running away
without telling us that you were coming out.
subQuotationList: ['You used us abominably ill,', 'in running away\nwithout telling us that you were coming out.']
speaker: Mrs. Hurst

quoteText:
This walk is not wide enough for our party. We had better go into the
avenue.
subQuotationList: ['This walk is not wide enough for our party. We had better go into the\navenue.']
speaker: Mr. Darcy
referringExpression: Mr Darcy felt their rudeness and immediately said

quoteText:
No, no; stay where you are.--You are charmingly group'd, and appear to
uncommon advantage. The picturesque would be spoilt by admitting a
fourth. Good bye.
subQuotationList: ["No, no; stay where you are.--You are charmingly group'd, and appear to\nuncommon advantage. The picturesque would be spoilt by admitting a\nfourth. Good bye."]
speaker: Elizabeth
referringExpression: Elizabeth who had not the least inclination to remain with them laughingly answered
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. Darcy', 'Mrs. Hurst', 'Miss Bingley'], ['Mr. Darcy', 'Mrs. Hurst', 'Miss Bingley']]]

quoteText: very glad;
subQuotationList: ['very glad;']
speaker: Mr. Hurst

quoteText:
How pleasant it
is to spend an evening in this way! I declare after all there is no
enjoyment like reading! How much sooner one tires of any thing than of a
book!--When I have a house of my own, I shall be miserable if I have not
an excellent library.
subQuotationList:
['How pleasant it
is to spend an evening in this way! I declare after all there is no
enjoyment like reading! How much sooner one tires of any thing than of a
book!--When I have a house of my own, I shall be miserable if I have not
an excellent library.']
speaker: Miss Bingley
referringExpression: she gave a great yawn and said

quoteText:
By the bye, Charles, are you really serious in meditating a dance at
Netherfield?--I would advise you, before you determine on it, to consult
the wishes of the present party; I am much mistaken if there are not
some among us to whom a ball would be rather a punishment than a
pleasure.
subQuotationList:
['By the bye, Charles, are you really serious in meditating a dance at
Netherfield?--I would advise you, before you determine on it, to consult
the wishes of the present party; I am much mistaken if there are not
some among us to whom a ball would be rather a punishment than a
pleasure.']
speaker: Miss Bingley
referringExpression: she turned suddenly towards him and said
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. Bingley'], ['Mr. Bingley'], ['Mr. Bingley'], ['Mr. Bingley'], ['Elizabeth', 'Jane', 'Mrs. Hurst', 'Miss Bingley', 'Mr. Bingley', 'Mr. Darcy', 'Mr. Hurst'], ['Mr. Darcy', 'Mrs. Hurst', 'Mr. Bingley', 'Mr. Hurst', 'Miss Bingley']]]

quoteText:
If you mean Darcy, he may go to bed, if he chuses,
before it begins--but as for the ball, it is quite a settled thing; and
as soon as Nicholls has made white soup enough I shall send round my
cards.
subQuotationList:
['If you mean Darcy,', 'he may go to bed, if he chuses,
before it begins--but as for the ball, it is quite a settled thing; and
as soon as Nicholls has made white soup enough I shall send round my
cards.']
speaker: Mr. Bingley

quoteText:
I should like balls infinitely better, if they were
carried on in a different manner; but there is something insufferably
tedious in the usual process of such a meeting. It would surely be much
more rational if conversation instead of dancing made the order of the
day.
subQuotationList:
['I should like balls infinitely better,', 'if they were
carried on in a different manner; but there is something insufferably
tedious in the usual process of such a meeting. It would surely be much
more rational if conversation instead of dancing made the order of the
day.']
speaker: Miss Bingley

quoteText:
Much more rational, my dear Caroline, I dare say, but it would not be
near so much like a ball.
subQuotationList: ['Much more rational, my dear Caroline, I dare say, but it would not be\nnear so much like a ball.']
speaker: Mr. Bingley

quoteText:
Miss Eliza Bennet, let me persuade you to follow my example, and take a
turn about the room.--I assure you it is very refreshing after sitting
so long in one attitude.
subQuotationList: ['Miss Eliza Bennet, let me persuade you to follow my example, and take a\nturn about the room.--I assure you it is very refreshing after sitting\nso long in one attitude.']
speaker: Miss Bingley
referringExpression: she resolved on one effort more and turning to Elizabeth said

quoteText:
Not at all, but depend upon it, he means to be severe
on us, and our surest way of disappointing him, will be to ask nothing
about it.
subQuotationList: ['Not at all,', 'but depend upon it, he means to be severe\non us, and our surest way of disappointing him, will be to ask nothing\nabout it.']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
I have not the smallest objection to explaining them, You either chuse this method of passing
the evening because you are in each other's confidence and have secret
affairs to discuss, or because you are conscious that your figures
appear to the greatest advantage in walking;--if the first, I should be
completely in your way;--and if the second, I can admire you much better
as I sit by the fire.
subQuotationList:
['I have not the smallest objection to explaining them,', "You either chuse this method of passing
the evening because you are in each other's confidence and have secret
affairs to discuss, or because you are conscious that your figures
appear to the greatest advantage in walking;--if the first, I should be
completely in your way;--and if the second, I can admire you much better
as I sit by the fire."]
speaker: Mr. Darcy
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Miss Bingley'], ['Miss Bingley'], ['Miss Bingley'], ['Elizabeth', 'Miss Bingley'], ['Elizabeth', 'Miss Bingley'], ['Miss Bingley']]]

quoteText:
Oh! shocking! I never heard any thing so
abominable. How shall we punish him for such a speech?
subQuotationList: ['Oh! shocking!', 'I never heard any thing so\nabominable. How shall we punish him for such a speech?']
speaker: Miss Bingley

quoteText:
Nothing so easy, if you have but the inclination, We
can all plague and punish one another. Teaze him--laugh at
him.--Intimate as you are, you must know how it is to be done.
subQuotationList: ['Nothing so easy, if you have but the inclination,', 'We\ncan all plague and punish one another. Teaze him--laugh at\nhim.--Intimate as you are, you must know how it is to be done.']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
But upon my honour I do _not_. I do assure you that my intimacy has not
yet taught me _that_. Teaze calmness of temper and presence of mind! No,
no--I feel he may defy us there. And as to laughter, we will not expose
ourselves, if you please, by attempting to laugh without a subject. Mr.
Darcy may hug himself.
subQuotationList:
['But upon my honour I do _not_. I do assure you that my intimacy has not
yet taught me _that_. Teaze calmness of temper and presence of mind! No,
no--I feel he may defy us there. And as to laughter, we will not expose
ourselves, if you please, by attempting to laugh without a subject. Mr.
Darcy may hug himself.']
speaker: Miss Bingley

quoteText:
Mr. Darcy is not to be laughed at! That is an
uncommon advantage, and uncommon I hope it will continue, for it would
be a great loss to _me_ to have many such acquaintance. I dearly love a
laugh.
subQuotationList:
['Mr. Darcy is not to be laughed at!', 'That is an
uncommon advantage, and uncommon I hope it will continue, for it would
be a great loss to _me_ to have many such acquaintance. I dearly love a
laugh.']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
Miss Bingley, has given me credit for more than can be. The
wisest and the best of men, nay, the wisest and best of their actions,
may be rendered ridiculous by a person whose first object in life is a
joke.
subQuotationList:
['Miss Bingley,', 'has given me credit for more than can be. The
wisest and the best of men, nay, the wisest and best of their actions,
may be rendered ridiculous by a person whose first object in life is a
joke.']
speaker: Mr. Darcy

quoteText:
Certainly, there are such people, but I hope I am
not one of _them_. I hope I never ridicule what is wise or good. Follies
and nonsense, whims and inconsistencies _do_ divert me, I own, and I
laugh at them whenever I can.--But these, I suppose, are precisely what
you are without.
subQuotationList:
['Certainly,', 'there are such people, but I hope I am
not one of _them_. I hope I never ridicule what is wise or good. Follies
and nonsense, whims and inconsistencies _do_ divert me, I own, and I
laugh at them whenever I can.--But these, I suppose, are precisely what
you are without.']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
Perhaps that is not possible for any one. But it has been the study of
my life to avoid those weaknesses which often expose a strong
understanding to ridicule.
subQuotationList: ['Perhaps that is not possible for any one. But it has been the study of\nmy life to avoid those weaknesses which often expose a strong\nunderstanding to ridicule.']
speaker: Mr. Darcy

quoteText: Such as vanity and pride.
subQuotationList: ['Such as vanity and pride.']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
Yes, vanity is a weakness indeed. But pride--where there is a real
superiority of mind, pride will be always under good regulation.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, vanity is a weakness indeed. But pride--where there is a real\nsuperiority of mind, pride will be always under good regulation.']
speaker: Mr. Darcy

quoteText: Your examination of Mr. Darcy is over, I presume, and pray what is the result?
subQuotationList: ['Your examination of Mr. Darcy is over, I presume,', 'and pray what is the result?']
speaker: Miss Bingley

quoteText:
I am perfectly convinced by it that Mr. Darcy has no defect. He owns it
himself without disguise.
subQuotationList: ['I am perfectly convinced by it that Mr. Darcy has no defect. He owns it\nhimself without disguise.']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
No I have made no such pretension. I have faults enough,
but they are not, I hope, of understanding. My temper I dare not vouch
for.--It is I believe too little yielding--certainly too little for the
convenience of the world. I cannot forget the follies and vices of
others so soon as I ought, nor their offences against myself. My
feelings are not puffed about with every attempt to move them. My temper
would perhaps be called resentful.--My good opinion once lost is lost
for ever.
subQuotationList:
['No', 'I have made no such pretension. I have faults enough,
but they are not, I hope, of understanding. My temper I dare not vouch
for.--It is I believe too little yielding--certainly too little for the
convenience of the world. I cannot forget the follies and vices of
others so soon as I ought, nor their offences against myself. My
feelings are not puffed about with every attempt to move them. My temper
would perhaps be called resentful.--My good opinion once lost is lost
for ever.']
speaker: Mr. Darcy

quoteText:
_That_ is a failing indeed! Implacable resentment
_is_ a shade in a character. But you have chosen your fault well.--I
really cannot _laugh_ at it. You are safe from me.
subQuotationList: ['_That_ is a failing indeed!', 'Implacable resentment\n_is_ a shade in a character. But you have chosen your fault well.--I\nreally cannot _laugh_ at it. You are safe from me.']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
There is, I believe, in every disposition a tendency to some particular
evil, a natural defect, which not even the best education can overcome.
subQuotationList: ['There is, I believe, in every disposition a tendency to some particular\nevil, a natural defect, which not even the best education can overcome.']
speaker: Mr. Darcy

quoteText: And _your_ defect is a propensity to hate every body.
subQuotationList: ['And _your_ defect is a propensity to hate every body.']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
And yours, is wilfully to misunderstand
them.
subQuotationList: ['And yours,', 'is wilfully to misunderstand\nthem.']
speaker: Mr. Darcy

quoteText:
Do let us have a little music, Louisa, you will not mind my
waking Mr. Hurst.
subQuotationList: ['Do let us have a little music,', 'Louisa, you will not mind my\nwaking Mr. Hurst.']
speaker: Miss Bingley
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. Darcy', 'Elizabeth', 'Mrs. Hurst', 'Mr. Bingley', 'Mr. Hurst', 'Miss Bingley']], [['Mrs. Hurst'], ['Mrs. Hurst'], ['Mr. Hurst']]]

quoteText:
I hope, my dear, that you have ordered a good dinner to-day,
because I have reason to expect an addition to our family party.
subQuotationList: ['I hope, my dear,', 'that you have ordered a good dinner to-day,\nbecause I have reason to expect an addition to our family party.']
speaker: Mr. Bennet
referringExpression: said Mr Bennet to his wife

quoteText:
Who do you mean, my dear? I know of nobody that is coming I am sure,
unless Charlotte Lucas should happen to call in, and I hope _my_ dinners
are good enough for her. I do not believe she often sees such at home.
subQuotationList: ['Who do you mean, my dear? I know of nobody that is coming I am sure,\nunless Charlotte Lucas should happen to call in, and I hope _my_ dinners\nare good enough for her. I do not believe she often sees such at home.']
speaker: Mrs. Bennet

quoteText: The person of whom I speak, is a gentleman and a stranger.
subQuotationList: ['The person of whom I speak, is a gentleman and a stranger.']
speaker: Mr. Bennet

quoteText:
A gentleman and a stranger! It is Mr. Bingley
I am sure. Why Jane--you never dropt a word of this; you sly thing!
Well, I am sure I shall be extremely glad to see Mr. Bingley.--But--good
lord! how unlucky! there is not a bit of fish to be got to-day. Lydia,
my love, ring the bell. I must speak to Hill, this moment.
subQuotationList:
['A gentleman and a stranger! It is Mr. Bingley
I am sure. Why Jane--you never dropt a word of this; you sly thing!
Well, I am sure I shall be extremely glad to see Mr. Bingley.--But--good
lord! how unlucky! there is not a bit of fish to be got to-day. Lydia,
my love, ring the bell. I must speak to Hill, this moment.']
speaker: Mrs. Bennet

quoteText:
It is _not_ Mr. Bingley, it is a person whom I
never saw in the whole course of my life.
subQuotationList: ['It is _not_ Mr. Bingley,', 'it is a person whom I\nnever saw in the whole course of my life.']
speaker: Mr. Bennet

quoteText:
About a month ago I received this letter, and about a fortnight ago I
answered it, for I thought it a case of some delicacy, and requiring
early attention. It is from my cousin, Mr. Collins, who, when I am dead,
may turn you all out of this house as soon as he pleases.
subQuotationList:
['About a month ago I received this letter, and about a fortnight ago I
answered it, for I thought it a case of some delicacy, and requiring
early attention. It is from my cousin, Mr. Collins, who, when I am dead,
may turn you all out of this house as soon as he pleases.']
speaker: Mr. Bennet

quoteText:
Oh! my dear, I cannot bear to hear that mentioned.
Pray do not talk of that odious man. I do think it is the hardest thing
in the world, that your estate should be entailed away from your own
children; and I am sure if I had been you, I should have tried long ago
to do something or other about it.
subQuotationList:
['Oh! my dear,', 'I cannot bear to hear that mentioned.
Pray do not talk of that odious man. I do think it is the hardest thing
in the world, that your estate should be entailed away from your own
children; and I am sure if I had been you, I should have tried long ago
to do something or other about it.']
speaker: Mrs. Bennet

quoteText:
It certainly is a most iniquitous affair, and
nothing can clear Mr. Collins from the guilt of inheriting Longbourn.
But if you will listen to his letter, you may perhaps be a little
softened by his manner of expressing himself.
subQuotationList:
['It certainly is a most iniquitous affair,', 'and
nothing can clear Mr. Collins from the guilt of inheriting Longbourn.
But if you will listen to his letter, you may perhaps be a little
softened by his manner of expressing himself.']
speaker: Mr. Bennet
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Mr. Collins'], ['Mrs. Bennet'], ['Mr. Collins'], ['Mrs. Bennet'], ['Mr. Collins'], ['Mr. Collins']]]

quoteText:
No, that I am sure I shall not; and I think it was very impertinent of
him to write to you at all, and very hypocritical. I hate such false
friends. Why could not he keep on quarrelling with you, as his father
did before him?
subQuotationList:
['No, that I am sure I shall not; and I think it was very impertinent of
him to write to you at all, and very hypocritical. I hate such false
friends. Why could not he keep on quarrelling with you, as his father
did before him?']
speaker: Mrs. Bennet

quoteText:
Why, indeed, he does seem to have had some filial scruples on that
head, as you will hear. There, Mrs. Bennet At four o'clock, therefore, we may expect this peace-making gentleman, He seems to be a most
conscientious and polite young man, upon my word; and I doubt not will
prove a valuable acquaintance, especially if Lady Catherine should be so
indulgent as to let him come to us again.
subQuotationList:
['Why, indeed, he does seem to have had some filial scruples on that
head, as you will hear.', 'There, Mrs. Bennet', "At four o'clock, therefore, we may expect this peace-making gentleman,", 'He seems to be a most
conscientious and polite young man, upon my word; and I doubt not will
prove a valuable acquaintance, especially if Lady Catherine should be so
indulgent as to let him come to us again.']
speaker: Mr. Bennet
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. Collins'], ['Mrs. Bennet']], [['Mrs. Bennet']], [['Mary', 'Elizabeth', 'Lydia', 'Mrs. Bennet', 'Kitty', 'Jane', 'Mr. Bennet'], ['Mr. Collins']], [['Mr. Collins'], ['Lady Catherine De Bourgh'], ['Mr. Collins'], ['Mary', 'Elizabeth', 'Lydia', 'Mrs. Bennet', 'Kitty', 'Jane', 'Mr. Bennet']]]

quoteText:
There is some sense in what he says about the girls however; and if he
is disposed to make them any amends, I shall not be the person to
discourage him.
subQuotationList: ['There is some sense in what he says about the girls however; and if he\nis disposed to make them any amends, I shall not be the person to\ndiscourage him.']
speaker: Mrs. Bennet

quoteText:
Though it is difficult, to guess in what way he can mean
to make us the atonement he thinks our due, the wish is certainly to his
credit.
subQuotationList: ['Though it is difficult,', 'to guess in what way he can mean\nto make us the atonement he thinks our due, the wish is certainly to his\ncredit.']
speaker: Jane

quoteText:
He must be an oddity, I think, I cannot make him
out.--There is something very pompous in his style.--And what can he
mean by apologizing for being next in the entail?--We cannot suppose he
would help it, if he could.--Can he be a sensible man, sir?
subQuotationList:
['He must be an oddity, I think,', 'I cannot make him
out.--There is something very pompous in his style.--And what can he
mean by apologizing for being next in the entail?--We cannot suppose he
would help it, if he could.--Can he be a sensible man, sir?']
speaker: Elizabeth
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. Collins']], [['Mr. Collins'], ['Mr. Collins'], ['Mary', 'Elizabeth', 'Lydia', 'Mrs. Bennet', 'Kitty', 'Jane', 'Mr. Bennet'], ['Mr. Collins'], ['Mr. Collins'], ['Mr. Collins'], ['Mr. Bennet']]]

quoteText:
No, my dear; I think not. I have great hopes of finding him quite the
reverse. There is a mixture of servility and self-importance in his
letter, which promises well. I am impatient to see him.
subQuotationList: ['No, my dear; I think not. I have great hopes of finding him quite the\nreverse. There is a mixture of servility and self-importance in his\nletter, which promises well. I am impatient to see him.']
speaker: Mr. Bennet

quoteText:
In point of composition, his letter does not seem
defective. The idea of the olive branch perhaps is not wholly new, yet I
think it is well expressed.
subQuotationList: ['In point of composition,', 'his letter does not seem\ndefective. The idea of the olive branch perhaps is not wholly new, yet I\nthink it is well expressed.']
speaker: Mary

quoteText:
You are very kind, sir, I am sure; and I wish with all my heart it may
prove so; for else they will be destitute enough. Things are settled so
oddly.
subQuotationList: ['You are very kind, sir, I am sure; and I wish with all my heart it may\nprove so; for else they will be destitute enough. Things are settled so\noddly.']
speaker: Mrs. Bennet
referringExpression: Mrs Bennet who quarrelled with no compliments answered

quoteText: You allude perhaps to the entail of this estate.
subQuotationList: ['You allude perhaps to the entail of this estate.']
speaker: Mr. Collins

quoteText:
Ah! sir, I do indeed. It is a grievous affair to my poor girls, you
must confess. Not that I mean to find fault with _you_, for such things
I know are all chance in this world. There is no knowing how estates
will go when once they come to be entailed.
subQuotationList:
['Ah! sir, I do indeed. It is a grievous affair to my poor girls, you
must confess. Not that I mean to find fault with _you_, for such things
I know are all chance in this world. There is no knowing how estates
will go when once they come to be entailed.']
speaker: Mrs. Bennet

quoteText:
I am very sensible, madam, of the hardship to my fair cousins,--and
could say much on the subject, but that I am cautious of appearing
forward and precipitate. But I can assure the young ladies that I come
prepared to admire them. At present I will not say more, but perhaps
when we are better acquainted----
subQuotationList:
['I am very sensible, madam, of the hardship to my fair cousins,--and
could say much on the subject, but that I am cautious of appearing
forward and precipitate. But I can assure the young ladies that I come
prepared to admire them. At present I will not say more, but perhaps
when we are better acquainted----']
speaker: Mr. Collins

quoteText:
That is all very proper and civil, I am sure, and I
dare say she is a very agreeable woman. It is a pity that great ladies
in general are not more like her. Does she live near you, sir?
subQuotationList: ['That is all very proper and civil, I am sure,', 'and I\ndare say she is a very agreeable woman. It is a pity that great ladies\nin general are not more like her. Does she live near you, sir?']
speaker: Mrs. Bennet
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Lady Catherine De Bourgh'], ['Lady Catherine De Bourgh'], ['Lady Catherine De Bourgh'], ['Mr. Collins'], ['Mr. Collins']]]

quoteText:
The garden in which stands my humble abode, is separated only by a lane
from Rosings Park, her ladyship's residence.
subQuotationList: ["The garden in which stands my humble abode, is separated only by a lane\nfrom Rosings Park, her ladyship's residence."]
speaker: Mr. Collins

quoteText: I think you said she was a widow, sir? has she any family?
subQuotationList: ['I think you said she was a widow, sir? has she any family?']
speaker: Mrs. Bennet
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. Collins'], ['Lady Catherine De Bourgh'], ['Mr. Collins'], ['Lady Catherine De Bourgh']]]

quoteText:
She has one only daughter, the heiress of Rosings, and of very
extensive property.
subQuotationList: ['She has one only daughter, the heiress of Rosings, and of very\nextensive property.']
speaker: Mr. Collins

quoteText:
Ah! then she is better off than
many girls. And what sort of young lady is she? is she handsome?
subQuotationList: ['Ah!', 'then she is better off than\nmany girls. And what sort of young lady is she? is she handsome?']
speaker: Mrs. Bennet
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Miss De Bourgh'], ['Miss De Bourgh'], ['Miss De Bourgh']]]

quoteText:
She is a most charming young lady indeed. Lady Catherine herself says
that in point of true beauty, Miss De Bourgh is far superior to the
handsomest of her sex; because there is that in her features which marks
the young woman of distinguished birth. She is unfortunately of a sickly
constitution, which has prevented her making that progress in many
accomplishments, which she could not otherwise have failed of; as I am
informed by the lady who superintended her education, and who still
resides with them. But she is perfectly amiable, and often condescends
to drive by my humble abode in her little phaeton and ponies.
subQuotationList:
['She is a most charming young lady indeed. Lady Catherine herself says
that in point of true beauty, Miss De Bourgh is far superior to the
handsomest of her sex; because there is that in her features which marks
the young woman of distinguished birth. She is unfortunately of a sickly
constitution, which has prevented her making that progress in many
accomplishments, which she could not otherwise have failed of; as I am
informed by the lady who superintended her education, and who still
resides with them. But she is perfectly amiable, and often condescends
to drive by my humble abode in her little phaeton and ponies.']
speaker: Mr. Collins
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Miss De Bourgh'], ['Lady Catherine De Bourgh'], ['Lady Catherine De Bourgh'], ['Miss De Bourgh'], ['Miss De Bourgh'], ['Miss De Bourgh'], ['Miss De Bourgh'], ['Miss De Bourgh'], ['Miss De Bourgh'], ['Miss De Bourgh'], ['Miss De Bourgh'], ['Lady Catherine De Bourgh', 'Miss De Bourgh'], ['Miss De Bourgh'], ['Miss De Bourgh']]]

quoteText:
Has she been presented? I do not remember her name among the ladies at
court.
subQuotationList: ['Has she been presented? I do not remember her name among the ladies at\ncourt.']
speaker: Mrs. Bennet

quoteText:
Her indifferent state of health unhappily prevents her being in town;
and by that means, as I told Lady Catherine myself one day, has deprived
the British court of its brightest ornament. Her ladyship seemed pleased
with the idea, and you may imagine that I am happy on every occasion to
offer those little delicate compliments which are always acceptable to
ladies. I have more than once observed to Lady Catherine, that her
charming daughter seemed born to be a duchess, and that the most
elevated rank, instead of giving her consequence, would be adorned by
her.--These are the kind of little things which please her ladyship, and
it is a sort of attention which I conceive myself peculiarly bound to
pay.
subQuotationList:
['Her indifferent state of health unhappily prevents her being in town;
and by that means, as I told Lady Catherine myself one day, has deprived
the British court of its brightest ornament. Her ladyship seemed pleased
with the idea, and you may imagine that I am happy on every occasion to
offer those little delicate compliments which are always acceptable to
ladies. I have more than once observed to Lady Catherine, that her
charming daughter seemed born to be a duchess, and that the most
elevated rank, instead of giving her consequence, would be adorned by
her.--These are the kind of little things which please her ladyship, and
it is a sort of attention which I conceive myself peculiarly bound to
pay.']
speaker: Mr. Collins
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Miss De Bourgh'], ['Miss De Bourgh'], ['Lady Catherine De Bourgh'], ['Lady Catherine De Bourgh'], ['Mrs. Bennet'], ['Lady Catherine De Bourgh'], ['Miss De Bourgh'], ['Miss De Bourgh'], ['Miss De Bourgh'], ['Lady Catherine De Bourgh']]]

quoteText:
You judge very properly, and it is happy for you
that you possess the talent of flattering with delicacy. May I ask
whether these pleasing attentions proceed from the impulse of the
moment, or are the result of previous study?
subQuotationList:
['You judge very properly,', 'and it is happy for you
that you possess the talent of flattering with delicacy. May I ask
whether these pleasing attentions proceed from the impulse of the
moment, or are the result of previous study?']
speaker: Mr. Bennet

quoteText:
They arise chiefly from what is passing at the time, and though I
sometimes amuse myself with suggesting and arranging such little elegant
compliments as may be adapted to ordinary occasions, I always wish to
give them as unstudied an air as possible.
subQuotationList:
['They arise chiefly from what is passing at the time, and though I
sometimes amuse myself with suggesting and arranging such little elegant
compliments as may be adapted to ordinary occasions, I always wish to
give them as unstudied an air as possible.']
speaker: Mr. Collins

quoteText:
Do you know, mama, that my uncle Philips talks of turning away Richard,
and if he does, Colonel Forster will hire him. My aunt told me so
herself on Saturday. I shall walk to Meryton to-morrow to hear more
about it, and to ask when Mr. Denny comes back from town.
subQuotationList:
['Do you know, mama, that my uncle Philips talks of turning away Richard,
and if he does, Colonel Forster will hire him. My aunt told me so
herself on Saturday. I shall walk to Meryton to-morrow to hear more
about it, and to ask when Mr. Denny comes back from town.']
speaker: Lydia
