and rivers, shall not be jumbled together in our imaginations; nor, when
we attempt to describe any particular scene, will we begin quarrelling
about its relative situation. Let _our_ first effusions be less
insupportable than those of the generality of travellers.']
speaker: Elizabeth
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mrs. Gardiner']], [['Mrs. Gardiner'], ['Elizabeth', 'Mrs. Gardiner'], ['Elizabeth', 'Mrs. Gardiner'], ['Elizabeth', 'Mrs. Gardiner'], ['Mr. Gardiner', 'Mrs. Gardiner', 'Elizabeth'], ['Elizabeth', 'Mrs. Gardiner'], ['Elizabeth', 'Mrs. Gardiner'], ['Mr. Gardiner', 'Mrs. Gardiner', 'Elizabeth'], ['Elizabeth', 'Mrs. Gardiner'], ['Elizabeth', 'Mrs. Gardiner']]]

quoteText:
Yes, Miss Elizabeth, you will have the honour of seeing Lady Catherine
de Bourgh on the ensuing Sunday at church, and I need not say you will
be delighted with her. She is all affability and condescension, and I
doubt not but you will be honoured with some portion of her notice when
service is over. I have scarcely any hesitation in saying that she will
include you and my sister Maria in every invitation with which she
honours us during your stay here. Her behaviour to my dear Charlotte is
charming. We dine at Rosings twice every week, and are never allowed to
walk home. Her ladyship's carriage is regularly ordered for us. I
_should_ say, one of her ladyship's carriages, for she has several.
subQuotationList:
["Yes, Miss Elizabeth, you will have the honour of seeing Lady Catherine
de Bourgh on the ensuing Sunday at church, and I need not say you will
be delighted with her. She is all affability and condescension, and I
doubt not but you will be honoured with some portion of her notice when
service is over. I have scarcely any hesitation in saying that she will
include you and my sister Maria in every invitation with which she

charming. We dine at Rosings twice every week, and are never allowed to
walk home. Her ladyship's carriage is regularly ordered for us. I
_should_ say, one of her ladyship's carriages, for she has several."]
speaker: Mr. Collins

quoteText: Lady Catherine is a very respectable, sensible woman indeed, and a most attentive neighbour.
subQuotationList: ['Lady Catherine is a very respectable, sensible woman indeed,', 'and a most attentive neighbour.']
speaker: Charlotte Lucas

quoteText:
Very true, my dear, that is exactly what I say. She is the sort of
woman whom one cannot regard with too much deference.
subQuotationList: ['Very true, my dear, that is exactly what I say. She is the sort of\nwoman whom one cannot regard with too much deference.']
speaker: Mr. Collins

quoteText:
Oh, my dear Eliza! pray make haste and come into the dining-room, for
there is such a sight to be seen! I will not tell you what it is. Make
haste, and come down this moment.
subQuotationList: ['Oh, my dear Eliza! pray make haste and come into the dining-room, for\nthere is such a sight to be seen! I will not tell you what it is. Make\nhaste, and come down this moment.']
speaker: Maria
referringExpression: Maria in the landing place who breathless with agitation cried out

quoteText:
And is this all? I expected at least that the pigs
were got into the garden, and here is nothing but Lady Catherine and her
daughter!
subQuotationList: ['And is this all?', 'I expected at least that the pigs\nwere got into the garden, and here is nothing but Lady Catherine and her\ndaughter!']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
La! my dear, it is not Lady
Catherine. The old lady is Mrs. Jenkinson, who lives with them. The
other is Miss De Bourgh. Only look at her. She is quite a little
creature. Who would have thought she could be so thin and small!
subQuotationList:
['La! my dear,', 'it is not Lady
Catherine. The old lady is Mrs. Jenkinson, who lives with them. The
other is Miss De Bourgh. Only look at her. She is quite a little

quoteText:
She is abominably rude to keep Charlotte out of doors in all this wind.
Why does she not come in?
subQuotationList: ['She is abominably rude to keep Charlotte out of doors in all this wind.\nWhy does she not come in?']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
Oh! Charlotte says, she hardly ever does. It is the greatest of favours
when Miss De Bourgh comes in.
subQuotationList: ['Oh! Charlotte says, she hardly ever does. It is the greatest of favours\nwhen Miss De Bourgh comes in.']
speaker: Maria

quoteText:
I like her appearance, She
looks sickly and cross.--Yes, she will do for him very well. She will
make him a very proper wife.
subQuotationList: ['I like her appearance,', 'She\nlooks sickly and cross.--Yes, she will do for him very well. She will\nmake him a very proper wife.']
speaker: Elizabeth
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Miss De Bourgh']], [['Miss De Bourgh'], ['Miss De Bourgh'], ['Mr. Darcy'], ['Miss De Bourgh'], ['Mr. Darcy']]]

quoteText:
I confess, that I should not have been at all surprised by
her Ladyship's asking us on Sunday to drink tea and spend the evening at
Rosings. I rather expected, from my knowledge of her affability, that it
would happen. But who could have foreseen such an attention as this? Who
could have imagined that we should receive an invitation to dine there
(an invitation moreover including the whole party) so immediately after
your arrival!
subQuotationList:
['I confess,', "that I should not have been at all surprised by
her Ladyship's asking us on Sunday to drink tea and spend the evening at
Rosings. I rather expected, from my knowledge of her affability, that it
would happen. But who could have foreseen such an attention as this? Who
could have imagined that we should receive an invitation to dine there
(an invitation moreover including the whole party) so immediately after
your arrival!"]
speaker: Mr. Collins
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Lady Catherine De Bourgh'], ['Elizabeth', 'Charlotte Lucas', 'Mr. Collins', 'Sir William Lucas', 'Maria'], ['Lady Catherine De Bourgh'], ['Elizabeth', 'Charlotte Lucas', 'Mr. Collins', 'Sir William Lucas', 'Maria'], ['Mr. Collins', 'Elizabeth', 'Charlotte Lucas', 'Sir William Lucas', 'Maria'], ['Elizabeth']]]

quoteText:
I am the less surprised at what has happened, from that knowledge of what the manners of the great really are, which
my situation in life has allowed me to acquire. About the Court, such
instances of elegant breeding are not uncommon.
subQuotationList: ['I am the less surprised at what has happened,', 'from that knowledge of what the manners of the great really are, which\nmy situation in life has allowed me to acquire. About the Court, such\ninstances of elegant breeding are not uncommon.']
speaker: Sir William Lucas

quoteText:
Do not make yourself uneasy, my dear cousin, about your apparel. Lady
Catherine is far from requiring that elegance of dress in us, which
becomes herself and daughter. I would advise you merely to put on
whatever of your clothes is superior to the rest, there is no occasion
for any thing more. Lady Catherine will not think the worse of you for
being simply dressed. She likes to have the distinction of rank
preserved.
subQuotationList:
['Do not make yourself uneasy, my dear cousin, about your apparel. Lady
Catherine is far from requiring that elegance of dress in us, which
becomes herself and daughter. I would advise you merely to put on
whatever of your clothes is superior to the rest, there is no occasion
for any thing more. Lady Catherine will not think the worse of you for
being simply dressed. She likes to have the distinction of rank
preserved.']
speaker: Mr. Collins
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Elizabeth'], ['Elizabeth'], ['Elizabeth'], ['Lady Catherine De Bourgh'], ['Elizabeth', 'Mr. Collins'], ['Lady Catherine De Bourgh'], ['Miss De Bourgh'], ['Elizabeth'], ['Elizabeth'], ['Lady Catherine De Bourgh'], ['Elizabeth'], ['Lady Catherine De Bourgh']]]

quoteText:
Your father's estate is entailed on Mr. Collins, I think. For your
sake, I am glad of it; but otherwise I see no
occasion for entailing estates from the female line.--It was not thought
necessary in Sir Lewis de Bourgh's family.--Do you play and sing, Miss
Bennet?
subQuotationList:
["Your father's estate is entailed on Mr. Collins, I think. For your
sake,", "I am glad of it; but otherwise I see no
occasion for entailing estates from the female line.--It was not thought
necessary in Sir Lewis de Bourgh's family.--Do you play and sing, Miss
Bennet?"]
speaker: Lady Catherine De Bourgh
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. Bennet'], ['Mr. Collins'], ['Charlotte Lucas']], [['Sir Lewis De Bourgh'], ['Elizabeth'], ['Elizabeth']]]

quoteText: A little.
subQuotationList: ['A little.']
speaker: Elizabeth
addressees: ['Mrs. Jenkinson', 'Lady Catherine De Bourgh', 'Charlotte Lucas', 'Miss De Bourgh', 'Maria']

quoteText:
Oh! then--some time or other we shall be happy to hear you. Our
instrument is a capital one, probably superior to----You shall try it
some day.--Do your sisters play and sing?
subQuotationList: ['Oh! then--some time or other we shall be happy to hear you. Our\ninstrument is a capital one, probably superior to----You shall try it\nsome day.--Do your sisters play and sing?']
speaker: Lady Catherine De Bourgh
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Lady Catherine De Bourgh', 'Miss De Bourgh'], ['Elizabeth'], ['Lady Catherine De Bourgh', 'Miss De Bourgh'], ['Elizabeth'], ['Mary', 'Lydia', 'Elizabeth', 'Kitty']]]

quoteText: One of them does.
subQuotationList: ['One of them does.']
speaker: Elizabeth
addressees: ['Mrs. Jenkinson', 'Lady Catherine De Bourgh', 'Charlotte Lucas', 'Miss De Bourgh', 'Maria']

quoteText:
Why did not you all learn?--You ought all to have learned. The Miss
Webbs all play, and their father has not so good an income as
your's.--Do you draw?
subQuotationList: ["Why did not you all learn?--You ought all to have learned. The Miss\nWebbs all play, and their father has not so good an income as\nyour's.--Do you draw?"]
speaker: Lady Catherine De Bourgh

quoteText: No, not at all.
subQuotationList: ['No, not at all.']
speaker: Elizabeth
addressees: ['Mrs. Jenkinson', 'Lady Catherine De Bourgh', 'Charlotte Lucas', 'Miss De Bourgh', 'Maria']

quoteText: What, none of you?
subQuotationList: ['What, none of you?']
speaker: Lady Catherine De Bourgh

quoteText: Not one.
subQuotationList: ['Not one.']
speaker: Elizabeth
addressees: ['Mrs. Jenkinson', 'Lady Catherine De Bourgh', 'Charlotte Lucas', 'Miss De Bourgh', 'Maria']

quoteText:
That is very strange. But I suppose you had no opportunity. Your mother
should have taken you to town every spring for the benefit of masters.
subQuotationList: ['That is very strange. But I suppose you had no opportunity. Your mother\nshould have taken you to town every spring for the benefit of masters.']
speaker: Lady Catherine De Bourgh

quoteText: My mother would have had no objection, but my father hates London.
subQuotationList: ['My mother would have had no objection, but my father hates London.']
speaker: Elizabeth
addressees: ['Mrs. Jenkinson', 'Lady Catherine De Bourgh', 'Charlotte Lucas', 'Miss De Bourgh', 'Maria']

quoteText: Has your governess left you?
subQuotationList: ['Has your governess left you?']
speaker: Lady Catherine De Bourgh

quoteText: We never had any governess.
subQuotationList: ['We never had any governess.']
speaker: Elizabeth
addressees: ['Mrs. Jenkinson', 'Lady Catherine De Bourgh', 'Charlotte Lucas', 'Miss De Bourgh', 'Maria']

quoteText:
No governess! How was that possible? Five daughters brought up at home
without a governess!--I never heard of such a thing. Your mother must
have been quite a slave to your education.
subQuotationList: ['No governess! How was that possible? Five daughters brought up at home\nwithout a governess!--I never heard of such a thing. Your mother must\nhave been quite a slave to your education.']
speaker: Lady Catherine De Bourgh

quoteText:
Then, who taught you? who attended to you? Without a governess you must
have been neglected.
subQuotationList: ['Then, who taught you? who attended to you? Without a governess you must\nhave been neglected.']
speaker: Lady Catherine De Bourgh

quoteText:
Compared with some families, I believe we were; but such of us as
wished to learn, never wanted the means. We were always encouraged to
read, and had all the masters that were necessary. Those who chose to be
idle, certainly might.
subQuotationList:
['Compared with some families, I believe we were; but such of us as
wished to learn, never wanted the means. We were always encouraged to
read, and had all the masters that were necessary. Those who chose to be
idle, certainly might.']
speaker: Elizabeth
addressees: ['Mrs. Jenkinson', 'Lady Catherine De Bourgh', 'Charlotte Lucas', 'Miss De Bourgh', 'Maria']

quoteText:
Aye, no doubt; but that is what a governess will prevent, and if I had
known your mother, I should have advised her most strenuously to engage
one. I always say that nothing is to be done in education without steady
and regular instruction, and nobody but a governess can give it. It is
wonderful how many families I have been the means of supplying in that
way. I am always glad to get a young person well placed out. Four nieces
of Mrs. Jenkinson are most delightfully situated through my means; and
it was but the other day, that I recommended another young person, who
was merely accidentally mentioned to me, and the family are quite
delighted with her. Mrs. Collins, did I tell you of Lady Metcalfe's
calling yesterday to thank me? She finds Miss Pope a treasure.
subQuotationList:
["Aye, no doubt; but that is what a governess will prevent, and if I had
known your mother, I should have advised her most strenuously to engage
one. I always say that nothing is to be done in education without steady
and regular instruction, and nobody but a governess can give it. It is
wonderful how many families I have been the means of supplying in that
way. I am always glad to get a young person well placed out. Four nieces
of Mrs. Jenkinson are most delightfully situated through my means; and

was merely accidentally mentioned to me, and the family are quite
delighted with her. Mrs. Collins, did I tell you of Lady Metcalfe's
calling yesterday to thank me? She finds Miss Pope a treasure."]
speaker: Lady Catherine De Bourgh

quoteText: said she
subQuotationList: ['said she']
speaker: Lady Catherine De Bourgh

quoteText:
Are any of your
younger sisters out, Miss Bennet?
subQuotationList: ['Are any of your\nyounger sisters out, Miss Bennet?']
speaker: Lady Catherine De Bourgh

quoteText: Yes, Ma'am, all.
subQuotationList: ["Yes, Ma'am, all."]
speaker: Elizabeth
addressees: ['Mrs. Jenkinson', 'Lady Catherine De Bourgh', 'Charlotte Lucas', 'Miss De Bourgh', 'Maria']

quoteText:
All!--What, all five out at once? Very odd!--And you only the
second.--The younger ones out before the elder are married!--Your
younger sisters must be very young?
subQuotationList: ['All!--What, all five out at once? Very odd!--And you only the\nsecond.--The younger ones out before the elder are married!--Your\nyounger sisters must be very young?']
speaker: Lady Catherine De Bourgh

quoteText:
Yes, my youngest is not sixteen. Perhaps _she_ is full young to be much
in company. But really, Ma'am, I think it would be very hard upon
younger sisters, that they should not have their share of society and
amusement because the elder may not have the means or inclination to
marry early.--The last born has as good a right to the pleasures of
youth, as the first. And to be kept back on _such_ a motive!--I think it
would not be very likely to promote sisterly affection or delicacy of
mind.
subQuotationList:
["Yes, my youngest is not sixteen. Perhaps _she_ is full young to be much
in company. But really, Ma'am, I think it would be very hard upon
younger sisters, that they should not have their share of society and
amusement because the elder may not have the means or inclination to
marry early.--The last born has as good a right to the pleasures of
youth, as the first. And to be kept back on _such_ a motive!--I think it
would not be very likely to promote sisterly affection or delicacy of
mind."]
speaker: Elizabeth
addressees: ['Mrs. Jenkinson', 'Lady Catherine De Bourgh', 'Charlotte Lucas', 'Miss De Bourgh', 'Maria']

quoteText:
Upon my word, you give your opinion very
decidedly for so young a person.--Pray, what is your age?
subQuotationList: ['Upon my word,', 'you give your opinion very\ndecidedly for so young a person.--Pray, what is your age?']
speaker: Lady Catherine De Bourgh

quoteText:
With three younger sisters grown up, your
Ladyship can hardly expect me to own it.
subQuotationList: ['With three younger sisters grown up,', 'your\nLadyship can hardly expect me to own it.']
speaker: Elizabeth
addressees: ['Mrs. Jenkinson', 'Lady Catherine De Bourgh', 'Charlotte Lucas', 'Miss De Bourgh', 'Maria']

quoteText:
You cannot be more than twenty, I am sure,--therefore you need not
conceal your age.
subQuotationList: ['You cannot be more than twenty, I am sure,--therefore you need not\nconceal your age.']
speaker: Lady Catherine De Bourgh

quoteText: I am not one and twenty.
subQuotationList: ['I am not one and twenty.']
speaker: Elizabeth
addressees: ['Mrs. Jenkinson', 'Lady Catherine De Bourgh', 'Charlotte Lucas', 'Miss De Bourgh', 'Maria']

quoteText:
I may thank you, Eliza, for this piece of civility. Mr. Darcy would
never have come so soon to wait upon me.
subQuotationList: ['I may thank you, Eliza, for this piece of civility. Mr. Darcy would\nnever have come so soon to wait upon me.']
speaker: Charlotte Lucas
referringExpression: Charlotte had seen them from her husbands room crossing the road and immediately running into the other told the girls what an honour they might expect adding

quoteText:
My eldest sister has been in town these three months. Have you never
happened to see her there?
subQuotationList: ['My eldest sister has been in town these three months. Have you never\nhappened to see her there?']
speaker: Elizabeth
referringExpression: She answered him in the usual way and after a moments pause added

quoteText:
What is that you are saying, Fitzwilliam? What is it you are talking
of? What are you telling Miss Bennet? Let me hear what it is.
subQuotationList: ['What is that you are saying, Fitzwilliam? What is it you are talking\nof? What are you telling Miss Bennet? Let me hear what it is.']
speaker: Lady Catherine De Bourgh
referringExpression: she did not scruple to call out

quoteText: We are speaking of music, Madam,
subQuotationList: ['We are speaking of music, Madam,']
speaker: Colonel Fitzwilliam

quoteText:
Of music! Then pray speak aloud. It is of all subjects my delight. I
must have my share in the conversation, if you are speaking of music.
There are few people in England, I suppose, who have more true enjoyment
of music than myself, or a better natural taste. If I had ever learnt, I
should have been a great proficient. And so would Anne, if her health
had allowed her to apply. I am confident that she would have performed
delightfully. How does Georgiana get on, Darcy?
subQuotationList:
['Of music! Then pray speak aloud. It is of all subjects my delight. I
must have my share in the conversation, if you are speaking of music.
There are few people in England, I suppose, who have more true enjoyment
of music than myself, or a better natural taste. If I had ever learnt, I
should have been a great proficient. And so would Anne, if her health
had allowed her to apply. I am confident that she would have performed
delightfully. How does Georgiana get on, Darcy?']
speaker: Lady Catherine De Bourgh
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Elizabeth', 'Colonel Fitzwilliam'], ['Anne De Bourgh'], ['Anne De Bourgh'], ['Anne De Bourgh'], ['Anne De Bourgh'], ['Miss Darcy'], ['Mr. Darcy']]]

quoteText:
I am very glad to hear such a good account of her, and pray tell her from me, that she cannot expect to excel,
if she does not practise a great deal.
subQuotationList: ['I am very glad to hear such a good account of her,', 'and pray tell her from me, that she cannot expect to excel,\nif she does not practise a great deal.']
speaker: Lady Catherine De Bourgh

quoteText:
I assure you, Madam, that she does not need such advice.
She practises very constantly.
subQuotationList: ['I assure you, Madam,', 'that she does not need such advice.\nShe practises very constantly.']
speaker: Mr. Darcy
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Lady Catherine De Bourgh'], ['Lady Catherine De Bourgh']], [['Miss Darcy'], ['Miss Darcy']]]

quoteText:
So much the better. It cannot be done too much; and when I next write
to her, I shall charge her not to neglect it on any account. I often
tell young ladies, that no excellence in music is to be acquired,
without constant practice. I have told Miss Bennet several times, that
she will never play really well, unless she practises more; and though
Mrs. Collins has no instrument, she is very welcome, as I have often
told her, to come to Rosings every day, and play on the piano-forte in
Mrs. Jenkinson's room. She would be in nobody's way, you know, in that
part of the house.
subQuotationList:
["So much the better. It cannot be done too much; and when I next write
to her, I shall charge her not to neglect it on any account. I often
tell young ladies, that no excellence in music is to be acquired,
without constant practice. I have told Miss Bennet several times, that
she will never play really well, unless she practises more; and though
Mrs. Collins has no instrument, she is very welcome, as I have often
told her, to come to Rosings every day, and play on the piano-forte in
Mrs. Jenkinson's room. She would be in nobody's way, you know, in that
part of the house."]
speaker: Lady Catherine De Bourgh
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Miss Darcy'], ['Miss Darcy'], ['Charlotte Lucas'], ['Charlotte Lucas'], ['Charlotte Lucas'], ['Mrs. Jenkinson'], ['Charlotte Lucas'], ['Mr. Darcy']]]

quoteText:
You mean to frighten me, Mr. Darcy, by coming in all this state to hear
me? But I will not be alarmed though your sister _does_ play so well.
There is a stubbornness about me that never can bear to be frightened at
the will of others. My courage always rises with every attempt to
intimidate me.
subQuotationList:
['You mean to frighten me, Mr. Darcy, by coming in all this state to hear
me? But I will not be alarmed though your sister _does_ play so well.
There is a stubbornness about me that never can bear to be frightened at
the will of others. My courage always rises with every attempt to
intimidate me.']
speaker: Elizabeth
referringExpression: Elizabeth saw what he was doing and at the first convenient pause turned to him with an arch smile and said

quoteText:
I shall not say that you are mistaken, because you could
not really believe me to entertain any design of alarming you; and I
have had the pleasure of your acquaintance long enough to know, that you
find great enjoyment in occasionally professing opinions which in fact
are not your own.
subQuotationList:
['I shall not say that you are mistaken,', 'because you could
not really believe me to entertain any design of alarming you; and I
have had the pleasure of your acquaintance long enough to know, that you
find great enjoyment in occasionally professing opinions which in fact
are not your own.']
speaker: Mr. Darcy

quoteText:
Your cousin will give you a very pretty notion of
me, and teach you not to believe a word I say. I am particularly unlucky
in meeting with a person so well able to expose my real character, in a
part of the world, where I had hoped to pass myself off with some degree
of credit. Indeed, Mr. Darcy, it is very ungenerous in you to mention
all that you knew to my disadvantage in Hertfordshire--and, give me
leave to say, very impolitic too--for it is provoking me to retaliate,
and such things may come out, as will shock your relations to hear.
subQuotationList:
['Your cousin will give you a very pretty notion of
me, and teach you not to believe a word I say. I am particularly unlucky
in meeting with a person so well able to expose my real character, in a
part of the world, where I had hoped to pass myself off with some degree
of credit. Indeed, Mr. Darcy, it is very ungenerous in you to mention
all that you knew to my disadvantage in Hertfordshire--and, give me
leave to say, very impolitic too--for it is provoking me to retaliate,
and such things may come out, as will shock your relations to hear.']
speaker: Elizabeth
referringExpression: Elizabeth laughed heartily at this picture of herself and said to Colonel Fitzwilliam
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. Darcy'], ['Colonel Fitzwilliam'], ['Colonel Fitzwilliam'], ['Mr. Darcy'], ['Mr. Darcy'], ['Mr. Darcy']]]

quoteText: I am not afraid of you,
subQuotationList: ['I am not afraid of you,']
speaker: Mr. Darcy

quoteText: Pray let me hear what you have to accuse him of, I should like to know how he behaves among strangers.
subQuotationList: ['Pray let me hear what you have to accuse him of,', 'I should like to know how he behaves among strangers.']
speaker: Colonel Fitzwilliam

quoteText:
You shall hear then--but prepare yourself for something very dreadful.
The first time of my ever seeing him in Hertfordshire, you must know,
was at a ball--and at this ball, what do you think he did? He danced
only four dances! I am sorry to pain you--but so it was. He danced only
four dances, though gentlemen were scarce; and, to my certain knowledge,
more than one young lady was sitting down in want of a partner. Mr.
Darcy, you cannot deny the fact.
subQuotationList:
['You shall hear then--but prepare yourself for something very dreadful.
The first time of my ever seeing him in Hertfordshire, you must know,
was at a ball--and at this ball, what do you think he did? He danced
only four dances! I am sorry to pain you--but so it was. He danced only
four dances, though gentlemen were scarce; and, to my certain knowledge,
more than one young lady was sitting down in want of a partner. Mr.
Darcy, you cannot deny the fact.']
speaker: Elizabeth
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Colonel Fitzwilliam'], ['Colonel Fitzwilliam'], ['Mr. Darcy'], ['Colonel Fitzwilliam'], ['Colonel Fitzwilliam'], ['Mr. Darcy'], ['Mr. Darcy'], ['Colonel Fitzwilliam'], ['Mr. Darcy'], ['Mr. Darcy'], ['Mr. Darcy']]]

quoteText:
I had not at that time the honour of knowing any lady in the assembly
beyond my own party.
subQuotationList: ['I had not at that time the honour of knowing any lady in the assembly\nbeyond my own party.']
speaker: Mr. Darcy

quoteText:
True; and nobody can ever be introduced in a ball room. Well, Colonel
Fitzwilliam, what do I play next? My fingers wait your orders.
subQuotationList: ['True; and nobody can ever be introduced in a ball room. Well, Colonel\nFitzwilliam, what do I play next? My fingers wait your orders.']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
Perhaps, I should have judged better, had I sought an
introduction, but I am ill qualified to recommend myself to strangers.
subQuotationList: ['Perhaps,', 'I should have judged better, had I sought an\nintroduction, but I am ill qualified to recommend myself to strangers.']
speaker: Mr. Darcy

quoteText:
Shall we ask your cousin the reason of this? Shall we ask him why a man of sense and
education, and who has lived in the world, is ill qualified to recommend
himself to strangers?
subQuotationList: ['Shall we ask your cousin the reason of this?', 'Shall we ask him why a man of sense and\neducation, and who has lived in the world, is ill qualified to recommend\nhimself to strangers?']
speaker: Elizabeth
referringExpression: said Elizabeth still addressing Colonel Fitzwilliam

quoteText:
I can answer your question, without applying to
him. It is because he will not give himself the trouble.
subQuotationList: ['I can answer your question,', 'without applying to\nhim. It is because he will not give himself the trouble.']
speaker: Colonel Fitzwilliam

quoteText:
I certainly have not the talent which some people possess, of conversing easily with those I have never seen before. I cannot
catch their tone of conversation, or appear interested in their
concerns, as I often see done.
subQuotationList: ['I certainly have not the talent which some people possess,', 'of conversing easily with those I have never seen before. I cannot\ncatch their tone of conversation, or appear interested in their\nconcerns, as I often see done.']
speaker: Mr. Darcy

quoteText:
My fingers, do not move over this instrument in the
masterly manner which I see so many women's do. They have not the same
force or rapidity, and do not produce the same expression. But then I
have always supposed it to be my own fault--because I would not take the
trouble of practising. It is not that I do not believe _my_ fingers as
capable as any other woman's of superior execution.
subQuotationList:
['My fingers,', "do not move over this instrument in the
masterly manner which I see so many women's do. They have not the same
force or rapidity, and do not produce the same expression. But then I
have always supposed it to be my own fault--because I would not take the
trouble of practising. It is not that I do not believe _my_ fingers as
capable as any other woman's of superior execution."]
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
You are perfectly right. You have employed your
time much better. No one admitted to the privilege of hearing you, can
think any thing wanting. We neither of us perform to strangers.
subQuotationList: ['You are perfectly right. You have employed your\ntime much better. No one admitted to the privilege of hearing you, can\nthink any thing wanting. We neither of us perform to strangers.']
speaker: Mr. Darcy

quoteText:
Miss Bennet would not play at all amiss, if she practised more, and
could have the advantage of a London master. She has a very good notion
of fingering, though her taste is not equal to Anne's. Anne would have
been a delightful performer, had her health allowed her to learn.
subQuotationList:
["Miss Bennet would not play at all amiss, if she practised more, and
could have the advantage of a London master. She has a very good notion
of fingering, though her taste is not equal to Anne's. Anne would have
been a delightful performer, had her health allowed her to learn."]
speaker: Lady Catherine De Bourgh
referringExpression: Lady Catherine approached and after listening for a few minutes said to Darcy
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Elizabeth'], ['Elizabeth'], ['Elizabeth'], ['Elizabeth'], ['Anne De Bourgh'], ['Anne De Bourgh'], ['Anne De Bourgh'], ['Anne De Bourgh']]]

quoteText:
How very suddenly you all quitted Netherfield last November, Mr. Darcy!
It must have been a most agreeable surprise to Mr. Bingley to see you
all after him so soon; for, if I recollect right, he went but the day
before. He and his sisters were well, I hope, when you left London.
subQuotationList:
['How very suddenly you all quitted Netherfield last November, Mr. Darcy!
It must have been a most agreeable surprise to Mr. Bingley to see you
all after him so soon; for, if I recollect right, he went but the day
before. He and his sisters were well, I hope, when you left London.']
speaker: Elizabeth
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. Darcy'], ['Mr. Bingley'], ['Mr. Bingley'], ['Mr. Bingley'], ['Mr. Bingley'], ['Mr. Darcy']]]

quoteText: Perfectly so--I thank you.
subQuotationList: ['Perfectly so--I thank you.']
speaker: Mr. Darcy

quoteText:
I think I have understood that Mr. Bingley has not much idea of ever
returning to Netherfield again?
subQuotationList: ['I think I have understood that Mr. Bingley has not much idea of ever\nreturning to Netherfield again?']
speaker: Elizabeth
referringExpression: She found that she was to receive no other answerand after a short pause added

quoteText:
I have never heard him say so; but it is probable that he may spend
very little of his time there in future. He has many friends, and he is
at a time of life when friends and engagements are continually
increasing.
subQuotationList:
['I have never heard him say so; but it is probable that he may spend
very little of his time there in future. He has many friends, and he is
at a time of life when friends and engagements are continually
increasing.']
speaker: Mr. Darcy

quoteText:
If he means to be but little at Netherfield, it would be better for the
neighbourhood that he should give up the place entirely, for then we
might possibly get a settled family there. But perhaps Mr. Bingley did
not take the house so much for the convenience of the neighbourhood as
for his own, and we must expect him to keep or quit it on the same
principle.
subQuotationList:
['If he means to be but little at Netherfield, it would be better for the
neighbourhood that he should give up the place entirely, for then we
might possibly get a settled family there. But perhaps Mr. Bingley did
not take the house so much for the convenience of the neighbourhood as
for his own, and we must expect him to keep or quit it on the same
principle.']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
I should not be surprised, if he were to give it up, as
soon as any eligible purchase offers.
subQuotationList: ['I should not be surprised,', 'if he were to give it up, as\nsoon as any eligible purchase offers.']
speaker: Mr. Darcy

quoteText:
This seems a very comfortable
house. Lady Catherine, I believe, did a great deal to it when Mr.
Collins first came to Hunsford.
subQuotationList: ['This seems a very comfortable\nhouse. Lady Catherine, I believe, did a great deal to it when Mr.\nCollins first came to Hunsford.']
speaker: Mr. Darcy
referringExpression: He took the hint and soon began

quoteText:
I believe she did--and I am sure she could not have bestowed her
kindness on a more grateful object.
subQuotationList: ['I believe she did--and I am sure she could not have bestowed her\nkindness on a more grateful object.']
speaker: Elizabeth
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Lady Catherine De Bourgh'], ['Lady Catherine De Bourgh'], ['Lady Catherine De Bourgh']]]

quoteText: Mr. Collins appears very fortunate in his choice of a wife.
subQuotationList: ['Mr. Collins appears very fortunate in his choice of a wife.']
speaker: Mr. Darcy

quoteText:
Yes, indeed; his friends may well rejoice in his having met with one of
the very few sensible women who would have accepted him, or have made
him happy if they had. My friend has an excellent understanding--though
I am not certain that I consider her marrying Mr. Collins as the wisest
thing she ever did. She seems perfectly happy, however, and in a
prudential light, it is certainly a very good match for her.
subQuotationList:
['Yes, indeed; his friends may well rejoice in his having met with one of
the very few sensible women who would have accepted him, or have made
him happy if they had. My friend has an excellent understanding--though
I am not certain that I consider her marrying Mr. Collins as the wisest
thing she ever did. She seems perfectly happy, however, and in a
prudential light, it is certainly a very good match for her.']
speaker: Elizabeth
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. Collins'], ['Mr. Collins'], ['Mr. Collins'], ['Charlotte Lucas'], ['Charlotte Lucas'], ['Mr. Collins'], ['Charlotte Lucas'], ['Charlotte Lucas'], ['Charlotte Lucas']]]

quoteText:
It must be very agreeable to her to be settled within so easy a
distance of her own family and friends.
subQuotationList: ['It must be very agreeable to her to be settled within so easy a\ndistance of her own family and friends.']
speaker: Mr. Darcy

quoteText: An easy distance do you call it? It is nearly fifty miles.
subQuotationList: ['An easy distance do you call it? It is nearly fifty miles.']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
And what is fifty miles of good road? Little more than half a day's
journey. Yes, I call it a _very_ easy distance.
subQuotationList: ["And what is fifty miles of good road? Little more than half a day's\njourney. Yes, I call it a _very_ easy distance."]
speaker: Mr. Darcy

quoteText:
I should never have considered the distance as one of the _advantages_
of the match, I should never have said Mrs. Collins
was settled _near_ her family.
subQuotationList: ['I should never have considered the distance as one of the _advantages_\nof the match,', 'I should never have said Mrs. Collins\nwas settled _near_ her family.']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
It is a proof of your own attachment to Hertfordshire. Any thing beyond
the very neighbourhood of Longbourn, I suppose, would appear far.
subQuotationList: ['It is a proof of your own attachment to Hertfordshire. Any thing beyond\nthe very neighbourhood of Longbourn, I suppose, would appear far.']
speaker: Mr. Darcy

quoteText:
I do not mean to say that a woman may not be settled too near her
family. The far and the near must be relative, and depend on many
varying circumstances. Where there is fortune to make the expence of
travelling unimportant, distance becomes no evil. But that is not the
case _here_. Mr. and Mrs. Collins have a comfortable income, but not
such a one as will allow of frequent journeys--and I am persuaded my
friend would not call herself _near_ her family under less than _half_
the present distance.
subQuotationList:
['I do not mean to say that a woman may not be settled too near her
family. The far and the near must be relative, and depend on many
varying circumstances. Where there is fortune to make the expence of
travelling unimportant, distance becomes no evil. But that is not the
case _here_. Mr. and Mrs. Collins have a comfortable income, but not
such a one as will allow of frequent journeys--and I am persuaded my
friend would not call herself _near_ her family under less than _half_
the present distance.']
speaker: Elizabeth
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Charlotte Lucas', 'Mr. Collins'], ['Charlotte Lucas'], ['Maria', 'Sir William Lucas', 'Lady Lucas']]]

quoteText:
_You_ cannot
have a right to such very strong local attachment. _You_ cannot have
been always at Longbourn.
subQuotationList: ['_You_ cannot\nhave a right to such very strong local attachment. _You_ cannot have\nbeen always at Longbourn.']
speaker: Mr. Darcy
referringExpression: Mr Darcy drew his chair a little towards her and said

quoteText: Are you pleased with Kent?
subQuotationList: ['Are you pleased with Kent?']
speaker: Mr. Darcy
referringExpression: he drew back his chair took a newspaper from the table and glancing over it said

quoteText:
What can be the meaning of this! My dear Eliza he must be in love with you, or he would never have
called on us in this familiar way.
subQuotationList: ['What can be the meaning of this!', 'My dear Eliza he must be in love with you, or he would never have\ncalled on us in this familiar way.']
speaker: Charlotte Lucas

quoteText: I did not know before that you ever walked this way.
subQuotationList: ['I did not know before that you ever walked this way.']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
I have been making the tour of the Park, as I generally
do every year, and intend to close it with a call at the Parsonage. Are
you going much farther?
subQuotationList: ['I have been making the tour of the Park,', 'as I generally\ndo every year, and intend to close it with a call at the Parsonage. Are\nyou going much farther?']
speaker: Colonel Fitzwilliam

quoteText: No, I should have turned in a moment.
subQuotationList: ['No, I should have turned in a moment.']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText: Do you certainly leave Kent on Saturday?
subQuotationList: ['Do you certainly leave Kent on Saturday?']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
Yes--if Darcy does not put it off again. But I am at his disposal. He
arranges the business just as he pleases.
subQuotationList: ['Yes--if Darcy does not put it off again. But I am at his disposal. He\narranges the business just as he pleases.']
speaker: Colonel Fitzwilliam

quoteText:
And if not able to please himself in the arrangement, he has at least
great pleasure in the power of choice. I do not know any body who seems
more to enjoy the power of doing what he likes than Mr. Darcy.
subQuotationList: ['And if not able to please himself in the arrangement, he has at least\ngreat pleasure in the power of choice. I do not know any body who seems\nmore to enjoy the power of doing what he likes than Mr. Darcy.']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
He likes to have his own way very well, But so we all do. It is only that he has better means of having it than
many others, because he is rich, and many others are poor. I speak
feelingly. A younger son, you know, must be inured to self-denial and
dependence.
subQuotationList:
['He likes to have his own way very well,', 'But so we all do. It is only that he has better means of having it than
many others, because he is rich, and many others are poor. I speak
feelingly. A younger son, you know, must be inured to self-denial and
dependence.']
speaker: Colonel Fitzwilliam

quoteText:
In my opinion, the younger son of an Earl can know very little of
either. Now, seriously, what have you ever known of self-denial and
dependence? When have you been prevented by want of money from going
wherever you chose, or procuring any thing you had a fancy for?
subQuotationList:
['In my opinion, the younger son of an Earl can know very little of
either. Now, seriously, what have you ever known of self-denial and
dependence? When have you been prevented by want of money from going
wherever you chose, or procuring any thing you had a fancy for?']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
These are home questions--and perhaps I cannot say that I have
experienced many hardships of that nature. But in matters of greater
weight, I may suffer from the want of money. Younger sons cannot marry
where they like.
subQuotationList:
['These are home questions--and perhaps I cannot say that I have
experienced many hardships of that nature. But in matters of greater
weight, I may suffer from the want of money. Younger sons cannot marry
where they like.']
speaker: Colonel Fitzwilliam

quoteText:
Unless where they like women of fortune, which I think they very often
do.
subQuotationList: ['Unless where they like women of fortune, which I think they very often\ndo.']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
Our habits of expence make us too dependant, and there are not many in
my rank of life who can afford to marry without some attention to
money.
subQuotationList: ['Our habits of expence make us too dependant, and there are not many in\nmy rank of life who can afford to marry without some attention to\nmoney.']
speaker: Colonel Fitzwilliam

quoteText: "Is this," "meant for me?"
subQuotationList: ['"Is this,"', '"meant for me?"']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
And pray, what is
the usual price of an Earl's younger son? Unless the elder brother is
very sickly, I suppose you would not ask above fifty thousand pounds.
subQuotationList: ["And pray, what is\nthe usual price of an Earl's younger son? Unless the elder brother is\nvery sickly, I suppose you would not ask above fifty thousand pounds."]
speaker: Elizabeth
referringExpression: she coloured at the idea but recovering herself said

quoteText:
I imagine your cousin brought you down with him chiefly for the sake of
having somebody at his disposal. I wonder he does not marry, to secure a
lasting convenience of that kind. But, perhaps his sister does as well
for the present, and, as she is under his sole care, he may do what he
likes with her.
subQuotationList:
['I imagine your cousin brought you down with him chiefly for the sake of
having somebody at his disposal. I wonder he does not marry, to secure a
lasting convenience of that kind. But, perhaps his sister does as well
for the present, and, as she is under his sole care, he may do what he
likes with her.']
speaker: Elizabeth
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. Darcy'], ['Colonel Fitzwilliam'], ['Mr. Darcy'], ['Mr. Darcy'], ['Mr. Darcy'], ['Miss Darcy'], ['Miss Darcy'], ['Mr. Darcy'], ['Mr. Darcy'], ['Darcy'], ['Miss Darcy']]]

quoteText:
No, that is an advantage which he must
divide with me. I am joined with him in the guardianship of Miss Darcy.
subQuotationList: ['No,', 'that is an advantage which he must\ndivide with me. I am joined with him in the guardianship of Miss Darcy.']
speaker: Colonel Fitzwilliam

quoteText:
Are you, indeed? And pray what sort of guardians do you make? Does your
charge give you much trouble? Young ladies of her age, are sometimes a
little difficult to manage, and if she has the true Darcy spirit, she
may like to have her own way.
subQuotationList:
['Are you, indeed? And pray what sort of guardians do you make? Does your
charge give you much trouble? Young ladies of her age, are sometimes a
little difficult to manage, and if she has the true Darcy spirit, she
may like to have her own way.']
speaker: Elizabeth
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Colonel Fitzwilliam'], ['Colonel Fitzwilliam'], ['Colonel Fitzwilliam'], ['Miss Darcy'], ['Miss Darcy'], ['Miss Darcy'], ['Miss Darcy']]]

quoteText:
You need not be frightened. I never heard any harm of her; and I dare
say she is one of the most tractable creatures in the world. She is a
very great favourite with some ladies of my acquaintance, Mrs. Hurst and
Miss Bingley. I think I have heard you say that you know them.
subQuotationList:
['You need not be frightened. I never heard any harm of her; and I dare
say she is one of the most tractable creatures in the world. She is a
very great favourite with some ladies of my acquaintance, Mrs. Hurst and
Miss Bingley. I think I have heard you say that you know them.']
speaker: Elizabeth
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Miss Darcy'], ['Miss Darcy'], ['Miss Darcy'], ['Mrs. Hurst'], ['Miss Bingley'], ['Miss Bingley', 'Mrs. Hurst']]]

quoteText:
I know them a little. Their brother is a pleasant gentleman-like
man--he is a great friend of Darcy's.
subQuotationList: ["I know them a little. Their brother is a pleasant gentleman-like\nman--he is a great friend of Darcy's."]
speaker: Colonel Fitzwilliam

quoteText:
Oh! yes, Mr. Darcy is uncommonly kind to Mr.
Bingley, and takes a prodigious deal of care of him.
subQuotationList: ['Oh! yes,', 'Mr. Darcy is uncommonly kind to Mr.\nBingley, and takes a prodigious deal of care of him.']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
Care of him!--Yes, I really believe Darcy _does_ take care of him in
those points where he most wants care. From something that he told me in
our journey hither, I have reason to think Bingley very much indebted to
him. But I ought to beg his pardon, for I have no right to suppose that
Bingley was the person meant. It was all conjecture.
subQuotationList:
['Care of him!--Yes, I really believe Darcy _does_ take care of him in
those points where he most wants care. From something that he told me in
our journey hither, I have reason to think Bingley very much indebted to
him. But I ought to beg his pardon, for I have no right to suppose that
Bingley was the person meant. It was all conjecture.']
speaker: Colonel Fitzwilliam
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. Bingley'], ['Mr. Darcy'], ['Mr. Bingley'], ['Mr. Bingley'], ['Mr. Darcy'], ['Mr. Bingley'], ['Darcy'], ['Mr. Bingley']]]

quoteText: What is it you mean?
subQuotationList: ['What is it you mean?']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
It is a circumstance which Darcy of course would not wish to be
generally known, because if it were to get round to the lady's family,
it would be an unpleasant thing.
subQuotationList: ["It is a circumstance which Darcy of course would not wish to be\ngenerally known, because if it were to get round to the lady's family,\nit would be an unpleasant thing."]
speaker: Colonel Fitzwilliam

quoteText: You may depend upon my not mentioning it.
subQuotationList: ['You may depend upon my not mentioning it.']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
And remember that I have not much reason for supposing it to be
Bingley. What he told me was merely this; that he congratulated himself
on having lately saved a friend from the inconveniences of a most
imprudent marriage, but without mentioning names or any other
particulars, and I only suspected it to be Bingley from believing him
the kind of young man to get into a scrape of that sort, and from
knowing them to have been together the whole of last summer.
subQuotationList:
['And remember that I have not much reason for supposing it to be
Bingley. What he told me was merely this; that he congratulated himself
on having lately saved a friend from the inconveniences of a most
imprudent marriage, but without mentioning names or any other
particulars, and I only suspected it to be Bingley from believing him
the kind of young man to get into a scrape of that sort, and from
knowing them to have been together the whole of last summer.']
speaker: Colonel Fitzwilliam
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. Bingley'], ['Mr. Darcy'], ['Mr. Darcy'], ['Mr. Bingley'], ['Mr. Bingley'], ['Mr. Darcy', 'Mr. Bingley']]]

quoteText: Did Mr. Darcy give you his reasons for this interference?
subQuotationList: ['Did Mr. Darcy give you his reasons for this interference?']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
I understood that there were some very strong objections against the
lady.
subQuotationList: ['I understood that there were some very strong objections against the\nlady.']
speaker: Colonel Fitzwilliam

quoteText: And what arts did he use to separate them?
subQuotationList: ['And what arts did he use to separate them?']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
He did not talk to me of his own arts, He
only told me, what I have now told you.
subQuotationList: ['He did not talk to me of his own arts,', 'He\nonly told me, what I have now told you.']
speaker: Colonel Fitzwilliam

quoteText:
I am thinking of what you have been telling me, Your
cousin's conduct does not suit my feelings. Why was he to be the judge?
subQuotationList: ['I am thinking of what you have been telling me,', "Your\ncousin's conduct does not suit my feelings. Why was he to be the judge?"]
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText: You are rather disposed to call his interference officious?
subQuotationList: ['You are rather disposed to call his interference officious?']
speaker: Colonel Fitzwilliam

quoteText:
I do not see what right Mr. Darcy had to decide on the propriety of
his friend's inclination, or why, upon his own judgment alone, he was to
determine and direct in what manner that friend was to be happy. But, as we know none of the
particulars, it is not fair to condemn him. It is not to be supposed
that there was much affection in the case.
subQuotationList:
["I do not see what right Mr. Darcy had to decide on the propriety of
his friend's inclination, or why, upon his own judgment alone, he was to
determine and direct in what manner that friend was to be happy.", 'But,', 'as we know none of the
particulars, it is not fair to condemn him. It is not to be supposed
that there was much affection in the case.']
speaker: Elizabeth
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. Darcy'], ['Mr. Bingley'], ['Mr. Darcy'], ['Mr. Darcy'], ['Mr. Bingley']], [], [['Elizabeth', 'Colonel Fitzwilliam'], ['Mr. Darcy']]]

quoteText:
That is not an unnatural surmise, but it is
lessening the honour of my cousin's triumph very sadly.
subQuotationList: ['That is not an unnatural surmise,', "but it is\nlessening the honour of my cousin's triumph very sadly."]
speaker: Colonel Fitzwilliam

quoteText: There were some very strong objections against the lady,
subQuotationList: ['There were some very strong objections against the lady,']
speaker: Colonel Fitzwilliam

quoteText:
To Jane herself, "there could be no possibility of
objection. All loveliness and goodness as she is! Her understanding
excellent, her mind improved, and her manners captivating. Neither could
any thing be urged against my father, who, though with some
peculiarities, has abilities which Mr. Darcy himself need not disdain,
and respectability which he will probably never reach."
subQuotationList:
['To Jane herself,', '"there could be no possibility of
objection. All loveliness and goodness as she is! Her understanding
excellent, her mind improved, and her manners captivating. Neither could
any thing be urged against my father, who, though with some
peculiarities, has abilities which Mr. Darcy himself need not disdain,
and respectability which he will probably never reach."']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
In vain have I struggled. It will not do. My feelings will not be
repressed. You must allow me to tell you how ardently I admire and love
you.
subQuotationList: ['In vain have I struggled. It will not do. My feelings will not be\nrepressed. You must allow me to tell you how ardently I admire and love\nyou.']
speaker: Mr. Darcy
referringExpression: he came towards her in an agitated manner and thus began

quoteText:
In such cases as this, it is, I believe, the established mode to
express a sense of obligation for the sentiments avowed, however
unequally they may be returned. It is natural that obligation should be
felt, and if I could _feel_ gratitude, I would now thank you. But I
cannot--I have never desired your good opinion, and you have certainly
bestowed it most unwillingly. I am sorry to have occasioned pain to any
one. It has been most unconsciously done, however, and I hope will be of
short duration. The feelings which, you tell me, have long prevented the
acknowledgment of your regard, can have little difficulty in overcoming
it after this explanation.
subQuotationList:
['In such cases as this, it is, I believe, the established mode to
express a sense of obligation for the sentiments avowed, however
unequally they may be returned. It is natural that obligation should be
felt, and if I could _feel_ gratitude, I would now thank you. But I
cannot--I have never desired your good opinion, and you have certainly
bestowed it most unwillingly. I am sorry to have occasioned pain to any
one. It has been most unconsciously done, however, and I hope will be of
short duration. The feelings which, you tell me, have long prevented the
acknowledgment of your regard, can have little difficulty in overcoming
it after this explanation.']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
And this is all the reply which I am to have the honour of expecting! I
might, perhaps, wish to be informed why, with so little _endeavour_ at
civility, I am thus rejected. But it is of small importance.
subQuotationList: ['And this is all the reply which I am to have the honour of expecting! I\nmight, perhaps, wish to be informed why, with so little _endeavour_ at\ncivility, I am thus rejected. But it is of small importance.']
speaker: Mr. Darcy

quoteText:
I might as well enquire, why with so evident a design of
offending and insulting me, you chose to tell me that you liked me
against your will, against your reason, and even against your character?
Was not this some excuse for incivility, if I _was_ uncivil? But I have
other provocations. You know I have. Had not my own feelings decided
against you, had they been indifferent, or had they even been
favourable, do you think that any consideration would tempt me to accept
the man, who has been the means of ruining, perhaps for ever, the
happiness of a most beloved sister?
subQuotationList:
['I might as well enquire,', 'why with so evident a design of
offending and insulting me, you chose to tell me that you liked me
against your will, against your reason, and even against your character?
Was not this some excuse for incivility, if I _was_ uncivil? But I have
other provocations. You know I have. Had not my own feelings decided
against you, had they been indifferent, or had they even been
favourable, do you think that any consideration would tempt me to accept
the man, who has been the means of ruining, perhaps for ever, the
happiness of a most beloved sister?']
speaker: Elizabeth
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Mr. Darcy'], ['Mr. Darcy'], ['Mr. Darcy'], ['Mr. Darcy'], ['Mr. Darcy'], ['Mr. Darcy'], ['Mr. Darcy'], ['Mr. Darcy'], ['Darcy'], ['Jane']]]

quoteText:
I have every reason in the world to think ill of you. No motive can
excuse the unjust and ungenerous part you acted _there_. You dare not,
you cannot deny that you have been the principal, if not the only means
of dividing them from each other, of exposing one to the censure of the
world for caprice and instability, the other to its derision for
disappointed hopes, and involving them both in misery of the acutest
kind.
subQuotationList:
['I have every reason in the world to think ill of you. No motive can
excuse the unjust and ungenerous part you acted _there_. You dare not,
you cannot deny that you have been the principal, if not the only means
of dividing them from each other, of exposing one to the censure of the
world for caprice and instability, the other to its derision for
disappointed hopes, and involving them both in misery of the acutest
kind.']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText: Can you deny that you have done it?
subQuotationList: ['Can you deny that you have done it?']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
I have no wish of denying
that I did every thing in my power to separate my friend from your
sister, or that I rejoice in my success. Towards _him_ I have been
kinder than towards myself.
subQuotationList:
['I have no wish of denying
that I did every thing in my power to separate my friend from your
sister, or that I rejoice in my success. Towards _him_ I have been
kinder than towards myself.']
speaker: Mr. Darcy

quoteText:
But it is not merely this affair, on which my dislike
is founded. Long before it had taken place, my opinion of you was
decided. Your character was unfolded in the recital which I received
many months ago from Mr. Wickham. On this subject, what can you have to
say? In what imaginary act of friendship can you here defend yourself?
or under what misrepresentation, can you here impose upon others?
subQuotationList:
['But it is not merely this affair,', 'on which my dislike
is founded. Long before it had taken place, my opinion of you was
decided. Your character was unfolded in the recital which I received
many months ago from Mr. Wickham. On this subject, what can you have to
say? In what imaginary act of friendship can you here defend yourself?
or under what misrepresentation, can you here impose upon others?']
speaker: Elizabeth
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Mr. Darcy'], ['Mr. Darcy'], ['George Wickham'], ['Mr. Darcy'], ['Mr. Darcy'], ['Mr. Darcy']]]

quoteText: You take an eager interest in that gentleman's concerns,
subQuotationList: ["You take an eager interest in that gentleman's concerns,"]
speaker: Mr. Darcy

quoteText:
Who that knows what his misfortunes have been, can help feeling an
interest in him?
subQuotationList: ['Who that knows what his misfortunes have been, can help feeling an\ninterest in him?']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
His misfortunes! yes, his misfortunes
have been great indeed.
subQuotationList: ['His misfortunes!', 'yes, his misfortunes\nhave been great indeed.']
speaker: Mr. Darcy

quoteText:
And of your infliction, You have reduced
him to his present state of poverty, comparative poverty. You have
withheld the advantages, which you must know to have been designed for
him. You have deprived the best years of his life, of that independence
which was no less his due than his desert. You have done all this! and
yet you can treat the mention of his misfortunes with contempt and
ridicule.
subQuotationList:
['And of your infliction,', 'You have reduced
him to his present state of poverty, comparative poverty. You have
withheld the advantages, which you must know to have been designed for
him. You have deprived the best years of his life, of that independence
which was no less his due than his desert. You have done all this! and
yet you can treat the mention of his misfortunes with contempt and
ridicule.']
speaker: Elizabeth
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Mr. Darcy'], ['George Wickham'], ['George Wickham'], ['Mr. Darcy'], ['Mr. Darcy'], ['Mr. Darcy'], ['George Wickham'], ['George Wickham'], ['George Wickham'], ['Mr. Darcy'], ['Mr. Darcy'], ['George Wickham']]]

quoteText:
And this, is your opinion of me! This is the estimation in which you hold me! I
thank you for explaining it so fully. My faults, according to this
calculation, are heavy indeed! But perhaps, these offences might have been
overlooked, had not your pride been hurt by my honest confession of the
scruples that had long prevented my forming any serious design. These
bitter accusations might have been suppressed, had I with greater policy
concealed my struggles, and flattered you into the belief of my being
impelled by unqualified, unalloyed inclination; by reason, by
reflection, by every thing. But disguise of every sort is my abhorrence.
Nor am I ashamed of the feelings I related. They were natural and just.
Could you expect me to rejoice in the inferiority of your connections?
To congratulate myself on the hope of relations, whose condition in life
is so decidedly beneath my own?
subQuotationList:
['And this,', 'is your opinion of me! This is the estimation in which you hold me! I
thank you for explaining it so fully. My faults, according to this
calculation, are heavy indeed! But perhaps,', 'these offences might have been
overlooked, had not your pride been hurt by my honest confession of the
scruples that had long prevented my forming any serious design. These
bitter accusations might have been suppressed, had I with greater policy
concealed my struggles, and flattered you into the belief of my being
impelled by unqualified, unalloyed inclination; by reason, by
reflection, by every thing. But disguise of every sort is my abhorrence.
Nor am I ashamed of the feelings I related. They were natural and just.
Could you expect me to rejoice in the inferiority of your connections?
To congratulate myself on the hope of relations, whose condition in life
is so decidedly beneath my own?']
speaker: Mr. Darcy

quoteText:
You are mistaken, Mr. Darcy, if you suppose that the mode of your
declaration affected me in any other way, than as it spared me the
concern which I might have felt in refusing you, had you behaved in a
more gentleman-like manner.
subQuotationList:
['You are mistaken, Mr. Darcy, if you suppose that the mode of your
declaration affected me in any other way, than as it spared me the
concern which I might have felt in refusing you, had you behaved in a
more gentleman-like manner.']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
You could not have made me the offer of your hand in any possible way
that would have tempted me to accept it.
subQuotationList: ['You could not have made me the offer of your hand in any possible way\nthat would have tempted me to accept it.']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
From the very beginning, from the first moment I may almost say, of my
acquaintance with you, your manners impressing me with the fullest
belief of your arrogance, your conceit, and your selfish disdain of the
feelings of others, were such as to form that ground-work of
disapprobation, on which succeeding events have built so immoveable a
dislike; and I had not known you a month before I felt that you were the
last man in the world whom I could ever be prevailed on to marry.
subQuotationList:
['From the very beginning, from the first moment I may almost say, of my
acquaintance with you, your manners impressing me with the fullest
belief of your arrogance, your conceit, and your selfish disdain of the
feelings of others, were such as to form that ground-work of
disapprobation, on which succeeding events have built so immoveable a
dislike; and I had not known you a month before I felt that you were the
last man in the world whom I could ever be prevailed on to marry.']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
You have said quite enough, madam. I perfectly comprehend your
feelings, and have now only to be ashamed of what my own have been.
Forgive me for having taken up so much of your time, and accept my best
wishes for your health and happiness.
subQuotationList:
['You have said quite enough, madam. I perfectly comprehend your
feelings, and have now only to be ashamed of what my own have been.
Forgive me for having taken up so much of your time, and accept my best
wishes for your health and happiness.']
speaker: Mr. Darcy

quoteText:
I
have been walking in the grove some time in the hope of meeting you.
Will you do me the honour of reading that letter?
subQuotationList: ['I\nhave been walking in the grove some time in the hope of meeting you.\nWill you do me the honour of reading that letter?']
speaker: Mr. Darcy
referringExpression: He had by that time reached it also and holding out a letter which she instinctively took said

quoteText:
This must be false!
This cannot be! This must be the grossest falsehood!
subQuotationList: ['This must be false!\nThis cannot be! This must be the grossest falsehood!']
speaker: Elizabeth
referringExpression: She wished to discredit it entirely repeatedly exclaiming

quoteText:
How despicably have I acted! I, who have prided myself on
my discernment!--I, who have valued myself on my abilities! who have
often disdained the generous candour of my sister, and gratified my
vanity, in useless or blameable distrust.--How humiliating is this
discovery!--Yet, how just a humiliation!--Had I been in love, I could
not have been more wretchedly blind. But vanity, not love, has been my
folly.--Pleased with the preference of one, and offended by the neglect
of the other, on the very beginning of our acquaintance, I have courted
prepossession and ignorance, and driven reason away, where either were
concerned. Till this moment, I never knew myself.
subQuotationList:
['How despicably have I acted!', 'I, who have prided myself on
my discernment!--I, who have valued myself on my abilities! who have
often disdained the generous candour of my sister, and gratified my
vanity, in useless or blameable distrust.--How humiliating is this
discovery!--Yet, how just a humiliation!--Had I been in love, I could
not have been more wretchedly blind. But vanity, not love, has been my
folly.--Pleased with the preference of one, and offended by the neglect
of the other, on the very beginning of our acquaintance, I have courted
prepossession and ignorance, and driven reason away, where either were
concerned. Till this moment, I never knew myself.']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
I assure
you, I feel it exceedingly, I believe nobody
feels the loss of friends so much as I do. But I am particularly
attached to these young men; and know them to be so much attached to
me!--They were excessively sorry to go! But so they always are. The dear
colonel rallied his spirits tolerably till just at last; but Darcy
seemed to feel it most acutely, more I think than last year. His
attachment to Rosings, certainly increases.
subQuotationList:
['I assure
you, I feel it exceedingly,', 'I believe nobody
feels the loss of friends so much as I do. But I am particularly
attached to these young men; and know them to be so much attached to
me!--They were excessively sorry to go! But so they always are. The dear
colonel rallied his spirits tolerably till just at last; but Darcy
seemed to feel it most acutely, more I think than last year. His
attachment to Rosings, certainly increases.']
speaker: Lady Catherine De Bourgh
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. Collins', 'Charlotte Lucas', 'Elizabeth']], [['Mr. Darcy', 'Colonel Fitzwilliam'], ['Mr. Darcy', 'Colonel Fitzwilliam'], ['Mr. Darcy', 'Colonel Fitzwilliam'], ['Mr. Darcy', 'Colonel Fitzwilliam'], ['Colonel Fitzwilliam'], ['Colonel Fitzwilliam'], ['Mr. Darcy'], ['Mr. Darcy']]]

quoteText:
But if that is the case, you must write to your mother to beg that you
may stay a little longer. Mrs. Collins will be very glad of your
company, I am sure.
subQuotationList: ['But if that is the case, you must write to your mother to beg that you\nmay stay a little longer. Mrs. Collins will be very glad of your\ncompany, I am sure.']
speaker: Lady Catherine De Bourgh

quoteText:
I am much obliged to your ladyship for your kind invitation, but it is not in my power to accept it.--I must be in town
next Saturday.
subQuotationList: ['I am much obliged to your ladyship for your kind invitation,', 'but it is not in my power to accept it.--I must be in town\nnext Saturday.']
speaker: Elizabeth
addressees: ['Anne De Bourgh', 'Lady Catherine De Bourgh', 'Charlotte Lucas', 'Mr. Collins']
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Lady Catherine De Bourgh'], ['Lady Catherine De Bourgh']], []]

quoteText:
Why, at that rate, you will have been here only six weeks. I expected
you to stay two months. I told Mrs. Collins so before you came. There
can be no occasion for your going so soon. Mrs. Bennet could certainly
spare you for another fortnight.
subQuotationList:
['Why, at that rate, you will have been here only six weeks. I expected
you to stay two months. I told Mrs. Collins so before you came. There
can be no occasion for your going so soon. Mrs. Bennet could certainly
spare you for another fortnight.']
speaker: Lady Catherine De Bourgh

quoteText: But my father cannot.--He wrote last week to hurry my return.
subQuotationList: ['But my father cannot.--He wrote last week to hurry my return.']
speaker: Elizabeth
addressees: ['Anne De Bourgh', 'Lady Catherine De Bourgh', 'Charlotte Lucas', 'Mr. Collins']

quoteText:
Oh! your father of course may spare you, if your mother can.--Daughters
are never of so much consequence to a father. And if you will stay
another _month_ complete, it will be in my power to take one of you as
far as London, for I am going there early in June, for a week; and as
Dawson does not object to the Barouche box, there will be very good room
for one of you--and indeed, if the weather should happen to be cool, I
should not object to taking you both, as you are neither of you large.
subQuotationList:
['Oh! your father of course may spare you, if your mother can.--Daughters
are never of so much consequence to a father. And if you will stay
another _month_ complete, it will be in my power to take one of you as
far as London, for I am going there early in June, for a week; and as
Dawson does not object to the Barouche box, there will be very good room
for one of you--and indeed, if the weather should happen to be cool, I
should not object to taking you both, as you are neither of you large.']
speaker: Lady Catherine De Bourgh

quoteText:
You are all kindness, Madam; but I believe we must abide by our
original plan.
subQuotationList: ['You are all kindness, Madam; but I believe we must abide by our\noriginal plan.']
speaker: Elizabeth
addressees: ['Anne De Bourgh', 'Lady Catherine De Bourgh', 'Charlotte Lucas', 'Mr. Collins']
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Lady Catherine De Bourgh'], ['Lady Catherine De Bourgh'], ['Elizabeth'], ['Elizabeth', 'Maria']]]

quoteText:
Mrs. Collins, you must send a servant with them. You know I always
speak my mind, and I cannot bear the idea of two young women travelling
post by themselves. It is highly improper. You must contrive to send
somebody. I have the greatest dislike in the world to that sort of
thing.--Young women should always be properly guarded and attended,
according to their situation in life. When my niece Georgiana went to
Ramsgate last summer, I made a point of her having two men servants go
with her.--Miss Darcy, the daughter of Mr. Darcy, of Pemberley, and Lady
Anne, could not have appeared with propriety in a different manner.--I
am excessively attentive to all those things. You must send John with
the young ladies, Mrs. Collins. I am glad it occurred to me to mention
it; for it would really be discreditable to _you_ to let them go alone.
subQuotationList:
['Mrs. Collins, you must send a servant with them. You know I always
speak my mind, and I cannot bear the idea of two young women travelling
post by themselves. It is highly improper. You must contrive to send
somebody. I have the greatest dislike in the world to that sort of
thing.--Young women should always be properly guarded and attended,
according to their situation in life. When my niece Georgiana went to

with her.--Miss Darcy, the daughter of Mr. Darcy, of Pemberley, and Lady
Anne, could not have appeared with propriety in a different manner.--I
am excessively attentive to all those things. You must send John with
the young ladies, Mrs. Collins. I am glad it occurred to me to mention
it; for it would really be discreditable to _you_ to let them go alone.']
speaker: Lady Catherine De Bourgh
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Charlotte Lucas'], ['Charlotte Lucas'], ['Elizabeth', 'Maria'], ['Charlotte Lucas'], ['Charlotte Lucas'], ['Miss Darcy'], ['Miss Darcy'], ['Miss Darcy'], ['Miss Darcy'], ['Miss Darcy'], ['Charlotte Lucas'], ['John'], ['Charlotte Lucas'], ['Charlotte Lucas'], ['Elizabeth', 'Maria']]]

quoteText: My uncle is to send a servant for us.
subQuotationList: ['My uncle is to send a servant for us.']
speaker: Elizabeth
addressees: ['Anne De Bourgh', 'Lady Catherine De Bourgh', 'Charlotte Lucas', 'Mr. Collins']

quoteText:
Oh!--Your uncle!--He keeps a man-servant, does he?--I am very glad you
have somebody who thinks of those things. Where shall you change
horses?--Oh! Bromley, of course.--If you mention my name at the Bell,
you will be attended to.
subQuotationList:
['Oh!--Your uncle!--He keeps a man-servant, does he?--I am very glad you
have somebody who thinks of those things. Where shall you change
horses?--Oh! Bromley, of course.--If you mention my name at the Bell,
you will be attended to.']
speaker: Lady Catherine De Bourgh

quoteText:
I know not, Miss Elizabeth, whether Mrs. Collins has yet
expressed her sense of your kindness in coming to us, but I am very
certain you will not leave the house without receiving her thanks for
it. The favour of your company has been much felt, I assure you. We know
how little there is to tempt any one to our humble abode. Our plain
manner of living, our small rooms, and few domestics, and the little we
see of the world, must make Hunsford extremely dull to a young lady like
yourself; but I hope you will believe us grateful for the condescension,
and that we have done every thing in our power to prevent your spending
your time unpleasantly.
subQuotationList:
['I know not, Miss Elizabeth,', 'whether Mrs. Collins has yet
expressed her sense of your kindness in coming to us, but I am very
certain you will not leave the house without receiving her thanks for
it. The favour of your company has been much felt, I assure you. We know
how little there is to tempt any one to our humble abode. Our plain
manner of living, our small rooms, and few domestics, and the little we
see of the world, must make Hunsford extremely dull to a young lady like
yourself; but I hope you will believe us grateful for the condescension,
and that we have done every thing in our power to prevent your spending
your time unpleasantly.']
speaker: Mr. Collins
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Elizabeth']], [['Charlotte Lucas'], ['Charlotte Lucas'], ['Charlotte Lucas', 'Mr. Collins'], ['Elizabeth'], ['Charlotte Lucas'], ['Elizabeth'], ['Elizabeth'], ['Charlotte Lucas', 'Mr. Collins'], ['Charlotte Lucas', 'Mr. Collins'], ['Charlotte Lucas', 'Mr. Collins'], ['Charlotte Lucas', 'Mr. Collins'], ['Charlotte Lucas', 'Mr. Collins'], ['Elizabeth'], ['Charlotte Lucas', 'Mr. Collins'], ['Charlotte Lucas', 'Mr. Collins'], ['Charlotte Lucas', 'Mr. Collins'], ['Elizabeth'], ['Elizabeth']]]

quoteText:
It gives me the greatest pleasure to hear that you have passed your
time not disagreeably. We have certainly done our best; and most
fortunately having it in our power to introduce you to very superior
society, and from our connection with Rosings, the frequent means of
varying the humble home scene, I think we may flatter ourselves that
your Hunsford visit cannot have been entirely irksome. Our situation
with regard to Lady Catherine's family is indeed the sort of
extraordinary advantage and blessing which few can boast. You see on
what a footing we are. You see how continually we are engaged there. In
truth I must acknowledge that, with all the disadvantages of this humble
parsonage, I should not think any one abiding in it an object of
compassion, while they are sharers of our intimacy at Rosings.
subQuotationList:
["It gives me the greatest pleasure to hear that you have passed your
time not disagreeably. We have certainly done our best; and most
fortunately having it in our power to introduce you to very superior
society, and from our connection with Rosings, the frequent means of
varying the humble home scene, I think we may flatter ourselves that
your Hunsford visit cannot have been entirely irksome. Our situation
with regard to Lady Catherine's family is indeed the sort of
extraordinary advantage and blessing which few can boast. You see on
what a footing we are. You see how continually we are engaged there. In
truth I must acknowledge that, with all the disadvantages of this humble
parsonage, I should not think any one abiding in it an object of
compassion, while they are sharers of our intimacy at Rosings."]
speaker: Mr. Collins
referringExpression: Mr Collins was gratified and with a more smiling solemnity replied
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Elizabeth'], ['Elizabeth'], ['Charlotte Lucas', 'Mr. Collins'], ['Mr. Collins', 'Charlotte Lucas'], ['Mr. Collins', 'Charlotte Lucas'], ['Elizabeth'], ['Mr. Collins', 'Charlotte Lucas'], ['Charlotte Lucas', 'Mr. Collins'], ['Elizabeth'], ['Mr. Collins', 'Charlotte Lucas'], ['Lady Catherine De Bourgh'], ['Elizabeth'], ['Charlotte Lucas', 'Mr. Collins'], ['Elizabeth'], ['Charlotte Lucas', 'Mr. Collins']]]

quoteText:
You may, in fact, carry a very favourable report of us into
Hertfordshire, my dear cousin. I flatter myself at least that you will
be able to do so. Lady Catherine's great attentions to Mrs. Collins you
have been a daily witness of; and altogether I trust it does not appear
that your friend has drawn an unfortunate--but on this point it will be
as well to be silent. Only let me assure you, my dear Miss Elizabeth,
that I can from my heart most cordially wish you equal felicity in
marriage. My dear Charlotte and I have but one mind and one way of
thinking. There is in every thing a most remarkable resemblance of
character and ideas between us. We seem to have been designed for each
other.
subQuotationList:
["You may, in fact, carry a very favourable report of us into
Hertfordshire, my dear cousin. I flatter myself at least that you will
be able to do so. Lady Catherine's great attentions to Mrs. Collins you
have been a daily witness of; and altogether I trust it does not appear
that your friend has drawn an unfortunate--but on this point it will be
as well to be silent. Only let me assure you, my dear Miss Elizabeth,
