quoteText:
but we expect him to-morrow, with a
large party of friends.
subQuotationList: ['but we expect him to-morrow, with a\nlarge party of friends.']
speaker: Mrs. Reynolds
referringExpression: Mrs Reynolds replied that he was adding

quoteText: He is now gone into the army, but I am afraid he has turned out very wild.
subQuotationList: ['He is now gone into the army,', 'but I am afraid he has turned out very wild.']
speaker: Mrs. Reynolds

quoteText:
And that, is my master--and very like him. It was drawn at the same time as the
other--about eight years ago.
subQuotationList: ['And that,', 'is my master--and very like him. It was drawn at the same time as the\nother--about eight years ago.']
speaker: Mrs. Reynolds

quoteText:
I have heard much of your master's fine person, it is a handsome face. But, Lizzy, you can tell
us whether it is like or not.
subQuotationList: ["I have heard much of your master's fine person,", 'it is a handsome face. But, Lizzy, you can tell\nus whether it is like or not.']
speaker: Mrs. Gardiner

quoteText: Does that young lady know Mr. Darcy?
subQuotationList: ['Does that young lady know Mr. Darcy?']
speaker: Mrs. Reynolds

quoteText: A little.
subQuotationList: ['A little.']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText: And do not you think him a very handsome gentleman, Ma'am?
subQuotationList: ["And do not you think him a very handsome gentleman, Ma'am?"]
speaker: Mrs. Reynolds

quoteText: Yes, very handsome.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, very handsome.']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
I am sure _I_ know none so handsome; but in the gallery up stairs you
will see a finer, larger picture of him than this. This room was my late
master's favourite room, and these miniatures are just as they used to
be then. He was very fond of them.
subQuotationList:
["I am sure _I_ know none so handsome; but in the gallery up stairs you
will see a finer, larger picture of him than this. This room was my late
master's favourite room, and these miniatures are just as they used to
be then. He was very fond of them."]
speaker: Mrs. Reynolds

quoteText: And is Miss Darcy as handsome as her brother?
subQuotationList: ['And is Miss Darcy as handsome as her brother?']
speaker: Mr. Gardiner

quoteText:
Oh! yes--the handsomest young lady that ever was seen; and so
accomplished!--She plays and sings all day long. In the next room is a
new instrument just come down for her--a present from my master; she
comes here to-morrow with him.
subQuotationList:
['Oh! yes--the handsomest young lady that ever was seen; and so
accomplished!--She plays and sings all day long. In the next room is a
new instrument just come down for her--a present from my master; she
comes here to-morrow with him.']
speaker: Mrs. Reynolds

quoteText: Is your master much at Pemberley in the course of the year?
subQuotationList: ['Is your master much at Pemberley in the course of the year?']
speaker: Mr. Gardiner

quoteText:
Not so much as I could wish, Sir; but I dare say he may spend half his
time here; and Miss Darcy is always down for the summer months.
subQuotationList: ['Not so much as I could wish, Sir; but I dare say he may spend half his\ntime here; and Miss Darcy is always down for the summer months.']
speaker: Mrs. Reynolds

quoteText: Except, when she goes to Ramsgate.
subQuotationList: ['Except,', 'when she goes to Ramsgate.']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText: If your master would marry, you might see more of him.
subQuotationList: ['If your master would marry, you might see more of him.']
speaker: Mr. Gardiner

quoteText:
Yes, Sir; but I do not know when _that_ will be. I do not know who is
good enough for him.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, Sir; but I do not know when _that_ will be. I do not know who is\ngood enough for him.']
speaker: Mrs. Reynolds

quoteText:
It is
very much to his credit, I am sure, that you should think so.
subQuotationList: ['It is\nvery much to his credit, I am sure, that you should think so.']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
I say no more than the truth, and what every body will say that knows
him, I have never had a cross word from him in my life, and I have known him
ever since he was four years old.
subQuotationList: ['I say no more than the truth, and what every body will say that knows\nhim,', 'I have never had a cross word from him in my life, and I have known him\never since he was four years old.']
speaker: Mrs. Reynolds

quoteText:
There are very few people of whom so much can be said. You are lucky in
having such a master.
subQuotationList: ['There are very few people of whom so much can be said. You are lucky in\nhaving such a master.']
speaker: Mr. Gardiner

quoteText:
Yes, Sir, I know I am. If I was to go through the world, I could not
meet with a better. But I have always observed, that they who are
good-natured when children, are good-natured when they grow up; and he
was always the sweetest-tempered, most generous-hearted, boy in the
world.
subQuotationList:
['Yes, Sir, I know I am. If I was to go through the world, I could not
meet with a better. But I have always observed, that they who are
good-natured when children, are good-natured when they grow up; and he
was always the sweetest-tempered, most generous-hearted, boy in the
world.']
speaker: Mrs. Reynolds

quoteText: Can this be Mr. Darcy!
subQuotationList: ['Can this be Mr. Darcy!']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText: His father was an excellent man,
subQuotationList: ['His father was an excellent man,']
speaker: Mrs. Gardiner

quoteText:
Yes, Ma'am, that he was indeed; and his son will be just like him--just
as affable to the poor.
subQuotationList: ["Yes, Ma'am, that he was indeed; and his son will be just like him--just\nas affable to the poor."]
speaker: Mrs. Reynolds

quoteText:
He is the best landlord, and the best master, that ever
lived. Not like the wild young men now-a-days, who think of nothing but
themselves. There is not one of his tenants or servants but what will
give him a good name. Some people call him proud; but I am sure I never
saw any thing of it. To my fancy, it is only because he does not rattle
away like other young men.
subQuotationList:
['He is the best landlord, and the best master,', 'that ever
lived. Not like the wild young men now-a-days, who think of nothing but
themselves. There is not one of his tenants or servants but what will
give him a good name. Some people call him proud; but I am sure I never
saw any thing of it. To my fancy, it is only because he does not rattle
away like other young men.']
speaker: Mrs. Reynolds

quoteText: In what an amiable light does this place him!
subQuotationList: ['In what an amiable light does this place him!']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
This fine account of him, is not
quite consistent with his behaviour to our poor friend.
subQuotationList: ['This fine account of him,', 'is not\nquite consistent with his behaviour to our poor friend.']
speaker: Mrs. Gardiner

quoteText: Perhaps we might be deceived.
subQuotationList: ['Perhaps we might be deceived.']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText: That is not very likely; our authority was too good.
subQuotationList: ['That is not very likely; our authority was too good.']
speaker: Mrs. Gardiner

quoteText: He is certainly a good brother,
subQuotationList: ['He is certainly a good brother,']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
And this is always the way with him, Whatever
can give his sister any pleasure, is sure to be done in a moment. There
is nothing he would not do for her.
subQuotationList: ['And this is always the way with him,', 'Whatever\ncan give his sister any pleasure, is sure to be done in a moment. There\nis nothing he would not do for her.']
speaker: Mrs. Reynolds

quoteText: delightful, charming,
subQuotationList: ['delightful,', 'charming,']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
What will be his surprise, when he knows who they are! He takes them now for people of
fashion.
subQuotationList: ['What will be his surprise,', 'when he knows who they are! He takes them now for people of\nfashion.']
speaker: Elizabeth
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. Darcy']], [['Mr. Darcy'], ['Mrs. Gardiner', 'Mr. Gardiner'], ['Mr. Darcy'], ['Mrs. Gardiner', 'Mr. Gardiner']]]

quoteText:
Why is he so altered? From
what can it proceed? It cannot be for _me_, it cannot be for _my_ sake
that his manners are thus softened. My reproofs at Hunsford could not
work such a change as this. It is impossible that he should still love
me.
subQuotationList:
['Why is he so altered? From
what can it proceed? It cannot be for _me_, it cannot be for _my_ sake
that his manners are thus softened. My reproofs at Hunsford could not
work such a change as this. It is impossible that he should still love
me.']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
for your housekeeper, informed us that
you would certainly not be here till to-morrow; and indeed, before we
left Bakewell, we understood that you were not immediately expected in
the country.
subQuotationList:
['for your housekeeper,', 'informed us that
you would certainly not be here till to-morrow; and indeed, before we
left Bakewell, we understood that you were not immediately expected in
the country.']
speaker: Elizabeth
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mrs. Reynolds']], [['Elizabeth', 'Mrs. Gardiner', 'Mr. Gardiner'], ['Mrs. Gardiner', 'Mr. Gardiner', 'Elizabeth'], ['Elizabeth', 'Mrs. Gardiner', 'Mr. Gardiner']]]

quoteText:
They
will join me early to-morrow, and among them are some
who will claim an acquaintance with you,--Mr. Bingley and his sisters. There is also one other person in the party, who more particularly wishes to be known to you,--Will you allow
me, or do I ask too much, to introduce my sister to your acquaintance
during your stay at Lambton?
subQuotationList:
['They
will join me early to-morrow,', 'and among them are some
who will claim an acquaintance with you,--Mr. Bingley and his sisters.', 'There is also one other person in the party,', 'who more particularly wishes to be known to you,--Will you allow
me, or do I ask too much, to introduce my sister to your acquaintance
during your stay at Lambton?']
speaker: Mr. Darcy

quoteText: He is perfectly well behaved, polite, and unassuming,
subQuotationList: ['He is perfectly well behaved, polite, and unassuming,']
speaker: Mr. Gardiner

quoteText:
There _is_ something a little stately in him to be sure, but it is confined to his air, and is not unbecoming. I can now
say with the housekeeper, that though some people may call him proud,
_I_ have seen nothing of it.
subQuotationList: ['There _is_ something a little stately in him to be sure,', 'but it is confined to his air, and is not unbecoming. I can now\nsay with the housekeeper, that though some people may call him proud,\n_I_ have seen nothing of it.']
speaker: Mrs. Gardiner

quoteText:
I was never more surprised than by his behaviour to us. It was more
than civil; it was really attentive; and there was no necessity for such
attention. His acquaintance with Elizabeth was very trifling.
subQuotationList: ['I was never more surprised than by his behaviour to us. It was more\nthan civil; it was really attentive; and there was no necessity for such\nattention. His acquaintance with Elizabeth was very trifling.']
speaker: Mr. Gardiner

quoteText:
To be sure, Lizzy, he is not so handsome as Wickham;
or rather he has not Wickham's countenance, for his features are
perfectly good. But how came you to tell us that he was so
disagreeable?
subQuotationList:
['To be sure, Lizzy,', "he is not so handsome as Wickham;
or rather he has not Wickham's countenance, for his features are
perfectly good. But how came you to tell us that he was so
disagreeable?"]
speaker: Mrs. Gardiner
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Elizabeth']], [['Mr. Darcy'], ['George Wickham'], ['Mr. Darcy'], ['George Wickham'], ['Mr. Darcy'], ['Elizabeth'], ['Mrs. Gardiner', 'Mr. Gardiner'], ['Mr. Darcy']]]

quoteText:
But perhaps he may be a little whimsical in his civilities, Your great men often are; and therefore I shall not take him
at his word about fishing, as he might change his mind another day, and
warn me off his grounds.
subQuotationList: ['But perhaps he may be a little whimsical in his civilities,', 'Your great men often are; and therefore I shall not take him\nat his word about fishing, as he might change his mind another day, and\nwarn me off his grounds.']
speaker: Mr. Gardiner
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. Darcy'], ['Mr. Darcy']], [['Darcy'], ['Mr. Darcy'], ['Mr. Darcy'], ['Mr. Darcy'], ['Mr. Darcy']]]

quoteText:
From what we have seen of him, I really
should not have thought that he could have behaved in so cruel a way by
any body, as he has done by poor Wickham. He has not an ill-natured
look. On the contrary, there is something pleasing about his mouth when
he speaks. And there is something of dignity in his countenance, that
would not give one an unfavourable idea of his heart. But to be sure,
the good lady who shewed us the house, did give him a most flaming
character! I could hardly help laughing aloud sometimes. But he is a
liberal master, I suppose, and _that_ in the eye of a servant
comprehends every virtue.
subQuotationList:
['From what we have seen of him,', 'I really
should not have thought that he could have behaved in so cruel a way by
any body, as he has done by poor Wickham. He has not an ill-natured
look. On the contrary, there is something pleasing about his mouth when
he speaks. And there is something of dignity in his countenance, that
would not give one an unfavourable idea of his heart. But to be sure,
the good lady who shewed us the house, did give him a most flaming
character! I could hardly help laughing aloud sometimes. But he is a
liberal master, I suppose, and _that_ in the eye of a servant
comprehends every virtue.']
speaker: Mrs. Gardiner
mentionTextsList: [['we', 'him'], ['he', 'he', 'poor Wickham', 'He', 'his', 'he', 'his', 'his', 'the good lady who shewed us the house', 'him', 'he']]
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mrs. Gardiner', 'Mr. Gardiner'], ['Mr. Darcy']], [['Mr. Darcy'], ['Mr. Darcy'], ['George Wickham'], ['Mr. Darcy'], ['Mr. Darcy'], ['Darcy'], ['Mr. Darcy'], ['Mr. Darcy'], ['Mrs. Reynolds'], ['Mr. Darcy'], ['Mr. Darcy']]]

quoteText:
It
is above eight months. We have not met since the 26th of November, when
we were all dancing together at Netherfield.
subQuotationList: ['It\nis above eight months. We have not met since the 26th of November, when\nwe were all dancing together at Netherfield.']
speaker: Mr. Bingley

quoteText:
Pray, Miss Eliza, are not the ----shire militia removed from Meryton?
They must be a great loss to _your_ family.
subQuotationList: ['Pray, Miss Eliza, are not the ----shire militia removed from Meryton?\nThey must be a great loss to _your_ family.']
speaker: Miss Bingley
referringExpression: Miss Bingley saw all this likewise and in the imprudence of anger took the first opportunity of saying

quoteText:
How very ill Eliza Bennet looks this morning, Mr. Darcy, I
never in my life saw any one so much altered as she is since the winter.
She is grown so brown and coarse! Louisa and I were agreeing that we
should not have known her again.
subQuotationList:
['How very ill Eliza Bennet looks this morning, Mr. Darcy,', 'I
never in my life saw any one so much altered as she is since the winter.
She is grown so brown and coarse! Louisa and I were agreeing that we
should not have known her again.']
speaker: Miss Bingley

quoteText:
For my own part, I must confess that I never could see
any beauty in her. Her face is too thin; her complexion has no
brilliancy; and her features are not at all handsome. Her nose wants
character; there is nothing marked in its lines. Her teeth are
tolerable, but not out of the common way; and as for her eyes, which
have sometimes been called so fine, I never could perceive any thing
extraordinary in them. They have a sharp, shrewish look, which I do not
like at all; and in her air altogether, there is a self-sufficiency
without fashion, which is intolerable.
subQuotationList:
['For my own part,', 'I must confess that I never could see
any beauty in her. Her face is too thin; her complexion has no
brilliancy; and her features are not at all handsome. Her nose wants
character; there is nothing marked in its lines. Her teeth are
tolerable, but not out of the common way; and as for her eyes, which
have sometimes been called so fine, I never could perceive any thing
extraordinary in them. They have a sharp, shrewish look, which I do not
like at all; and in her air altogether, there is a self-sufficiency
without fashion, which is intolerable.']
speaker: Miss Bingley

quoteText:
I remember, when we first knew her in Hertfordshire, how amazed we all
were to find that she was a reputed beauty; and I particularly recollect
your saying one night, after they had been dining at Netherfield, But afterwards she
seemed to improve on you, and I believe you thought her rather pretty at
one time.
subQuotationList:
['I remember, when we first knew her in Hertfordshire, how amazed we all
were to find that she was a reputed beauty; and I particularly recollect
your saying one night, after they had been dining at Netherfield,', 'But afterwards she
seemed to improve on you, and I believe you thought her rather pretty at
one time.']
speaker: Miss Bingley
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Miss Bingley', 'Mr. Darcy', 'Mrs. Hurst'], ['Elizabeth'], ['Miss Bingley', 'Mr. Darcy', 'Mrs. Hurst'], ['Elizabeth'], ['Mary', 'Elizabeth', 'Mrs. Bennet', 'Lydia', 'Kitty', 'Mr. Bennet']], [['Mr. Darcy'], ['Mr. Darcy'], ['Elizabeth']]]

quoteText:
Yes, but _that_
was only when I first knew her, for it is many months since I have
considered her as one of the handsomest women of my acquaintance.
subQuotationList: ['Yes,', 'but _that_\nwas only when I first knew her, for it is many months since I have\nconsidered her as one of the handsomest women of my acquaintance.']
speaker: Mr. Darcy

quoteText: Oh! where, where is my uncle?
subQuotationList: ['Oh! where, where is my uncle?']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
I beg your pardon, but I must leave you.
I must find Mr. Gardiner this moment, on business that cannot be
delayed; I have not an instant to lose.
subQuotationList: ['I beg your pardon, but I must leave you.\nI must find Mr. Gardiner this moment, on business that cannot be\ndelayed; I have not an instant to lose.']
speaker: Elizabeth
referringExpression: she in whose mind every idea was superseded by Lydias situation hastily exclaimed

quoteText:
Good God! what is the matter? I will not detain you a minute,
but let me, or let the servant, go after Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner. You are
not well enough;--you cannot go yourself.
subQuotationList: ['Good God! what is the matter?', 'I will not detain you a minute,\nbut let me, or let the servant, go after Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner. You are\nnot well enough;--you cannot go yourself.']
speaker: Mr. Darcy

quoteText:
Let me call your maid. Is there nothing you could take, to give you
present relief?--A glass of wine;--shall I get you one?--You are very
ill.
subQuotationList: ['Let me call your maid. Is there nothing you could take, to give you\npresent relief?--A glass of wine;--shall I get you one?--You are very\nill.']
speaker: Mr. Darcy
referringExpression: it was impossible for Darcy to leave her or to refrain from saying

quoteText:
No, I thank you; There
is nothing the matter with me. I am quite well. I am only distressed by
some dreadful news which I have just received from Longbourn.
subQuotationList: ['No, I thank you;', 'There\nis nothing the matter with me. I am quite well. I am only distressed by\nsome dreadful news which I have just received from Longbourn.']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
I have just had a letter from
Jane, with such dreadful news. It cannot be concealed from any one. My
youngest sister has left all her friends--has eloped;--has thrown
herself into the power of--of Mr. Wickham. They are gone off together
from Brighton. _You_ know him too well to doubt the rest. She has no
money, no connections, nothing that can tempt him to--she is lost for
ever.
subQuotationList:
['I have just had a letter from
Jane, with such dreadful news. It cannot be concealed from any one. My
youngest sister has left all her friends--has eloped;--has thrown
herself into the power of--of Mr. Wickham. They are gone off together
from Brighton. _You_ know him too well to doubt the rest. She has no
money, no connections, nothing that can tempt him to--she is lost for
ever.']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
When I consider, that _I_ might have prevented it!--_I_ who knew
what he was. Had I but explained some part of it only--some part of what
I learnt, to my own family! Had his character been known, this could not
have happened. But it is all, all too late now.
subQuotationList:
['When I consider,', 'that _I_ might have prevented it!--_I_ who knew
what he was. Had I but explained some part of it only--some part of what
I learnt, to my own family! Had his character been known, this could not
have happened. But it is all, all too late now.']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
I am grieved, indeed, grieved--shocked. But is it
certain, absolutely certain?
subQuotationList: ['I am grieved, indeed,', 'grieved--shocked. But is it\ncertain, absolutely certain?']
speaker: Mr. Darcy

quoteText:
Oh yes!--They left Brighton together on Sunday night, and were traced
almost to London, but not beyond; they are certainly not gone to
Scotland.
subQuotationList: ['Oh yes!--They left Brighton together on Sunday night, and were traced\nalmost to London, but not beyond; they are certainly not gone to\nScotland.']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText: And what has been done, what has been attempted, to recover her?
subQuotationList: ['And what has been done, what has been attempted, to recover her?']
speaker: Mr. Darcy

quoteText:
My father is gone to London, and Jane has written to beg my uncle's
immediate assistance, and we shall be off, I hope, in half an hour. But
nothing can be done; I know very well that nothing can be done. How is
such a man to be worked on? How are they even to be discovered? I have
not the smallest hope. It is every way horrible!
subQuotationList:
["My father is gone to London, and Jane has written to beg my uncle's
immediate assistance, and we shall be off, I hope, in half an hour. But
nothing can be done; I know very well that nothing can be done. How is
such a man to be worked on? How are they even to be discovered? I have
not the smallest hope. It is every way horrible!"]
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
When _my_ eyes were opened to his real character.--Oh! had I known what
I ought, what I dared, to do! But I knew not--I was afraid of doing too
much. Wretched, wretched, mistake!
subQuotationList: ['When _my_ eyes were opened to his real character.--Oh! had I known what\nI ought, what I dared, to do! But I knew not--I was afraid of doing too\nmuch. Wretched, wretched, mistake!']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
I am afraid you have been
long desiring my absence, nor have I any thing to plead in excuse of my
stay, but real, though unavailing, concern. Would to heaven that any
thing could be either said or done on my part, that might offer
consolation to such distress.--But I will not torment you with vain
wishes, which may seem purposely to ask for your thanks. This
unfortunate affair will, I fear, prevent my sister's having the pleasure
of seeing you at Pemberley to-day.
subQuotationList:
["I am afraid you have been
long desiring my absence, nor have I any thing to plead in excuse of my
stay, but real, though unavailing, concern. Would to heaven that any
thing could be either said or done on my part, that might offer
consolation to such distress.--But I will not torment you with vain
wishes, which may seem purposely to ask for your thanks. This
unfortunate affair will, I fear, prevent my sister's having the pleasure
of seeing you at Pemberley to-day."]
speaker: Mr. Darcy
referringExpression: her companion who in a manner which though it spoke compassion spoke likewise restraint said

quoteText:
Oh, yes. Be so kind as to apologize for us to Miss Darcy. Say that
urgent business calls us home immediately. Conceal the unhappy truth as
long as it is possible.--I know it cannot be long.
subQuotationList: ['Oh, yes. Be so kind as to apologize for us to Miss Darcy. Say that\nurgent business calls us home immediately. Conceal the unhappy truth as\nlong as it is possible.--I know it cannot be long.']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
But what is to be
done about Pemberley? John told us Mr. Darcy was
here when you sent for us;--was it so?
subQuotationList: ['But what is to be\ndone about Pemberley?', 'John told us Mr. Darcy was\nhere when you sent for us;--was it so?']
speaker: Mrs. Gardiner

quoteText:
Yes; and I told him we should not be able to keep our engagement.
_That_ is all settled.
subQuotationList: ['Yes; and I told him we should not be able to keep our engagement.\n_That_ is all settled.']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText: That is all settled;
subQuotationList: ['That is all settled;']
speaker: Mrs. Gardiner

quoteText:
And are they upon such terms as for her to disclose the real
truth! Oh, that I knew how it was!
subQuotationList: ['And are they upon such terms as for her to disclose the real\ntruth! Oh, that I knew how it was!']
speaker: Mrs. Gardiner

quoteText:
I have been thinking it over again, Elizabeth, and really, upon serious consideration, I am much
more inclined than I was to judge as your eldest sister does of the
matter. It appears to me so very unlikely, that any young man should
form such a design against a girl who is by no means unprotected or
friendless, and who was actually staying in his colonel's family, that I
am strongly inclined to hope the best. Could he expect that her friends
would not step forward? Could he expect to be noticed again by the
regiment, after such an affront to Colonel Forster? His temptation is
not adequate to the risk.
subQuotationList:
['I have been thinking it over again, Elizabeth,', "and really, upon serious consideration, I am much
more inclined than I was to judge as your eldest sister does of the
matter. It appears to me so very unlikely, that any young man should
form such a design against a girl who is by no means unprotected or
friendless, and who was actually staying in his colonel's family, that I
am strongly inclined to hope the best. Could he expect that her friends
would not step forward? Could he expect to be noticed again by the
regiment, after such an affront to Colonel Forster? His temptation is
not adequate to the risk."]
speaker: Mr. Gardiner

quoteText: Do you really think so?
subQuotationList: ['Do you really think so?']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
Upon my word, I begin to be of your uncle's
opinion. It is really too great a violation of decency, honour, and
interest, for him to be guilty of it. I cannot think so very ill of
Wickham. Can you, yourself, Lizzy, so wholly give him up, as to believe
him capable of it?
subQuotationList:
['Upon my word,', "I begin to be of your uncle's
opinion. It is really too great a violation of decency, honour, and
interest, for him to be guilty of it. I cannot think so very ill of
Wickham. Can you, yourself, Lizzy, so wholly give him up, as to believe
him capable of it?"]
speaker: Mrs. Gardiner

quoteText:
Not perhaps of neglecting his own interest. But of every other neglect
I can believe him capable. If, indeed, it should be so! But I dare not
hope it. Why should they not go on to Scotland, if that had been the
case?
subQuotationList:
['Not perhaps of neglecting his own interest. But of every other neglect
I can believe him capable. If, indeed, it should be so! But I dare not
hope it. Why should they not go on to Scotland, if that had been the
case?']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
In the first place, there is no absolute proof
that they are not gone to Scotland.
subQuotationList: ['In the first place,', 'there is no absolute proof\nthat they are not gone to Scotland.']
speaker: Mr. Gardiner

quoteText:
Oh! but their removing from the chaise into an hackney coach is such a
presumption! And, besides, no traces of them were to be found on the
Barnet road.
subQuotationList: ['Oh! but their removing from the chaise into an hackney coach is such a\npresumption! And, besides, no traces of them were to be found on the\nBarnet road.']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
Well, then--supposing them to be in London. They may be there, though
for the purpose of concealment, for no more exceptionable purpose. It is
not likely that money should be very abundant on either side; and it
might strike them that they could be more economically, though less
expeditiously, married in London, than in Scotland.
subQuotationList:
['Well, then--supposing them to be in London. They may be there, though
for the purpose of concealment, for no more exceptionable purpose. It is
not likely that money should be very abundant on either side; and it
might strike them that they could be more economically, though less
expeditiously, married in London, than in Scotland.']
speaker: Mr. Gardiner

quoteText:
But why all this secrecy? Why any fear of detection? Why must their
marriage be private? Oh! no, no, this is not likely. His most particular
friend, you see by Jane's account, was persuaded of his never intending
to marry her. Wickham will never marry a woman without some money. He
cannot afford it. And what claims has Lydia, what attractions has she
beyond youth, health, and good humour, that could make him for her sake,
forego every chance of benefiting himself by marrying well? As to what
restraint the apprehension of disgrace in the corps might throw on a
dishonourable elopement with her, I am not able to judge; for I know
nothing of the effects that such a step might produce. But as to your
other objection, I am afraid it will hardly hold good. Lydia has no
brothers to step forward; and he might imagine, from my father's
behaviour, from his indolence and the little attention he has ever
seemed to give to what was going forward in his family, that _he_ would
do as little, and think as little about it, as any father could do, in
such a matter.
subQuotationList:
["But why all this secrecy? Why any fear of detection? Why must their
marriage be private? Oh! no, no, this is not likely. His most particular
friend, you see by Jane's account, was persuaded of his never intending
to marry her. Wickham will never marry a woman without some money. He
cannot afford it. And what claims has Lydia, what attractions has she
beyond youth, health, and good humour, that could make him for her sake,
forego every chance of benefiting himself by marrying well? As to what
restraint the apprehension of disgrace in the corps might throw on a
dishonourable elopement with her, I am not able to judge; for I know
nothing of the effects that such a step might produce. But as to your
other objection, I am afraid it will hardly hold good. Lydia has no
brothers to step forward; and he might imagine, from my father's
behaviour, from his indolence and the little attention he has ever
seemed to give to what was going forward in his family, that _he_ would
do as little, and think as little about it, as any father could do, in
such a matter."]
speaker: Elizabeth
mentionEntitiesList: [[['George Wickham', 'Lydia'], ['Jane'], ['Lydia'], ['Lydia'], ['Lydia'], ['Lydia'], ['Mr. Bennet'], ['Lydia'], ['Mr. Gardiner'], ['Lydia'], ['Mr. Bennet'], ['Mr. Bennet'], ['Mr. Bennet'], ['Mr. Bennet'], ['Mr. Bennet']]]

quoteText:
But can you think that Lydia is so lost to every thing but love of him,
as to consent to live with him on any other terms than marriage?
subQuotationList: ['But can you think that Lydia is so lost to every thing but love of him,\nas to consent to live with him on any other terms than marriage?']
speaker: Mr. Gardiner

quoteText:
It does seem, and it is most shocking indeed, that a sister's sense of decency and virtue in such
a point should admit of doubt. But, really, I know not what to say.
Perhaps I am not doing her justice. But she is very young; she has never
been taught to think on serious subjects; and for the last half year,
nay, for a twelvemonth, she has been given up to nothing but amusement
and vanity. She has been allowed to dispose of her time in the most idle
and frivolous manner, and to adopt any opinions that came in her way.
Since the ----shire were first quartered in Meryton, nothing but love,
flirtation, and officers, have been in her head. She has been doing
every thing in her power by thinking and talking on the subject, to give
greater--what shall I call it? susceptibility to her feelings; which are
naturally lively enough. And we all know that Wickham has every charm of
person and address that can captivate a woman.
subQuotationList:
['It does seem, and it is most shocking indeed,', "that a sister's sense of decency and virtue in such
a point should admit of doubt. But, really, I know not what to say.
Perhaps I am not doing her justice. But she is very young; she has never
been taught to think on serious subjects; and for the last half year,
nay, for a twelvemonth, she has been given up to nothing but amusement
and vanity. She has been allowed to dispose of her time in the most idle
and frivolous manner, and to adopt any opinions that came in her way.
Since the ----shire were first quartered in Meryton, nothing but love,
flirtation, and officers, have been in her head. She has been doing
every thing in her power by thinking and talking on the subject, to give
greater--what shall I call it? susceptibility to her feelings; which are
naturally lively enough. And we all know that Wickham has every charm of
person and address that can captivate a woman."]
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
But you see that Jane, does not think so ill of
Wickham, as to believe him capable of the attempt.
subQuotationList: ['But you see that Jane,', 'does not think so ill of\nWickham, as to believe him capable of the attempt.']
speaker: Mrs. Gardiner

quoteText:
Of whom does Jane ever think ill? And who is there, whatever might be
their former conduct, that she would believe capable of such an attempt,
till it were proved against them? But Jane knows, as well as I do, what
Wickham really is. We both know that he has been profligate in every
sense of the word. That he has neither integrity nor honour. That he is
as false and deceitful, as he is insinuating.
subQuotationList:
['Of whom does Jane ever think ill? And who is there, whatever might be
their former conduct, that she would believe capable of such an attempt,
till it were proved against them? But Jane knows, as well as I do, what
Wickham really is. We both know that he has been profligate in every
sense of the word. That he has neither integrity nor honour. That he is
as false and deceitful, as he is insinuating.']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText: And do you really know all this?
subQuotationList: ['And do you really know all this?']
speaker: Mrs. Gardiner

quoteText:
I do, indeed, I told you the other day,
of his infamous behaviour to Mr. Darcy; and you, yourself, when last at
Longbourn, heard in what manner he spoke of the man, who had behaved
with such forbearance and liberality towards him. And there are other
circumstances which I am not at liberty--which it is not worth while to
relate; but his lies about the whole Pemberley family are endless. From
what he said of Miss Darcy, I was thoroughly prepared to see a proud,
reserved, disagreeable girl. Yet he knew to the contrary himself. He
must know that she was as amiable and unpretending as we have found
her.
subQuotationList:
['I do, indeed,', 'I told you the other day,
of his infamous behaviour to Mr. Darcy; and you, yourself, when last at
Longbourn, heard in what manner he spoke of the man, who had behaved
with such forbearance and liberality towards him. And there are other
circumstances which I am not at liberty--which it is not worth while to
relate; but his lies about the whole Pemberley family are endless. From
what he said of Miss Darcy, I was thoroughly prepared to see a proud,
reserved, disagreeable girl. Yet he knew to the contrary himself. He
must know that she was as amiable and unpretending as we have found
her.']
speaker: Elizabeth
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Mrs. Gardiner'], ['George Wickham'], ['Mr. Darcy'], ['Mrs. Gardiner'], ['Mrs. Gardiner'], ['George Wickham'], ['George Wickham'], ['Miss Darcy'], ['George Wickham'], ['George Wickham'], ['George Wickham'], ['Miss Darcy'], ['Elizabeth', 'Mrs. Gardiner', 'Mr. Gardiner'], ['Miss Darcy']]]

quoteText:
But does Lydia know nothing of this? Can she be ignorant of what you
and Jane seem so well to understand?
subQuotationList: ['But does Lydia know nothing of this? Can she be ignorant of what you\nand Jane seem so well to understand?']
speaker: Mrs. Gardiner

quoteText:
Oh, yes!--that, that is the worst of all. Till I was in Kent, and saw
so much both of Mr. Darcy and his relation, Colonel Fitzwilliam, I was
ignorant of the truth myself. And when I returned home, the ----shire
was to leave Meryton in a week or fortnight's time. As that was the
case, neither Jane, to whom I related the whole, nor I, thought it
necessary to make our knowledge public; for of what use could it
apparently be to any one, that the good opinion which all the
neighbourhood had of him, should then be overthrown? And even when it
was settled that Lydia should go with Mrs. Forster, the necessity of
opening her eyes to his character never occurred to me. That _she_ could
be in any danger from the deception never entered my head. That such a
consequence as _this_ should ensue, you may easily believe was far
enough from my thoughts.
subQuotationList:
["Oh, yes!--that, that is the worst of all. Till I was in Kent, and saw
so much both of Mr. Darcy and his relation, Colonel Fitzwilliam, I was
ignorant of the truth myself. And when I returned home, the ----shire
was to leave Meryton in a week or fortnight's time. As that was the
case, neither Jane, to whom I related the whole, nor I, thought it
necessary to make our knowledge public; for of what use could it
apparently be to any one, that the good opinion which all the
neighbourhood had of him, should then be overthrown? And even when it
was settled that Lydia should go with Mrs. Forster, the necessity of
opening her eyes to his character never occurred to me. That _she_ could
be in any danger from the deception never entered my head. That such a
consequence as _this_ should ensue, you may easily believe was far
enough from my thoughts."]
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
When they all removed to Brighton, therefore, you had no reason, I
suppose, to believe them fond of each other.
subQuotationList: ['When they all removed to Brighton, therefore, you had no reason, I\nsuppose, to believe them fond of each other.']
speaker: Mrs. Gardiner

quoteText:
Not the slightest. I can remember no symptom of affection on either
side; and had any thing of the kind been perceptible, you must be aware
that ours is not a family, on which it could be thrown away. When first
he entered the corps, she was ready enough to admire him; but so we all
were. Every girl in, or near Meryton, was out of her senses about him
for the first two months; but he never distinguished _her_ by any
particular attention, and, consequently, after a moderate period of
extravagant and wild admiration, her fancy for him gave way, and others
of the regiment, who treated her with more distinction, again became her
favourites.
subQuotationList:
['Not the slightest. I can remember no symptom of affection on either
side; and had any thing of the kind been perceptible, you must be aware
that ours is not a family, on which it could be thrown away. When first
he entered the corps, she was ready enough to admire him; but so we all
were. Every girl in, or near Meryton, was out of her senses about him
for the first two months; but he never distinguished _her_ by any
particular attention, and, consequently, after a moderate period of
extravagant and wild admiration, her fancy for him gave way, and others
of the regiment, who treated her with more distinction, again became her
favourites.']
speaker: Elizabeth
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mrs. Gardiner'], ['Elizabeth', 'Jane', 'Mrs. Bennet', 'Mary', 'Mr. Bennet', 'Kitty', 'Lydia'], ['George Wickham'], ['Lydia'], ['George Wickham'], ['Elizabeth', 'Jane', 'Mrs. Bennet', 'Mary', 'Mr. Bennet', 'Kitty', 'Lydia'], ['George Wickham'], ['Lydia'], ['Lydia'], ['George Wickham'], ['Lydia'], ['Lydia']]]

quoteText:
Not yet, But now that my dear uncle is come, I hope
every thing will be well.
subQuotationList: ['Not yet,', 'But now that my dear uncle is come, I hope\nevery thing will be well.']
speaker: Jane

quoteText: Is my father in town?
subQuotationList: ['Is my father in town?']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText: Yes, he went on Tuesday as I wrote you word.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, he went on Tuesday as I wrote you word.']
speaker: Jane

quoteText: And have you heard from him often?
subQuotationList: ['And have you heard from him often?']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
We have heard only once. He wrote me a few lines on Wednesday, to say
that he had arrived in safety, and to give me his directions, which I
particularly begged him to do. He merely added, that he should not write
again, till he had something of importance to mention.
subQuotationList:
['We have heard only once. He wrote me a few lines on Wednesday, to say
that he had arrived in safety, and to give me his directions, which I
particularly begged him to do. He merely added, that he should not write
again, till he had something of importance to mention.']
speaker: Jane
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mrs. Bennet', 'Mary', 'Kitty', 'Jane'], ['Mr. Bennet'], ['Mr. Bennet'], ['Mr. Bennet'], ['Mr. Bennet'], ['Mr. Bennet'], ['Mr. Bennet'], ['Mr. Bennet']]]

quoteText: And my mother--How is she? How are you all?
subQuotationList: ['And my mother--How is she? How are you all?']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
My mother is tolerably well, I trust; though her spirits are greatly
shaken. She is up stairs, and will have great satisfaction in seeing you
all. She does not yet leave her dressing-room. Mary and Kitty, thank
Heaven! are quite well.
subQuotationList:
['My mother is tolerably well, I trust; though her spirits are greatly
shaken. She is up stairs, and will have great satisfaction in seeing you
all. She does not yet leave her dressing-room. Mary and Kitty, thank
Heaven! are quite well.']
speaker: Jane
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mrs. Bennet'], ['Mrs. Bennet'], ['Mrs. Bennet'], ['Elizabeth', 'Mrs. Gardiner', 'Mr. Gardiner'], ['Mrs. Bennet'], ['Mrs. Bennet'], ['Mary'], ['Kitty']]]

quoteText:
But you--How are you? You look pale. How much you
must have gone through!
subQuotationList: ['But you--How are you?', 'You look pale. How much you\nmust have gone through!']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
If I had been able, to carry my point of going to Brighton,
with all my family, _this_ would not have happened; but poor dear Lydia
had nobody to take care of her. Why did the Forsters ever let her go out
of their sight? I am sure there was some great neglect or other on their
side, for she is not the kind of girl to do such a thing, if she had
been well looked after. I always thought they were very unfit to have
the charge of her; but I was over-ruled, as I always am. Poor dear
child! And now here's Mr. Bennet gone away, and I know he will fight
Wickham, wherever he meets him, and then he will be killed, and what is
to become of us all? The Collinses will turn us out, before he is cold
in his grave; and if you are not kind to us, brother, I do not know what
we shall do.
subQuotationList:
['If I had been able,', "to carry my point of going to Brighton,
with all my family, _this_ would not have happened; but poor dear Lydia
had nobody to take care of her. Why did the Forsters ever let her go out
of their sight? I am sure there was some great neglect or other on their
side, for she is not the kind of girl to do such a thing, if she had
been well looked after. I always thought they were very unfit to have
the charge of her; but I was over-ruled, as I always am. Poor dear
child! And now here's Mr. Bennet gone away, and I know he will fight
Wickham, wherever he meets him, and then he will be killed, and what is
to become of us all? The Collinses will turn us out, before he is cold
in his grave; and if you are not kind to us, brother, I do not know what
we shall do."]
speaker: Mrs. Bennet

mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Elizabeth', 'Jane', 'Mary', 'Lydia', 'Mr. Bennet', 'Kitty'], ['Lydia'], ['Lydia'], ['Colonel Forster'], ['Lydia'], ['Colonel Forster'], ['Colonel Forster'], ['Lydia'], ['Lydia'], ['Colonel Forster'], ['Lydia'], ['Lydia'], ['Mr. Bennet'], ['Mr. Bennet'], ['George Wickham'], ['Mr. Bennet'], ['George Wickham'], ['Mr. Bennet'], ['Mary', 'Elizabeth', 'Mrs. Bennet', 'Kitty'], ['Charlotte Lucas', 'Mr. Collins'], ['Mary', 'Elizabeth', 'Mrs. Bennet', 'Kitty'], ['Mr. Bennet'], ['Mr. Bennet'], ['Mr. Gardiner'], ['Mary', 'Elizabeth', 'Mrs. Bennet', 'Kitty'], ['Mr. Gardiner']]]

quoteText:
Do not give way to useless alarm, though it is right to be
prepared for the worst, there is no occasion to look on it as certain.
It is not quite a week since they left Brighton. In a few days more, we
may gain some news of them, and till we know that they are not married,
and have no design of marrying, do not let us give the matter over as
lost. As soon as I get to town, I shall go to my brother, and make him
come home with me to Gracechurch Street, and then we may consult
together as to what is to be done.
subQuotationList:
['Do not give way to useless alarm,', 'though it is right to be
prepared for the worst, there is no occasion to look on it as certain.
It is not quite a week since they left Brighton. In a few days more, we
may gain some news of them, and till we know that they are not married,
and have no design of marrying, do not let us give the matter over as
lost. As soon as I get to town, I shall go to my brother, and make him
come home with me to Gracechurch Street, and then we may consult
together as to what is to be done.']
speaker: Mr. Gardiner
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['George Wickham', 'Lydia'], ['Elizabeth', 'Mrs. Bennet', 'Mrs. Gardiner', 'Mr. Gardiner'], ['George Wickham', 'Lydia'], ['Elizabeth', 'Mrs. Bennet', 'Mrs. Gardiner', 'Mr. Gardiner'], ['George Wickham', 'Lydia'], ['Elizabeth', 'Mrs. Bennet', 'Mrs. Gardiner', 'Mr. Gardiner'], ['Mr. Bennet'], ['Mr. Bennet'], ['Mr. Bennet', 'Mr. Gardiner']]]

quoteText:
Oh! my dear brother, that is exactly what I
could most wish for. And now do, when you get to town, find them out,
wherever they may be; and if they are not married already, _make_ them
marry. And as for wedding clothes, do not let them wait for that, but
tell Lydia she shall have as much money as she chuses, to buy them,
after they are married. And, above all things, keep Mr. Bennet from
fighting. Tell him what a dreadful state I am in,--that I am frightened
out of my wits; and have such tremblings, such flutterings, all over me,
such spasms in my side, and pains in my head, and such beatings at
heart, that I can get no rest by night nor by day. And tell my dear
Lydia, not to give any directions about her clothes, till she has seen
me, for she does not know which are the best warehouses. Oh, brother,
how kind you are! I know you will contrive it all.
subQuotationList:
['Oh! my dear brother,', 'that is exactly what I
could most wish for. And now do, when you get to town, find them out,
wherever they may be; and if they are not married already, _make_ them
marry. And as for wedding clothes, do not let them wait for that, but
tell Lydia she shall have as much money as she chuses, to buy them,
after they are married. And, above all things, keep Mr. Bennet from
fighting. Tell him what a dreadful state I am in,--that I am frightened
out of my wits; and have such tremblings, such flutterings, all over me,
such spasms in my side, and pains in my head, and such beatings at
heart, that I can get no rest by night nor by day. And tell my dear
Lydia, not to give any directions about her clothes, till she has seen
me, for she does not know which are the best warehouses. Oh, brother,
how kind you are! I know you will contrive it all.']
speaker: Mrs. Bennet
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. Gardiner']], [['Mr. Gardiner'], ['George Wickham', 'Lydia'], ['George Wickham', 'Lydia'], ['George Wickham', 'Lydia'], ['George Wickham', 'Lydia'], ['George Wickham', 'Lydia'], ['Lydia'], ['Lydia'], ['Lydia'], ['George Wickham', 'Lydia'], ['George Wickham', 'Lydia'], ['Mr. Bennet'], ['Mr. Bennet'], ['Lydia'], ['Lydia'], ['Lydia'], ['Lydia'], ['Mr. Gardiner'], ['Mr. Gardiner'], ['Mr. Gardiner']]]

quoteText:
This is a most unfortunate affair; and will probably be much talked of.
But we must stem the tide of malice, and pour into the wounded bosoms of
each other, the balm of sisterly consolation.
subQuotationList: ['This is a most unfortunate affair; and will probably be much talked of.\nBut we must stem the tide of malice, and pour into the wounded bosoms of\neach other, the balm of sisterly consolation.']
speaker: Mary
referringExpression: she was mistress enough of herself to whisper to Elizabeth

quoteText:
Unhappy as the event must be for Lydia, we may draw from it this useful
lesson; that loss of virtue in a female is irretrievable--that one false
step involves her in endless ruin--that her reputation is no less
brittle than it is beautiful,--and that she cannot be too much guarded
in her behaviour towards the undeserving of the other sex.
subQuotationList:
['Unhappy as the event must be for Lydia, we may draw from it this useful
lesson; that loss of virtue in a female is irretrievable--that one false
step involves her in endless ruin--that her reputation is no less
brittle than it is beautiful,--and that she cannot be too much guarded
in her behaviour towards the undeserving of the other sex.']
speaker: Mary

quoteText:
But tell me all and every thing about it, which
I have not already heard. Give me farther particulars. What did Colonel
Forster say? Had they no apprehension of any thing before the elopement
took place? They must have seen them together for ever.
subQuotationList:
['But tell me all and every thing about it, which
I have not already heard. Give me farther particulars. What did Colonel
Forster say? Had they no apprehension of any thing before the elopement
took place? They must have seen them together for ever.']
speaker: Elizabeth
referringExpression: the former continued the subject by saying

quoteText:
Colonel Forster did own that he had often suspected some partiality,
especially on Lydia's side, but nothing to give him any alarm. I am so
grieved for him. His behaviour was attentive and kind to the utmost. He
_was_ coming to us, in order to assure us of his concern, before he had
any idea of their not being gone to Scotland: when that apprehension
first got abroad, it hastened his journey.
subQuotationList:
["Colonel Forster did own that he had often suspected some partiality,
especially on Lydia's side, but nothing to give him any alarm. I am so
grieved for him. His behaviour was attentive and kind to the utmost. He
_was_ coming to us, in order to assure us of his concern, before he had
any idea of their not being gone to Scotland: when that apprehension
first got abroad, it hastened his journey."]
speaker: Jane
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Colonel Forster'], ['Colonel Forster'], ['Lydia'], ['Colonel Forster'], ['Colonel Forster'], ['Colonel Forster'], ['Colonel Forster'], ['Mary', 'Mrs. Bennet', 'Kitty', 'Mr. Bennet'], ['Mary', 'Mrs. Bennet', 'Kitty', 'Mr. Bennet'], ['Colonel Forster'], ['Colonel Forster'], ['George Wickham', 'Lydia'], ['Colonel Forster']]]

quoteText:
And was Denny convinced that Wickham would not marry? Did he know of
their intending to go off? Had Colonel Forster seen Denny himself?
subQuotationList: ['And was Denny convinced that Wickham would not marry? Did he know of\ntheir intending to go off? Had Colonel Forster seen Denny himself?']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
Yes; but when questioned by _him_ Denny denied knowing any thing of
their plan, and would not give his real opinion about it. He did not
repeat his persuasion of their not marrying--and from _that_, I am
inclined to hope, he might have been misunderstood before.
subQuotationList:
['Yes; but when questioned by _him_ Denny denied knowing any thing of
their plan, and would not give his real opinion about it. He did not
repeat his persuasion of their not marrying--and from _that_, I am
inclined to hope, he might have been misunderstood before.']
speaker: Jane

quoteText:
And till Colonel Forster came himself, not one of you entertained a
doubt, I suppose, of their being really married?
subQuotationList: ['And till Colonel Forster came himself, not one of you entertained a\ndoubt, I suppose, of their being really married?']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
How was it possible that such an idea should enter our brains! I felt a
little uneasy--a little fearful of my sister's happiness with him in
marriage, because I knew that his conduct had not been always quite
right. My father and mother knew nothing of that, they only felt how
imprudent a match it must be. Kitty then owned, with a very natural
triumph on knowing more than the rest of us, that in Lydia's last
letter, she had prepared her for such a step. She had known, it seems,
of their being in love with each other, many weeks.
subQuotationList:
["How was it possible that such an idea should enter our brains! I felt a
little uneasy--a little fearful of my sister's happiness with him in
marriage, because I knew that his conduct had not been always quite
right. My father and mother knew nothing of that, they only felt how
imprudent a match it must be. Kitty then owned, with a very natural
triumph on knowing more than the rest of us, that in Lydia's last
letter, she had prepared her for such a step. She had known, it seems,
of their being in love with each other, many weeks."]
speaker: Jane
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Jane', 'Mrs. Bennet', 'Mary', 'Mr. Bennet', 'Kitty'], ['Lydia'], ['George Wickham'], ['George Wickham'], ['Mr. Bennet'], ['Mrs. Bennet'], ['Mr. Bennet', 'Mrs. Bennet'], ['Kitty'], ['Mary', 'Mrs. Bennet', 'Mr. Bennet'], ['Lydia'], ['Lydia'], ['Kitty'], ['Kitty'], ['George Wickham', 'Lydia']]]

quoteText: But not before they went to Brighton?
subQuotationList: ['But not before they went to Brighton?']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText: No, I believe not.
subQuotationList: ['No, I believe not.']
speaker: Jane

quoteText:
And did Colonel Forster appear to think ill of Wickham himself? Does he
know his real character?
subQuotationList: ['And did Colonel Forster appear to think ill of Wickham himself? Does he\nknow his real character?']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
I must confess that he did not speak so well of Wickham as he formerly
did. He believed him to be imprudent and extravagant. And since this sad
affair has taken place, it is said, that he left Meryton greatly in
debt; but I hope this may be false.
subQuotationList:
['I must confess that he did not speak so well of Wickham as he formerly
did. He believed him to be imprudent and extravagant. And since this sad
affair has taken place, it is said, that he left Meryton greatly in
debt; but I hope this may be false.']
speaker: Jane

quoteText:
Oh, Jane, had we been less secret, had we told what we knew of him,
this could not have happened!
subQuotationList: ['Oh, Jane, had we been less secret, had we told what we knew of him,\nthis could not have happened!']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
Perhaps it would have been better; But to expose
the former faults of any person, without knowing what their present
feelings were, seemed unjustifiable. We acted with the best intentions.
subQuotationList: ['Perhaps it would have been better;', 'But to expose\nthe former faults of any person, without knowing what their present\nfeelings were, seemed unjustifiable. We acted with the best intentions.']
speaker: Jane

quoteText:
Could Colonel Forster repeat the particulars of Lydia's note to his
wife?
subQuotationList: ["Could Colonel Forster repeat the particulars of Lydia's note to his\nwife?"]
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText: He brought it with him for us to see.
subQuotationList: ['He brought it with him for us to see.']
speaker: Jane

quoteText:
Oh! thoughtless, thoughtless Lydia! What a letter is this, to be written at such a moment. But
at least it shews, that _she_ was serious in the object of her journey.
Whatever he might afterwards persuade her to, it was not on her side a
_scheme_ of infamy. My poor father! how he must have felt it!
subQuotationList:
['Oh! thoughtless, thoughtless Lydia!', 'What a letter is this, to be written at such a moment. But
at least it shews, that _she_ was serious in the object of her journey.
Whatever he might afterwards persuade her to, it was not on her side a
_scheme_ of infamy. My poor father! how he must have felt it!']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
I never saw any one so shocked. He could not speak a word for full ten
minutes. My mother was taken ill immediately, and the whole house in
such confusion!
subQuotationList: ['I never saw any one so shocked. He could not speak a word for full ten\nminutes. My mother was taken ill immediately, and the whole house in\nsuch confusion!']
speaker: Jane

quoteText:
Oh! Jane, was there a servant belonging to it, who
did not know the whole story before the end of the day?
subQuotationList: ['Oh! Jane,', 'was there a servant belonging to it, who\ndid not know the whole story before the end of the day?']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
I do not know.--I hope there was.--But to be guarded at such a time, is
very difficult. My mother was in hysterics, and though I endeavoured to
give her every assistance in my power, I am afraid I did not do so much
as I might have done! But the horror of what might possibly happen,
almost took from me my faculties.
subQuotationList:
['I do not know.--I hope there was.--But to be guarded at such a time, is
very difficult. My mother was in hysterics, and though I endeavoured to
give her every assistance in my power, I am afraid I did not do so much
as I might have done! But the horror of what might possibly happen,
almost took from me my faculties.']
speaker: Jane

quoteText:
Your attendance upon her, has been too much for you. You do not look
well. Oh! that I had been with you, you have had every care and anxiety
upon yourself alone.
subQuotationList: ['Your attendance upon her, has been too much for you. You do not look\nwell. Oh! that I had been with you, you have had every care and anxiety\nupon yourself alone.']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
Mary and Kitty have been very kind, and would have shared in every
fatigue, I am sure, but I did not think it right for either of them.
Kitty is slight and delicate, and Mary studies so much, that her hours
of repose should not be broken in on. My aunt Philips came to Longbourn
on Tuesday, after my father went away; and was so good as to stay till
Thursday with me. She was of great use and comfort to us all, and lady
Lucas has been very kind; she walked here on Wednesday morning to
condole with us, and offered her services, or any of her daughters, if
they could be of use to us.
subQuotationList:
['Mary and Kitty have been very kind, and would have shared in every
fatigue, I am sure, but I did not think it right for either of them.
Kitty is slight and delicate, and Mary studies so much, that her hours
of repose should not be broken in on. My aunt Philips came to Longbourn
on Tuesday, after my father went away; and was so good as to stay till
Thursday with me. She was of great use and comfort to us all, and lady
Lucas has been very kind; she walked here on Wednesday morning to
condole with us, and offered her services, or any of her daughters, if
they could be of use to us.']
speaker: Jane
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mary'], ['Kitty'], ['Mary', 'Kitty'], ['Kitty'], ['Mary'], ['Mary'], ['Mr. Bennet'], ['Mary', 'Mrs. Bennet', 'Kitty'], ['Lady Lucas'], ['Lady Lucas'], ['Mary', 'Mrs. Bennet', 'Kitty'], ['Lady Lucas'], ['Lady Lucas'], ['Charlotte Lucas'], ['Charlotte Lucas'], ['Mary', 'Mrs. Bennet', 'Kitty']]]

quoteText:
She had better have stayed at home, perhaps she
_meant_ well, but, under such a misfortune as this, one cannot see too
little of one's neighbours. Assistance is impossible; condolence,
insufferable. Let them triumph over us at a distance, and be satisfied.
subQuotationList:
['She had better have stayed at home,', "perhaps she
_meant_ well, but, under such a misfortune as this, one cannot see too
little of one's neighbours. Assistance is impossible; condolence,
insufferable. Let them triumph over us at a distance, and be satisfied."]
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
He meant, I believe, to go to Epsom, the place where
they last changed horses, see the postilions, and try if any thing could
be made out from them. His principal object must be, to discover the
number of the hackney coach which took them from Clapham. It had come
with a fare from London; and as he thought the circumstance of a
gentleman and lady's removing from one carriage into another, might be
remarked, he meant to make enquiries at Clapham. If he could any how
discover at what house the coachman had before set down his fare, he
determined to make enquiries there, and hoped it might not be impossible
to find out the stand and number of the coach. I do not know of any
other designs that he had formed: but he was in such a hurry to be gone,
and his spirits so greatly discomposed, that I had difficulty in finding
out even so much as this.
subQuotationList:
['He meant, I believe,', "to go to Epsom, the place where
they last changed horses, see the postilions, and try if any thing could
be made out from them. His principal object must be, to discover the
number of the hackney coach which took them from Clapham. It had come
with a fare from London; and as he thought the circumstance of a
gentleman and lady's removing from one carriage into another, might be
remarked, he meant to make enquiries at Clapham. If he could any how
discover at what house the coachman had before set down his fare, he
determined to make enquiries there, and hoped it might not be impossible
to find out the stand and number of the coach. I do not know of any
other designs that he had formed: but he was in such a hurry to be gone,
and his spirits so greatly discomposed, that I had difficulty in finding
out even so much as this."]
speaker: Jane
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. Bennet']], [['George Wickham', 'Lydia'], ['Mr. Bennet'], ['George Wickham', 'Lydia'], ['Mr. Bennet'], ['Mr. Bennet'], ['Mr. Bennet'], ['Mr. Bennet'], ['Mr. Bennet'], ['Mr. Bennet'], ['Mr. Bennet'], ['Mr. Bennet']]]

quoteText:
A gamester! This is
wholly unexpected. I had not an idea of it.
subQuotationList: ['A gamester!', 'This is\nwholly unexpected. I had not an idea of it.']
speaker: Jane

quoteText:
What, is he coming home, and without poor Lydia! Sure he
will not leave London before he has found them. Who is to fight Wickham,
and make him marry her, if he comes away?
subQuotationList: ['What, is he coming home, and without poor Lydia!', 'Sure he\nwill not leave London before he has found them. Who is to fight Wickham,\nand make him marry her, if he comes away?']
speaker: Mrs. Bennet
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. Bennet'], ['Lydia']], [['Mr. Bennet'], ['Mr. Bennet'], ['George Wickham', 'Lydia'], ['George Wickham'], ['George Wickham'], ['Lydia'], ['Mr. Bennet']]]

quoteText:
Say
nothing of that. Who should suffer but myself? It has been my own doing,
and I ought to feel it.
subQuotationList: ['Say\nnothing of that. Who should suffer but myself? It has been my own doing,\nand I ought to feel it.']
speaker: Mr. Bennet

quoteText: You must not be too severe upon yourself,
subQuotationList: ['You must not be too severe upon yourself,']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
You may well warn me against such an evil. Human nature is so prone to
fall into it! No, Lizzy, let me once in my life feel how much I have
been to blame. I am not afraid of being overpowered by the impression.
It will pass away soon enough.
subQuotationList:
['You may well warn me against such an evil. Human nature is so prone to
fall into it! No, Lizzy, let me once in my life feel how much I have
been to blame. I am not afraid of being overpowered by the impression.
It will pass away soon enough.']
speaker: Mr. Bennet

quoteText: Do you suppose them to be in London?
subQuotationList: ['Do you suppose them to be in London?']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText: Yes; where else can they be so well concealed?
subQuotationList: ['Yes; where else can they be so well concealed?']
speaker: Mr. Bennet

quoteText: And Lydia used to want to go to London,
subQuotationList: ['And Lydia used to want to go to London,']
speaker: Kitty

quoteText:
She is happy, then, and her residence there
will probably be of some duration.
subQuotationList: ['She is happy, then,', 'and her residence there\nwill probably be of some duration.']
speaker: Mr. Bennet

quoteText:
Lizzy, I bear you no
ill-will for being justified in your advice to me last May, which,
considering the event, shews some greatness of mind.
subQuotationList: ['Lizzy, I bear you no\nill-will for being justified in your advice to me last May, which,\nconsidering the event, shews some greatness of mind.']
speaker: Mr. Bennet

quoteText:
This is a parade, which does one good; it gives such an
elegance to misfortune! Another day I will do the same; I will sit in
my library, in my night cap and powdering gown, and give as much trouble
as I can,--or, perhaps, I may defer it, till Kitty runs away.
subQuotationList:
['This is a parade,', 'which does one good; it gives such an
elegance to misfortune! Another day I will do the same; I will sit in
my library, in my night cap and powdering gown, and give as much trouble
as I can,--or, perhaps, I may defer it, till Kitty runs away.']
speaker: Mr. Bennet

quoteText:
I am not going to run away, Papa, if _I_
should ever go to Brighton, I would behave better than Lydia.
subQuotationList: ['I am not going to run away, Papa,', 'if _I_\nshould ever go to Brighton, I would behave better than Lydia.']
speaker: Kitty

quoteText:
_You_ go to Brighton!--I would not trust you so near it as East Bourne
for fifty pounds! No, Kitty, I have at last learnt to be cautious, and
you will feel the effects of it. No officer is ever to enter my house
again, nor even to pass through the village. Balls will be absolutely
prohibited, unless you stand up with one of your sisters. And you are
never to stir out of doors, till you can prove, that you have spent ten
minutes of every day in a rational manner.
subQuotationList:
['_You_ go to Brighton!--I would not trust you so near it as East Bourne
for fifty pounds! No, Kitty, I have at last learnt to be cautious, and
you will feel the effects of it. No officer is ever to enter my house
again, nor even to pass through the village. Balls will be absolutely
prohibited, unless you stand up with one of your sisters. And you are
never to stir out of doors, till you can prove, that you have spent ten
minutes of every day in a rational manner.']
speaker: Mr. Bennet

quoteText:
Well, well, do not make yourself unhappy. If you are a good
girl for the next ten years, I will take you to a review at the end of
them.
subQuotationList: ['Well, well,', 'do not make yourself unhappy. If you are a good\ngirl for the next ten years, I will take you to a review at the end of\nthem.']
speaker: Mr. Bennet

quoteText:
I beg your pardon,
madam, for interrupting you, but I was in hopes you might have got some
good news from town, so I took the liberty of coming to ask.
subQuotationList: ['I beg your pardon,\nmadam, for interrupting you, but I was in hopes you might have got some\ngood news from town, so I took the liberty of coming to ask.']
speaker: Mrs. Hill

quoteText: What do you mean, Hill? We have heard nothing from town.
subQuotationList: ['What do you mean, Hill? We have heard nothing from town.']
speaker: Jane

quoteText:
Dear madam, don't you know
there is an express come for master from Mr. Gardiner? He has been here
this half hour, and master has had a letter.
subQuotationList: ['Dear madam,', "don't you know\nthere is an express come for master from Mr. Gardiner? He has been here\nthis half hour, and master has had a letter."]
speaker: Mrs. Hill

quoteText:
If you are looking for my master, ma'am, he is walking towards the
little copse.
subQuotationList: ["If you are looking for my master, ma'am, he is walking towards the\nlittle copse."]
speaker: Butler

quoteText: Oh, Papa, what news? what news? have you heard from my uncle?
subQuotationList: ['Oh, Papa, what news? what news? have you heard from my uncle?']
speaker: Elizabeth
referringExpression: her sister panting for breath came up with him and eagerly cried out

quoteText: Yes, I have had a letter from him by express.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, I have had a letter from him by express.']
speaker: Mr. Bennet

quoteText: Well, and what news does it bring? good or bad?
subQuotationList: ['Well, and what news does it bring? good or bad?']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText: What is there of good to be expected? but perhaps you would like to read it.
subQuotationList: ['What is there of good to be expected?', 'but perhaps you would like to read it.']
speaker: Mr. Bennet

quoteText:
Read it aloud, for I hardly know myself what it is
about.
subQuotationList: ['Read it aloud,', 'for I hardly know myself what it is\nabout.']
speaker: Mr. Bennet

quoteText: Then it is, as I always hoped, they are married!
subQuotationList: ['Then it is, as I always hoped,', 'they are married!']
speaker: Jane

quoteText:
Is it possible! Can it be
possible that he will marry her?
subQuotationList: ['Is it possible!', 'Can it be\npossible that he will marry her?']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText: Wickham is not so undeserving, then, as we have thought him; My dear father, I congratulate you.
subQuotationList: ['Wickham is not so undeserving, then, as we have thought him;', 'My dear father, I congratulate you.']
speaker: Jane
mentionEntitiesList: [[['George Wickham'], ['Elizabeth', 'Mrs. Gardiner', 'Mr. Gardiner', 'Jane', 'Mrs. Bennet', 'Mary', 'Mr. Bennet', 'Kitty'], ['George Wickham']], [['Mr. Bennet'], ['Mr. Bennet']]]

quoteText: And have you answered the letter?
subQuotationList: ['And have you answered the letter?']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText: No; but it must be done soon.
subQuotationList: ['No; but it must be done soon.']
speaker: Mr. Bennet

quoteText:
Oh! my dear father, come back, and write immediately.
Consider how important every moment is, in such a case.
subQuotationList: ['Oh! my dear father,', 'come back, and write immediately.\nConsider how important every moment is, in such a case.']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
Let me write for you, if you dislike the trouble
yourself.
subQuotationList: ['Let me write for you,', 'if you dislike the trouble\nyourself.']
speaker: Jane

quoteText: I dislike it very much, but it must be done.
subQuotationList: ['I dislike it very much,', 'but it must be done.']
speaker: Mr. Bennet

quoteText:
And may I ask? but the terms, I suppose, must be
complied with.
subQuotationList: ['And may I ask?', 'but the terms, I suppose, must be\ncomplied with.']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText: Complied with! I am only ashamed of his asking so little.
subQuotationList: ['Complied with! I am only ashamed of his asking so little.']
speaker: Mr. Bennet

quoteText: And they _must_ marry! Yet he is _such_ a man!
subQuotationList: ['And they _must_ marry! Yet he is _such_ a man!']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
Yes, yes, they must marry. There is nothing else to be done. But there
are two things that I want very much to know:--one is, how much money
your uncle has laid down, to bring it about; and the other, how I am
ever to pay him.
subQuotationList:
['Yes, yes, they must marry. There is nothing else to be done. But there
are two things that I want very much to know:--one is, how much money
your uncle has laid down, to bring it about; and the other, how I am
ever to pay him.']
speaker: Mr. Bennet

quoteText: Money! my uncle! what do you mean, Sir?
subQuotationList: ['Money! my uncle!', 'what do you mean, Sir?']
speaker: Jane

quoteText:
I mean, that no man in his senses, would marry Lydia on so slight a
temptation as one hundred a-year during my life, and fifty after I am
gone.
subQuotationList: ['I mean, that no man in his senses, would marry Lydia on so slight a\ntemptation as one hundred a-year during my life, and fifty after I am\ngone.']
speaker: Mr. Bennet

quoteText:
That is very true, though it had not occurred to me
before. His debts to be discharged, and something still to remain! Oh!
it must be my uncle's doings! Generous, good man, I am afraid he has
distressed himself. A small sum could not do all this.
subQuotationList:
['That is very true,', "though it had not occurred to me
before. His debts to be discharged, and something still to remain! Oh!
it must be my uncle's doings! Generous, good man, I am afraid he has
distressed himself. A small sum could not do all this."]
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
No, Wickham's a fool, if he takes her with a
farthing less than ten thousand pounds. I should be sorry to think so
ill of him, in the very beginning of our relationship.
subQuotationList: ['No,', "Wickham's a fool, if he takes her with a\nfarthing less than ten thousand pounds. I should be sorry to think so\nill of him, in the very beginning of our relationship."]
speaker: Mr. Bennet

quoteText:
Ten thousand pounds! Heaven forbid! How is half such a sum to be
repaid?
subQuotationList: ['Ten thousand pounds! Heaven forbid! How is half such a sum to be\nrepaid?']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
And they are really to be married! How strange this is! And for _this_ we are to be
thankful. That they should marry, small as is their chance of happiness,
and wretched as is his character, we are forced to rejoice! Oh, Lydia!
subQuotationList: ['And they are really to be married!', 'How strange this is! And for _this_ we are to be\nthankful. That they should marry, small as is their chance of happiness,\nand wretched as is his character, we are forced to rejoice! Oh, Lydia!']
speaker: Elizabeth
mentionEntitiesList: [[['George Wickham', 'Lydia']], [['Elizabeth', 'Mrs. Gardiner', 'Mr. Gardiner', 'Jane', 'Mrs. Bennet', 'Mary', 'Mr. Bennet', 'Kitty'], ['George Wickham', 'Lydia'], ['George Wickham', 'Lydia'], ['George Wickham'], ['Mary', 'Elizabeth', 'Mrs. Bennet', 'Kitty', 'Mr. Bennet'], ['Lydia']]]

quoteText:
I comfort myself with thinking, that he certainly would
not marry Lydia, if he had not a real regard for her. Though our kind
uncle has done something towards clearing him, I cannot believe that ten
thousand pounds, or any thing like it, has been advanced. He has
children of his own, and may have more. How could he spare half ten
thousand pounds?
subQuotationList:
['I comfort myself with thinking,', 'that he certainly would
not marry Lydia, if he had not a real regard for her. Though our kind
uncle has done something towards clearing him, I cannot believe that ten
thousand pounds, or any thing like it, has been advanced. He has
children of his own, and may have more. How could he spare half ten
thousand pounds?']
speaker: Jane
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['George Wickham'], ['Lydia'], ['George Wickham'], ['Lydia'], ['Mr. Gardiner'], ['George Wickham'], ['Mr. Gardiner'], ['Mr. Gardiner'], ['Mr. Gardiner']]]

quoteText:
If we are ever able to learn what Wickham's debts have been, and how much is settled on his side on our sister, we shall
exactly know what Mr. Gardiner has done for them, because Wickham has
not sixpence of his own. The kindness of my uncle and aunt can never be
requited. Their taking her home, and affording her their personal
protection and countenance, is such a sacrifice to her advantage, as
years of gratitude cannot enough acknowledge. By this time she is
actually with them! If such goodness does not make her miserable now,
she will never deserve to be happy! What a meeting for her, when she
first sees my aunt!
subQuotationList:
["If we are ever able to learn what Wickham's debts have been,", 'and how much is settled on his side on our sister, we shall
exactly know what Mr. Gardiner has done for them, because Wickham has
not sixpence of his own. The kindness of my uncle and aunt can never be
requited. Their taking her home, and affording her their personal
protection and countenance, is such a sacrifice to her advantage, as
years of gratitude cannot enough acknowledge. By this time she is
actually with them! If such goodness does not make her miserable now,
she will never deserve to be happy! What a meeting for her, when she
first sees my aunt!']
speaker: Elizabeth
mentionTextsList: [['we', 'Wickham'], ['his', 'our sister', 'we', 'Mr. Gardiner', 'them', 'Wickham', 'his', 'my uncle and aunt', 'aunt ', 'her', 'her', 'her', 'she', 'them', 'her', 'she ', 'her', 'she', 'my aunt']]
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Elizabeth', 'Jane'], ['George Wickham']], [['George Wickham'], ['Lydia'], ['Elizabeth', 'Jane'], ['Mr. Gardiner'], ['George Wickham', 'Lydia'], ['George Wickham'], ['George Wickham'], ['Mr. Gardiner'], ['Mrs. Gardiner'], ['Lydia'], ['Lydia'], ['Lydia'], ['Lydia'], ['Mrs. Gardiner', 'Mr. Gardiner'], ['Lydia'], ['Lydia'], ['Lydia'], ['Lydia'], ['Mrs. Gardiner']]]

quoteText:
We must endeavour to forget all that has passed on either side, I hope and trust they will yet be happy. His consenting to marry
her is a proof, I will believe, that he is come to a right way of
thinking. Their mutual affection will steady them; and I flatter myself
they will settle so quietly, and live in so rational a manner, as may in
time make their past imprudence forgotten.
subQuotationList:
['We must endeavour to forget all that has passed on either side,', 'I hope and trust they will yet be happy. His consenting to marry
her is a proof, I will believe, that he is come to a right way of
thinking. Their mutual affection will steady them; and I flatter myself
they will settle so quietly, and live in so rational a manner, as may in
time make their past imprudence forgotten.']
speaker: Jane
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Elizabeth', 'Jane', 'Mr. Bennet']], [['George Wickham', 'Lydia'], ['George Wickham'], ['Lydia'], ['George Wickham'], ['George Wickham', 'Lydia'], ['George Wickham', 'Lydia'], ['George Wickham', 'Lydia']]]

quoteText:
Their conduct has been such, as neither you, nor
I, nor any body, can ever forget. It is useless to talk of it.
subQuotationList: ['Their conduct has been such,', 'as neither you, nor\nI, nor any body, can ever forget. It is useless to talk of it.']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText: Just as you please.
subQuotationList: ['Just as you please.']
speaker: Mr. Bennet

quoteText: May we take my uncle's letter to read to her?
subQuotationList: ["May we take my uncle's letter to read to her?"]
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText: Take whatever you like, and get away.
subQuotationList: ['Take whatever you like, and get away.']
speaker: Mr. Bennet

quoteText:
My dear, dear Lydia! This is delightful indeed!--She will
be married!--I shall see her again!--She will be married at sixteen!--My
good, kind brother!--I knew how it would be--I knew he would manage
every thing. How I long to see her! and to see dear Wickham too! But the
clothes, the wedding clothes! I will write to my sister Gardiner about
them directly. Lizzy, my dear, run down to your father, and ask him how
much he will give her. Stay, stay, I will go myself. Ring the bell,
Kitty, for Hill. I will put on my things in a moment. My dear, dear
Lydia!--How merry we shall be together when we meet!
