subQuotationList:
['My dear, dear Lydia!', 'This is delightful indeed!--She will
be married!--I shall see her again!--She will be married at sixteen!--My
good, kind brother!--I knew how it would be--I knew he would manage
every thing. How I long to see her! and to see dear Wickham too! But the
clothes, the wedding clothes! I will write to my sister Gardiner about
them directly. Lizzy, my dear, run down to your father, and ask him how
much he will give her. Stay, stay, I will go myself. Ring the bell,
Kitty, for Hill. I will put on my things in a moment. My dear, dear
Lydia!--How merry we shall be together when we meet!']
speaker: Mrs. Bennet
mentionTextsList: [['My dear, dear Lydia'], ['She', 'her', 'She', 'My\ngood, kind brother', 'he', 'her', 'dear Wickham', 'my sister Gardiner', 'Lizzy', 'my dear', 'your father', 'him', 'he', 'her', 'Kitty', 'Hill', 'My dear, dear\nLydia', 'we', 'we']]
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Lydia']], [['Lydia'], ['Lydia'], ['Lydia'], ['Mr. Gardiner'], ['Mr. Gardiner'], ['Lydia'], ['George Wickham'], ['Mrs. Gardiner'], ['Elizabeth'], ['Elizabeth'], ['Mr. Bennet'], ['Mr. Bennet'], ['Mr. Bennet'], ['Lydia'], ['Kitty'], ['Mrs. Hill'], ['Lydia'], ['Mrs. Bennet'], ['Mrs. Bennet']]]

quoteText:
For we must attribute this happy conclusion, in a great
measure, to his kindness. We are persuaded that he has pledged himself
to assist Mr. Wickham with money.
subQuotationList: ['For we must attribute this happy conclusion,', 'in a great\nmeasure, to his kindness. We are persuaded that he has pledged himself\nto assist Mr. Wickham with money.']
speaker: Jane

quoteText:
Well, it is all very right; who should do it but
her own uncle? If he had not had a family of his own, I and my children
must have had all his money you know, and it is the first time we have
ever had any thing from him, except a few presents. Well! I am so happy.
In a short time, I shall have a daughter married. Mrs. Wickham! How well
it sounds. And she was only sixteen last June. My dear Jane, I am in
such a flutter, that I am sure I can't write; so I will dictate, and you
write for me. We will settle with your father about the money
afterwards; but the things should be ordered immediately.
subQuotationList:
['Well,', "it is all very right; who should do it but
her own uncle? If he had not had a family of his own, I and my children
must have had all his money you know, and it is the first time we have
ever had any thing from him, except a few presents. Well! I am so happy.
In a short time, I shall have a daughter married. Mrs. Wickham! How well
it sounds. And she was only sixteen last June. My dear Jane, I am in
such a flutter, that I am sure I can't write; so I will dictate, and you
write for me. We will settle with your father about the money
afterwards; but the things should be ordered immediately."]
speaker: Mrs. Bennet
mentionTextsList: [[], ['my children', 'you', 'we', 'him', 'a daughter married', 'Mrs. Wickham', 'she', 'My dear Jane', 'you', 'We', 'your father']]

quoteText:
I will go to Meryton, as soon as I am dressed, and tell the
good, good news to my sister Philips. And as I come back, I can call on
Lady Lucas and Mrs. Long. Kitty, run down and order the carriage. An
airing would do me a great deal of good, I am sure. Girls, can I do any
thing for you in Meryton? Oh! here comes Hill. My dear Hill, have you
heard the good news? Miss Lydia is going to be married; and you shall
all have a bowl of punch, to make merry at her wedding.
subQuotationList:
['I will go to Meryton,', 'as soon as I am dressed, and tell the
good, good news to my sister Philips. And as I come back, I can call on
Lady Lucas and Mrs. Long. Kitty, run down and order the carriage. An
airing would do me a great deal of good, I am sure. Girls, can I do any
thing for you in Meryton? Oh! here comes Hill. My dear Hill, have you
heard the good news? Miss Lydia is going to be married; and you shall
all have a bowl of punch, to make merry at her wedding.']
speaker: Mrs. Bennet
mentionTextsList: [[], ['my sister Philips', 'Lady Lucas', 'Mrs. Long', 'Kitty', 'Girls', 'you', 'Hill', 'My dear Hill', 'you', 'Miss Lydia', 'her']]
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Mrs. Philips'], ['Lady Lucas'], ['Mrs. Long'], ['Kitty'], ['Mary', 'Elizabeth', 'Kitty', 'Jane'], ['Mary', 'Elizabeth', 'Kitty', 'Jane'], ['Mrs. Hill'], ['Mrs. Hill'], ['Mrs. Hill'], ['Lydia'], ['Lydia']]]

quoteText:
Haye-Park might do, if the Gouldings would quit it, or the
great house at Stoke, if the drawing-room were larger; but Ashworth is
too far off! I could not bear to have her ten miles from me; and as for
Purvis Lodge, the attics are dreadful.
subQuotationList:
['Haye-Park might do,', 'if the Gouldings would quit it, or the
great house at Stoke, if the drawing-room were larger; but Ashworth is
too far off! I could not bear to have her ten miles from me; and as for
Purvis Lodge, the attics are dreadful.']
speaker: Mrs. Bennet

quoteText:
Mrs.
Bennet, before you take any, or all of these houses, for your son and
daughter, let us come to a right understanding. Into _one_ house in this
neighbourhood, they shall never have admittance. I will not encourage
the impudence of either, by receiving them at Longbourn.
subQuotationList:
['Mrs.
Bennet, before you take any, or all of these houses, for your son and
daughter, let us come to a right understanding. Into _one_ house in this
neighbourhood, they shall never have admittance. I will not encourage
the impudence of either, by receiving them at Longbourn.']
speaker: Mr. Bennet
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mrs. Bennet'], ['Mrs. Bennet'], ['George Wickham', 'Lydia'], ['Mr. Bennet', 'Mrs. Bennet'], ['George Wickham', 'Lydia'], ['George Wickham', 'Lydia']]]

quoteText:
She is so fond of Mrs. Forster, it will be quite shocking
to send her away! And there are several of the young men, too, that she
likes very much. The officers may not be so pleasant in General ----'s
regiment.
subQuotationList:
['She is so fond of Mrs. Forster,', "it will be quite shocking
to send her away! And there are several of the young men, too, that she
likes very much. The officers may not be so pleasant in General ----'s
regiment."]
speaker: Mrs. Bennet

quoteText:
Only think of its being three months, since I went away;
it seems but a fortnight I declare; and yet there have been things
enough happened in the time. Good gracious! when I went away, I am sure
I had no more idea of being married till I came back again! though I
thought it would be very good fun if I was.
subQuotationList:
['Only think of its being three months,', 'since I went away;
it seems but a fortnight I declare; and yet there have been things
enough happened in the time. Good gracious! when I went away, I am sure
I had no more idea of being married till I came back again! though I
thought it would be very good fun if I was.']
speaker: Lydia

quoteText:
Oh! mamma, do the
people here abouts know I am married to-day? I was afraid they might
not; and we overtook William Goulding in his curricle, so I was
determined he should know it, and so I let down the side glass next to
him, and took off my glove, and let my hand just rest upon the window
frame, so that he might see the ring, and then I bowed and smiled like
any thing.
subQuotationList:
['Oh! mamma, do the
people here abouts know I am married to-day? I was afraid they might
not; and we overtook William Goulding in his curricle, so I was
determined he should know it, and so I let down the side glass next to
him, and took off my glove, and let my hand just rest upon the window
frame, so that he might see the ring, and then I bowed and smiled like
any thing.']
speaker: Lydia
referringExpression: she who never heard nor saw any thing of which she chose to be insensible gaily continued
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mrs. Bennet'], ['Lydia', 'George Wickham'], ['William Goulding'], ['William Goulding'], ['William Goulding'], ['Mr. Goulding'], ['William Goulding']]]

quoteText:
Ah! Jane, I take your place now, and you must go
lower, because I am a married woman.
subQuotationList: ['Ah! Jane, I take your place now, and you must go\nlower, because I am a married woman.']
speaker: Lydia

quoteText:
Well, mamma, and what do you think of my husband? Is not he a charming man? I
am sure my sisters must all envy me. I only hope they may have half my
good luck. They must all go to Brighton. That is the place to get
husbands. What a pity it is, mamma, we did not all go.
subQuotationList:
['Well, mamma,', 'and what do you think of my husband? Is not he a charming man? I
am sure my sisters must all envy me. I only hope they may have half my
good luck. They must all go to Brighton. That is the place to get
husbands. What a pity it is, mamma, we did not all go.']
speaker: Lydia
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mrs. Bennet']], [['Mrs. Bennet'], ['George Wickham'], ['George Wickham'], ['Mary', 'Elizabeth', 'Kitty', 'Jane'], ['Mary', 'Elizabeth', 'Kitty', 'Jane'], ['Mary', 'Elizabeth', 'Kitty', 'Jane'], ['Mrs. Bennet'], ['Mary', 'Elizabeth', 'Lydia', 'Mrs. Bennet', 'Kitty']]]

quoteText:
Very true; and if I had my will, we should. But my dear Lydia, I don't
at all like your going such a way off. Must it be so?
subQuotationList: ["Very true; and if I had my will, we should. But my dear Lydia, I don't\nat all like your going such a way off. Must it be so?"]
speaker: Mrs. Bennet

quoteText:
Oh, lord! yes;--there is nothing in that. I shall like it of all
things. You and papa, and my sisters, must come down and see us. We
shall be at Newcastle all the winter, and I dare say there will be some
balls, and I will take care to get good partners for them all.
subQuotationList:
['Oh, lord! yes;--there is nothing in that. I shall like it of all
things. You and papa, and my sisters, must come down and see us. We
shall be at Newcastle all the winter, and I dare say there will be some
balls, and I will take care to get good partners for them all.']
speaker: Lydia

quoteText: I should like it beyond any thing!
subQuotationList: ['I should like it beyond any thing!']
speaker: Mrs. Bennet

quoteText:
And then when you go away, you may leave one or two of my sisters
behind you; and I dare say I shall get husbands for them before the
winter is over.
subQuotationList: ['And then when you go away, you may leave one or two of my sisters\nbehind you; and I dare say I shall get husbands for them before the\nwinter is over.']
speaker: Lydia

quoteText:
I thank you for my share of the favour, but I do not
particularly like your way of getting husbands.
subQuotationList: ['I thank you for my share of the favour,', 'but I do not\nparticularly like your way of getting husbands.']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
Lizzy, I never gave _you_ an account of my wedding, I believe. You were
not by, when I told mamma, and the others, all about it. Are not you
curious to hear how it was managed?
subQuotationList: ['Lizzy, I never gave _you_ an account of my wedding, I believe. You were\nnot by, when I told mamma, and the others, all about it. Are not you\ncurious to hear how it was managed?']
speaker: Lydia

quoteText:
No really, I think there cannot be too little said
on the subject.
subQuotationList: ['No really,', 'I think there cannot be too little said\non the subject.']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
La! You are so strange! But I must tell you how it went off. We were
married, you know, at St. Clement's, because Wickham's lodgings were in
that parish. And it was settled that we should all be there by eleven
o'clock. My uncle and aunt and I were to go together; and the others
were to meet us at the church. Well, Monday morning came, and I was in
such a fuss! I was so afraid you know that something would happen to put
it off, and then I should have gone quite distracted. And there was my
aunt, all the time I was dressing, preaching and talking away just as if
she was reading a sermon. However, I did not hear above one word in ten,
for I was thinking, you may suppose, of my dear Wickham. I longed to
know whether he would be married in his blue coat.
subQuotationList:
["La! You are so strange! But I must tell you how it went off. We were
married, you know, at St. Clement's, because Wickham's lodgings were in
that parish. And it was settled that we should all be there by eleven
o'clock. My uncle and aunt and I were to go together; and the others
were to meet us at the church. Well, Monday morning came, and I was in
such a fuss! I was so afraid you know that something would happen to put
it off, and then I should have gone quite distracted. And there was my
aunt, all the time I was dressing, preaching and talking away just as if
she was reading a sermon. However, I did not hear above one word in ten,
for I was thinking, you may suppose, of my dear Wickham. I longed to
know whether he would be married in his blue coat."]
speaker: Lydia
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Elizabeth'], ['Elizabeth'], ['George Wickham', 'Lydia'], ['Elizabeth'], ['George Wickham'], ['George Wickham', 'Lydia'], ['Mr. Gardiner'], ['Mrs. Gardiner'], ['Mrs. Gardiner', 'Mr. Gardiner', 'Lydia'], ['Elizabeth'], ['Mrs. Gardiner'], ['Mrs. Gardiner'], ['Elizabeth'], ['George Wickham'], ['George Wickham'], ['George Wickham']]]

quoteText:
Well, and so we breakfasted at ten as usual; I thought it would never
be over; for, by the bye, you are to understand, that my uncle and aunt
were horrid unpleasant all the time I was with them. If you'll believe
me, I did not once put my foot out of doors, though I was there a
fortnight. Not one party, or scheme, or any thing. To be sure London was
rather thin, but however the little Theatre was open. Well, and so just
as the carriage came to the door, my uncle was called away upon business
to that horrid man Mr. Stone. And then, you know, when once they get
together, there is no end of it. Well, I was so frightened I did not
know what to do, for my uncle was to give me away; and if we were beyond
the hour, we could not be married all day. But, luckily, he came back
again in ten minutes time, and then we all set out. However, I
recollected afterwards, that if he _had_ been prevented going, the
wedding need not be put off, for Mr. Darcy might have done as well.
subQuotationList:
["Well, and so we breakfasted at ten as usual; I thought it would never
be over; for, by the bye, you are to understand, that my uncle and aunt
were horrid unpleasant all the time I was with them. If you'll believe
me, I did not once put my foot out of doors, though I was there a
fortnight. Not one party, or scheme, or any thing. To be sure London was
rather thin, but however the little Theatre was open. Well, and so just
as the carriage came to the door, my uncle was called away upon business
to that horrid man Mr. Stone. And then, you know, when once they get
together, there is no end of it. Well, I was so frightened I did not
know what to do, for my uncle was to give me away; and if we were beyond
the hour, we could not be married all day. But, luckily, he came back
again in ten minutes time, and then we all set out. However, I
recollected afterwards, that if he _had_ been prevented going, the
wedding need not be put off, for Mr. Darcy might have done as well."]
speaker: Lydia
mentionTextsList: [['we', 'my uncle and aunt', 'aunt', 'them', 'you', 'my uncle', 'Mr. Stone', 'you', 'they', ' my uncle', 'we', 'we ', 'he', 'we', 'he', 'Mr. Darcy']]
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mrs. Gardiner', 'Mr. Gardiner', 'Lydia'], ['Mr. Gardiner'], ['Mrs. Gardiner'], ['Mrs. Gardiner', 'Mr. Gardiner'], ['Elizabeth'], ['Mr. Gardiner'], ['Mr. Stone'], ['Elizabeth'], ['Mr. Gardiner', 'Mr. Stone'], ['Mr. Gardiner'], ['Mrs. Gardiner', 'Mr. Gardiner', 'Lydia'], ['George Wickham', 'Lydia'], ['Mr. Gardiner'], ['Mrs. Gardiner', 'Mr. Gardiner', 'Lydia'], ['Mr. Gardiner'], ['Mr. Darcy']]]

quoteText: Mr. Darcy!
subQuotationList: ['Mr. Darcy!']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
Oh, yes!--he was to come there with Wickham, you know. But gracious me!
I quite forgot! I ought not to have said a word about it. I promised
them so faithfully! What will Wickham say? It was to be such a secret!
subQuotationList: ['Oh, yes!--he was to come there with Wickham, you know. But gracious me!\nI quite forgot! I ought not to have said a word about it. I promised\nthem so faithfully! What will Wickham say? It was to be such a secret!']
speaker: Lydia

quoteText:
If it was to be secret, say not another word on the
subject. You may depend upon my seeking no further.
subQuotationList: ['If it was to be secret,', 'say not another word on the\nsubject. You may depend upon my seeking no further.']
speaker: Jane

quoteText:
Oh! certainly, we will
ask you no questions.
subQuotationList: ['Oh! certainly,', 'we will\nask you no questions.']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
Thank you, for if you did, I should certainly tell you
all, and then Wickham would be angry.
subQuotationList: ['Thank you,', 'for if you did, I should certainly tell you\nall, and then Wickham would be angry.']
speaker: Lydia

quoteText:
Not that I _shall_ though, and my dear aunt, if you do not tell me in an honourable
manner, I shall certainly be reduced to tricks and stratagems to find it
out.
subQuotationList: ['Not that I _shall_ though,', 'and my dear aunt, if you do not tell me in an honourable\nmanner, I shall certainly be reduced to tricks and stratagems to find it\nout.']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText: I am afraid I interrupt your solitary ramble, my dear sister?
subQuotationList: ['I am afraid I interrupt your solitary ramble, my dear sister?']
speaker: George Wickham

quoteText:
You certainly do, but it does not follow
that the interruption must be unwelcome.
subQuotationList: ['You certainly do,', 'but it does not follow\nthat the interruption must be unwelcome.']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
I should be sorry indeed, if it were. _We_ were always good friends;
and now we are better.
subQuotationList: ['I should be sorry indeed, if it were. _We_ were always good friends;\nand now we are better.']
speaker: George Wickham

quoteText: True. Are the others coming out?
subQuotationList: ['True. Are the others coming out?']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
I do not know. Mrs. Bennet and Lydia are going in the carriage to
Meryton. And so, my dear sister, I find from our uncle and aunt, that
you have actually seen Pemberley.
subQuotationList: ['I do not know. Mrs. Bennet and Lydia are going in the carriage to\nMeryton. And so, my dear sister, I find from our uncle and aunt, that\nyou have actually seen Pemberley.']
speaker: George Wickham
mentionTextsList: [['Mrs. Bennet', 'Lydia', 'my dear sister', 'our uncle and aunt', 'aunt', 'you ']]

quoteText:
I almost envy you the pleasure, and yet I believe it would be too much
for me, or else I could take it in my way to Newcastle. And you saw the
old housekeeper, I suppose? Poor Reynolds, she was always very fond of
me. But of course she did not mention my name to you.
subQuotationList:
['I almost envy you the pleasure, and yet I believe it would be too much
for me, or else I could take it in my way to Newcastle. And you saw the
old housekeeper, I suppose? Poor Reynolds, she was always very fond of
me. But of course she did not mention my name to you.']
speaker: George Wickham

quoteText: Yes, she did.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, she did.']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText: And what did she say?
subQuotationList: ['And what did she say?']
speaker: George Wickham

quoteText:
That you were gone into the army, and she was afraid had--not turned
out well. At such a distance as _that_, you know, things are strangely
misrepresented.
subQuotationList: ['That you were gone into the army, and she was afraid had--not turned\nout well. At such a distance as _that_, you know, things are strangely\nmisrepresented.']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText: Certainly,
subQuotationList: ['Certainly,']
speaker: George Wickham

quoteText:
I was surprised to see Darcy in town last month. We passed each other
several times. I wonder what he can be doing there.
subQuotationList: ['I was surprised to see Darcy in town last month. We passed each other\nseveral times. I wonder what he can be doing there.']
speaker: George Wickham

quoteText:
Perhaps preparing for his marriage with Miss de Bourgh, It must be something particular, to take him there at this
time of year.
subQuotationList: ['Perhaps preparing for his marriage with Miss de Bourgh,', 'It must be something particular, to take him there at this\ntime of year.']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
Undoubtedly. Did you see him while you were at Lambton? I thought I
understood from the Gardiners that you had.
subQuotationList: ['Undoubtedly. Did you see him while you were at Lambton? I thought I\nunderstood from the Gardiners that you had.']
speaker: George Wickham

quoteText: Yes; he introduced us to his sister.
subQuotationList: ['Yes; he introduced us to his sister.']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText: And do you like her?
subQuotationList: ['And do you like her?']
speaker: George Wickham

quoteText: Very much.
subQuotationList: ['Very much.']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
I have heard, indeed, that she is uncommonly improved within this year
or two. When I last saw her, she was not very promising. I am very glad
you liked her. I hope she will turn out well.
subQuotationList: ['I have heard, indeed, that she is uncommonly improved within this year\nor two. When I last saw her, she was not very promising. I am very glad\nyou liked her. I hope she will turn out well.']
speaker: George Wickham

quoteText: I dare say she will; she has got over the most trying age.
subQuotationList: ['I dare say she will; she has got over the most trying age.']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText: Did you go by the village of Kympton?
subQuotationList: ['Did you go by the village of Kympton?']
speaker: George Wickham

quoteText: I do not recollect that we did.
subQuotationList: ['I do not recollect that we did.']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
I mention it, because it is the living which I ought to have had. A
most delightful place!--Excellent Parsonage House! It would have suited
me in every respect.
subQuotationList: ['I mention it, because it is the living which I ought to have had. A\nmost delightful place!--Excellent Parsonage House! It would have suited\nme in every respect.']
speaker: George Wickham

quoteText: How should you have liked making sermons?
subQuotationList: ['How should you have liked making sermons?']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
Exceedingly well. I should have considered it as part of my duty, and
the exertion would soon have been nothing. One ought not to
repine;--but, to be sure, it would have been such a thing for me! The
quiet, the retirement of such a life, would have answered all my ideas
of happiness! But it was not to be. Did you ever hear Darcy mention the
circumstance, when you were in Kent?
subQuotationList:
['Exceedingly well. I should have considered it as part of my duty, and
the exertion would soon have been nothing. One ought not to
repine;--but, to be sure, it would have been such a thing for me! The
quiet, the retirement of such a life, would have answered all my ideas
of happiness! But it was not to be. Did you ever hear Darcy mention the
circumstance, when you were in Kent?']
speaker: George Wickham

quoteText:
I _have_ heard from authority, which I thought _as good_, that it was
left you conditionally only, and at the will of the present patron.
subQuotationList: ['I _have_ heard from authority, which I thought _as good_, that it was\nleft you conditionally only, and at the will of the present patron.']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
You have. Yes, there was something in _that_; I told you so from the
first, you may remember.
subQuotationList: ['You have. Yes, there was something in _that_; I told you so from the\nfirst, you may remember.']
speaker: George Wickham

quoteText:
I _did_ hear, too, that there was a time, when sermon-making was not so
palatable to you as it seems to be at present; that you actually
declared your resolution of never taking orders, and that the business
had been compromised accordingly.
subQuotationList:
['I _did_ hear, too, that there was a time, when sermon-making was not so
palatable to you as it seems to be at present; that you actually
declared your resolution of never taking orders, and that the business
had been compromised accordingly.']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
You did! and it was not wholly without foundation. You may remember
what I told you on that point, when first we talked of it.
subQuotationList: ['You did! and it was not wholly without foundation. You may remember\nwhat I told you on that point, when first we talked of it.']
speaker: George Wickham

quoteText:
Come, Mr. Wickham, we are brother and sister, you know. Do not let us
quarrel about the past. In future, I hope we shall be always of one
mind.
subQuotationList: ['Come, Mr. Wickham, we are brother and sister, you know. Do not let us\nquarrel about the past. In future, I hope we shall be always of one\nmind.']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText: Oh! my dear Lydia, when shall we meet again?
subQuotationList: ['Oh! my dear Lydia,', 'when shall we meet again?']
speaker: Mrs. Bennet

quoteText: Oh, lord! I don't know. Not these two or three years perhaps.
subQuotationList: ["Oh, lord! I don't know. Not these two or three years perhaps."]
speaker: Lydia

quoteText: Write to me very often, my dear.
subQuotationList: ['Write to me very often, my dear.']
speaker: Mrs. Bennet

quoteText:
As often as I can. But you know married women have never much time for
writing. My sisters may write to _me_. They will have nothing else to
do.
subQuotationList: ['As often as I can. But you know married women have never much time for\nwriting. My sisters may write to _me_. They will have nothing else to\ndo.']
speaker: Lydia

quoteText:
He is as fine a fellow, as ever I saw. He simpers, and smirks, and makes love to us
all. I am prodigiously proud of him. I defy even Sir William Lucas
himself, to produce a more valuable son-in-law.
subQuotationList: ['He is as fine a fellow,', 'as ever I saw. He simpers, and smirks, and makes love to us\nall. I am prodigiously proud of him. I defy even Sir William Lucas\nhimself, to produce a more valuable son-in-law.']
speaker: Mr. Bennet
mentionEntitiesList: [[['George Wickham']], [['George Wickham'], ['Elizabeth', 'Jane', 'Mrs. Bennet', 'Mary', 'Mr. Bennet', 'Kitty'], ['George Wickham'], ['Sir William Lucas'], ['Mr. Collins']]]

quoteText:
I often think, that there is nothing so bad as parting with
one's friends. One seems so forlorn without them.
subQuotationList: ['I often think,', "that there is nothing so bad as parting with\none's friends. One seems so forlorn without them."]
speaker: Mrs. Bennet

quoteText:
This is the consequence you see, Madam, of marrying a daughter, It must make you better satisfied that your other four are
single.
subQuotationList: ['This is the consequence you see, Madam, of marrying a daughter,', 'It must make you better satisfied that your other four are\nsingle.']
speaker: Elizabeth

subQuotationList: ["It is no such thing. Lydia does not leave me because she is married;\nbut only because her husband's regiment happens to be so far off. If\nthat had been nearer, she would not have gone so soon."]
speaker: Mrs. Bennet

quoteText: Well, well, and so Mr. Bingley is coming down, sister,
subQuotationList: ['Well, well, and so Mr. Bingley is coming down, sister,']
speaker: Mrs. Bennet

quoteText:
Well, so much the better. Not that
I care about it, though. He is nothing to us, you know, and I am sure
_I_ never want to see him again. But, however, he is very welcome to
come to Netherfield, if he likes it. And who knows what _may_ happen?
But that is nothing to us. You know, sister, we agreed long ago never to
mention a word about it. And so, is it quite certain he is coming?
subQuotationList:
['Well, so much the better. Not that
I care about it, though. He is nothing to us, you know, and I am sure
_I_ never want to see him again. But, however, he is very welcome to
come to Netherfield, if he likes it. And who knows what _may_ happen?
But that is nothing to us. You know, sister, we agreed long ago never to
mention a word about it. And so, is it quite certain he is coming?']
speaker: Mrs. Bennet

quoteText:
You may depend on it, for Mrs. Nicholls was in
Meryton last night; I saw her passing by, and went out myself on purpose
to know the truth of it; and she told me that it was certain true. He
comes down on Thursday at the latest, very likely on Wednesday. She was
going to the butcher's, she told me, on purpose to order in some meat on
Wednesday, and she has got three couple of ducks, just fit to be
killed.
subQuotationList:
['You may depend on it,', "for Mrs. Nicholls was in
Meryton last night; I saw her passing by, and went out myself on purpose
to know the truth of it; and she told me that it was certain true. He
comes down on Thursday at the latest, very likely on Wednesday. She was
going to the butcher's, she told me, on purpose to order in some meat on
Wednesday, and she has got three couple of ducks, just fit to be
killed."]
speaker: Mrs. Philips
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Mrs. Nicholls'], ['Mrs. Nicholls'], ['Mrs. Nicholls'], ['Mr. Bingley'], ['Mrs. Nicholls'], ['Mrs. Nicholls'], ['Mrs. Nicholls']]]

quoteText:
I saw you look at me to-day, Lizzy, when my aunt told us of the present
report; and I know I appeared distressed. But don't imagine it was from
any silly cause. I was only confused for the moment, because I felt
that I _should_ be looked at. I do assure you, that the news does not
affect me either with pleasure or pain. I am glad of one thing, that he
comes alone; because we shall see the less of him. Not that I am afraid
of _myself_, but I dread other people's remarks.
subQuotationList:
["I saw you look at me to-day, Lizzy, when my aunt told us of the present
report; and I know I appeared distressed. But don't imagine it was from
any silly cause. I was only confused for the moment, because I felt
that I _should_ be looked at. I do assure you, that the news does not
affect me either with pleasure or pain. I am glad of one thing, that he
comes alone; because we shall see the less of him. Not that I am afraid
of _myself_, but I dread other people's remarks."]
speaker: Jane

quoteText:
Yet it is hard, that this poor man cannot come
to a house, which he has legally hired, without raising all this
speculation! I _will_ leave him to himself.
subQuotationList: ['Yet it is hard,', 'that this poor man cannot come\nto a house, which he has legally hired, without raising all this\nspeculation! I _will_ leave him to himself.']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
As soon as ever Mr. Bingley comes, my dear, you
will wait on him of course.
subQuotationList: ['As soon as ever Mr. Bingley comes, my dear,', 'you\nwill wait on him of course.']
speaker: Mrs. Bennet

quoteText:
No, no. You forced me into visiting him last year, and promised if I
went to see him, he should marry one of my daughters. But it ended in
nothing, and I will not be sent on a fool's errand again.
subQuotationList: ["No, no. You forced me into visiting him last year, and promised if I\nwent to see him, he should marry one of my daughters. But it ended in\nnothing, and I will not be sent on a fool's errand again."]
speaker: Mr. Bennet

quoteText:
'Tis an etiquette I despise, If he wants our society, let
him seek it. He knows where we live. I will not spend _my_ hours in
running after my neighbours every time they go away, and come back
again.
subQuotationList:
["'Tis an etiquette I despise,", 'If he wants our society, let
him seek it. He knows where we live. I will not spend _my_ hours in
running after my neighbours every time they go away, and come back
again.']
speaker: Mr. Bennet
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Mr. Bingley'], ['Elizabeth', 'Jane', 'Mrs. Bennet', 'Mary', 'Mr. Bennet', 'Kitty'], ['Mr. Bingley'], ['Mr. Bingley'], ['Mr. Bennet', 'Mrs. Bennet']]]

quoteText:
Well, all I know is, that it will be abominably rude if you do not
wait on him. But, however, that shan't prevent my asking him to dine
here, I am determined. We must have Mrs. Long and the Gouldings soon.
That will make thirteen with ourselves, so there will be just room at
table for him.
subQuotationList:
["Well, all I know is, that it will be abominably rude if you do not
wait on him. But, however, that shan't prevent my asking him to dine
here, I am determined. We must have Mrs. Long and the Gouldings soon.
That will make thirteen with ourselves, so there will be just room at
table for him."]
speaker: Mrs. Bennet
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. Bennet'], ['Mr. Bingley'], ['Mr. Bingley'], ['Mr. Bennet', 'Mrs. Bennet'], ['Mrs. Long'], ['Mrs. Goulding', 'Mr. Goulding'], ['Elizabeth', 'Jane', 'Mrs. Bennet', 'Mary', 'Mr. Bennet'], ['Mr. Bingley']]]

quoteText:
I begin to be sorry that he comes at all, It
would be nothing; I could see him with perfect indifference, but I can
hardly bear to hear it thus perpetually talked of. My mother means well;
but she does not know, no one can know how much I suffer from what she
says. Happy shall I be, when his stay at Netherfield is over!
subQuotationList:
['I begin to be sorry that he comes at all,', 'It
would be nothing; I could see him with perfect indifference, but I can
hardly bear to hear it thus perpetually talked of. My mother means well;
but she does not know, no one can know how much I suffer from what she
says. Happy shall I be, when his stay at Netherfield is over!']
speaker: Jane
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. Bingley']], [['Mr. Bingley'], ['Mrs. Bennet'], ['Mrs. Bennet'], ['Mrs. Bennet'], ['Mr. Bingley']]]

quoteText:
I wish I could say any thing to comfort you, but
it is wholly out of my power. You must feel it; and the usual
satisfaction of preaching patience to a sufferer is denied me, because
you have always so much.
subQuotationList:
['I wish I could say any thing to comfort you,', 'but
it is wholly out of my power. You must feel it; and the usual
satisfaction of preaching patience to a sufferer is denied me, because
you have always so much.']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText: There is a gentleman with him, mamma, who can it be?
subQuotationList: ['There is a gentleman with him, mamma,', 'who can it be?']
speaker: Kitty

quoteText:
Some acquaintance or other, my dear, I suppose; I am sure I do not
know.
subQuotationList: ['Some acquaintance or other, my dear, I suppose; I am sure I do not\nknow.']
speaker: Mrs. Bennet

quoteText:
La! it looks just like that man that used to be with
him before. Mr. what's his name. That tall, proud man.
subQuotationList: ['La!', "it looks just like that man that used to be with\nhim before. Mr. what's his name. That tall, proud man."]
speaker: Kitty

quoteText:
Good gracious! Mr. Darcy!--and so it does I vow. Well, any friend of
Mr. Bingley's will always be welcome here to be sure; but else I must
say that I hate the very sight of him.
subQuotationList: ["Good gracious! Mr. Darcy!--and so it does I vow. Well, any friend of\nMr. Bingley's will always be welcome here to be sure; but else I must\nsay that I hate the very sight of him."]
speaker: Mrs. Bennet

quoteText:
Let me first see how he behaves, it will then be early
enough for expectation. Could I expect it to be otherwise! Yet why did he come?
subQuotationList: ['Let me first see how he behaves,', 'it will then be early\nenough for expectation.', 'Could I expect it to be otherwise!', 'Yet why did he come?']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText: It is a long time, Mr. Bingley, since you went away,
subQuotationList: ['It is a long time, Mr. Bingley, since you went away,']
speaker: Mrs. Bennet

quoteText:
I began to be afraid you would never come back again. People _did_ say,
you meant to quit the place entirely at Michaelmas; but, however, I hope
it is not true. A great many changes have happened in the neighbourhood,
since you went away. Miss Lucas is married and settled. And one of my
own daughters. I suppose you have heard of it; indeed, you must have
seen it in the papers. It was in the Times and the Courier, I know;
though it was not put in as it ought to be. It was only said,
subQuotationList:
['I began to be afraid you would never come back again. People _did_ say,
you meant to quit the place entirely at Michaelmas; but, however, I hope
it is not true. A great many changes have happened in the neighbourhood,
since you went away. Miss Lucas is married and settled. And one of my
own daughters. I suppose you have heard of it; indeed, you must have
seen it in the papers. It was in the Times and the Courier, I know;
though it was not put in as it ought to be. It was only said,']
speaker: Mrs. Bennet
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. Bingley'], ['Mr. Bingley'], ['Mr. Bingley'], ['Charlotte Lucas'], ['Lydia'], ['Mr. Bingley'], ['Mr. Bingley']]]

quoteText:
without there being a
syllable said of her father, or the place where she lived, or any thing.
It was my brother Gardiner's drawing up too, and I wonder how he came to
make such an awkward business of it. Did you see it?
subQuotationList:
["without there being a
syllable said of her father, or the place where she lived, or any thing.
It was my brother Gardiner's drawing up too, and I wonder how he came to
make such an awkward business of it. Did you see it?"]
speaker: Mrs. Bennet

quoteText:
It is a delightful thing, to be sure, to have a daughter well married, but at the same time, Mr. Bingley, it is very
hard to have her taken such a way from me. They are gone down to
Newcastle, a place quite northward, it seems, and there they are to
stay, I do not know how long. His regiment is there; for I suppose you
have heard of his leaving the ----shire, and of his being gone into the
regulars. Thank Heaven! he has _some_ friends, though perhaps not so
many as he deserves.
subQuotationList:
['It is a delightful thing, to be sure, to have a daughter well married,', 'but at the same time, Mr. Bingley, it is very
hard to have her taken such a way from me. They are gone down to
Newcastle, a place quite northward, it seems, and there they are to
stay, I do not know how long. His regiment is there; for I suppose you
have heard of his leaving the ----shire, and of his being gone into the
regulars. Thank Heaven! he has _some_ friends, though perhaps not so
many as he deserves.']
speaker: Mrs. Bennet
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Lydia']], [['Mr. Bingley'], ['Lydia'], ['George Wickham', 'Lydia'], ['George Wickham', 'Lydia'], ['George Wickham'], ['Mr. Bingley'], ['George Wickham'], ['George Wickham'], ['George Wickham'], ['George Wickham']]]

quoteText:
When you have killed all your own birds, Mr. Bingley, I beg you will come here, and shoot as many as you please, on Mr.
Bennet's manor. I am sure he will be vastly happy to oblige you, and
will save all the best of the covies for you.
subQuotationList: ['When you have killed all your own birds, Mr. Bingley,', "I beg you will come here, and shoot as many as you please, on Mr.\nBennet's manor. I am sure he will be vastly happy to oblige you, and\nwill save all the best of the covies for you."]
speaker: Mrs. Bennet
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. Bingley'], ['Bingley'], ['Mr. Bingley']], [['Mr. Bingley'], ['Mr. Bingley'], ['Mr. Bennet'], ['Mr. Bennet'], ['Mr. Bingley'], ['Mr. Bingley']]]

quoteText:
The first wish of my heart, is never more to be
in company with either of them. Their society can afford no pleasure,
that will atone for such wretchedness as this! Let me never see either
one or the other again!
subQuotationList:
['The first wish of my heart,', 'is never more to be
in company with either of them. Their society can afford no pleasure,
that will atone for such wretchedness as this! Let me never see either
one or the other again!']
speaker: Elizabeth
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Mr. Darcy', 'Mr. Bingley'], ['Mr. Darcy', 'Mr. Bingley'], ['Mr. Darcy', 'Mr. Bingley']]]

quoteText:
You are quite a visit in my debt, Mr. Bingley, for when
you went to town last winter, you promised to take a family dinner with
us, as soon as you returned. I have not forgot, you see; and I assure
you, I was very much disappointed that you did not come back and keep
your engagement.
subQuotationList:
['You are quite a visit in my debt, Mr. Bingley,', 'for when
you went to town last winter, you promised to take a family dinner with
us, as soon as you returned. I have not forgot, you see; and I assure
you, I was very much disappointed that you did not come back and keep
your engagement.']
speaker: Mrs. Bennet
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. Bingley'], ['Mr. Bingley']], [['Mr. Bingley'], ['Mr. Bingley'], ['Mary', 'Elizabeth', 'Lydia', 'Mrs. Bennet', 'Kitty', 'Mr. Bennet'], ['Mr. Bingley'], ['Mr. Bingley'], ['Mr. Bingley'], ['Mr. Bingley'], ['Mr. Bingley']]]

quoteText: Why, if he came only to be silent, grave, and indifferent, did he come at all?
subQuotationList: ['Why, if he came only to be silent, grave, and indifferent,', 'did he come at all?']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
He could be still amiable, still pleasing, to my uncle and aunt, when
he was in town; and why not to me? If he fears me, why come hither? If
he no longer cares for me, why silent? Teazing, teazing, man! I will
think no more about him.
subQuotationList:
['He could be still amiable, still pleasing, to my uncle and aunt, when
he was in town; and why not to me? If he fears me, why come hither? If
he no longer cares for me, why silent? Teazing, teazing, man! I will
think no more about him.']
speaker: Elizabeth
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. Darcy'], ['Mr. Gardiner'], ['Mrs. Gardiner'], ['Mr. Darcy'], ['Mr. Darcy'], ['Mr. Darcy'], ['Mr. Darcy'], ['Mr. Darcy']]]

quoteText:
Now, that this first meeting is over, I feel perfectly
easy. I know my own strength, and I shall never be embarrassed again by
his coming. I am glad he dines here on Tuesday. It will then be publicly
seen, that on both sides, we meet only as common and indifferent
acquaintance.
subQuotationList:
['Now,', 'that this first meeting is over, I feel perfectly
easy. I know my own strength, and I shall never be embarrassed again by
his coming. I am glad he dines here on Tuesday. It will then be publicly
seen, that on both sides, we meet only as common and indifferent
acquaintance.']
speaker: Jane

quoteText:
Yes, very indifferent indeed, Oh, Jane,
take care.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, very indifferent indeed,', 'Oh, Jane,\ntake care.']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText: My dear Lizzy, you cannot think me so weak, as to be in danger now.
subQuotationList: ['My dear Lizzy, you cannot think me so weak, as to be in danger now.']
speaker: Jane

quoteText:
I think you are in very great danger of making him as much in love with
you as ever.
subQuotationList: ['I think you are in very great danger of making him as much in love with\nyou as ever.']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
If he does not come to me, _then_, I shall give him up for
ever.
subQuotationList: ['If he does not come to me, _then_,', 'I shall give him up for\never.']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
A man who has once been refused! How could I ever be foolish enough to
expect a renewal of his love? Is there one among the sex, who would not
protest against such a weakness as a second proposal to the same woman?
There is no indignity so abhorrent to their feelings!
subQuotationList:
['A man who has once been refused! How could I ever be foolish enough to
expect a renewal of his love? Is there one among the sex, who would not
protest against such a weakness as a second proposal to the same woman?
There is no indignity so abhorrent to their feelings!']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText: Is your sister at Pemberley still?
subQuotationList: ['Is your sister at Pemberley still?']
speaker: Elizabeth
referringExpression: she seized the opportunity of saying

quoteText: Yes, she will remain there till Christmas.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, she will remain there till Christmas.']
speaker: Mr. Darcy

quoteText: And quite alone? Have all her friends left her?
subQuotationList: ['And quite alone? Have all her friends left her?']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
Mrs. Annesley is with her. The others have been gone on to Scarborough,
these three weeks.
subQuotationList: ['Mrs. Annesley is with her. The others have been gone on to Scarborough,\nthese three weeks.']
speaker: Mr. Darcy

quoteText:
Well girls, What
say you to the day? I think every thing has passed off uncommonly well,
I assure you. The dinner was as well dressed as any I ever saw. The
venison was roasted to a turn--and everybody said, they never saw so fat
a haunch. The soup was fifty times better than what we had at the
Lucas's last week; and even Mr. Darcy acknowledged, that the partridges
were remarkably well done; and I suppose he has two or three French
cooks at least. And, my dear Jane, I never saw you look in greater
beauty. Mrs. Long said so too, for I asked her whether you did not. And
what do you think she said besides? She did indeed. I do think Mrs. Long is as good
a creature as ever lived--and her nieces are very pretty behaved girls,
and not at all handsome: I like them prodigiously.
subQuotationList:
['Well girls,', "What
say you to the day? I think every thing has passed off uncommonly well,
I assure you. The dinner was as well dressed as any I ever saw. The
venison was roasted to a turn--and everybody said, they never saw so fat
a haunch. The soup was fifty times better than what we had at the
Lucas's last week; and even Mr. Darcy acknowledged, that the partridges
were remarkably well done; and I suppose he has two or three French
cooks at least. And, my dear Jane, I never saw you look in greater
beauty. Mrs. Long said so too, for I asked her whether you did not. And
what do you think she said besides?", 'She did indeed. I do think Mrs. Long is as good
a creature as ever lived--and her nieces are very pretty behaved girls,
and not at all handsome: I like them prodigiously.']
speaker: Mrs. Bennet
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Elizabeth', 'Jane']], [['Elizabeth', 'Jane'], ['Elizabeth', 'Jane'], ['Elizabeth', 'Mrs. Bennet'], ['Lady Lucas', 'Sir William Lucas'], ['Mr. Darcy'], ['Mr. Darcy'], ['Jane'], ['Jane'], ['Mrs. Long'], ['Mrs. Long'], ['Jane'], ['Jane'], ['Mrs. Long']], [['Mrs. Long'], ['Mrs. Long'], ['Mrs. Long'], ['Mrs. Long']]]

quoteText:
It has been a very agreeable day, The
party seemed so well selected, so suitable one with the other. I hope we
may often meet again.
subQuotationList: ['It has been a very agreeable day,', 'The\nparty seemed so well selected, so suitable one with the other. I hope we\nmay often meet again.']
speaker: Jane

quoteText:
Lizzy, you must not do so. You must not suspect me. It mortifies me. I
assure you that I have now learnt to enjoy his conversation as an
agreeable and sensible young man, without having a wish beyond it. I am
perfectly satisfied from what his manners now are, that he never had any
design of engaging my affection. It is only that he is blessed with
greater sweetness of address, and a stronger desire of generally
pleasing than any other man.
subQuotationList:
['Lizzy, you must not do so. You must not suspect me. It mortifies me. I
assure you that I have now learnt to enjoy his conversation as an
agreeable and sensible young man, without having a wish beyond it. I am
perfectly satisfied from what his manners now are, that he never had any
design of engaging my affection. It is only that he is blessed with
greater sweetness of address, and a stronger desire of generally
pleasing than any other man.']
speaker: Jane

quoteText:
You are very cruel, you will not let me smile, and
are provoking me to it every moment.
subQuotationList: ['You are very cruel,', 'you will not let me smile, and\nare provoking me to it every moment.']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText: How hard it is in some cases to be believed!
subQuotationList: ['How hard it is in some cases to be believed!']
speaker: Jane

quoteText: And how impossible in others!
subQuotationList: ['And how impossible in others!']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
But why should you wish to persuade me that I feel more than I
acknowledge?
subQuotationList: ['But why should you wish to persuade me that I feel more than I\nacknowledge?']
speaker: Jane

quoteText:
That is a question which I hardly know how to answer. We all love to
instruct, though we can teach only what is not worth knowing. Forgive
me; and if you persist in indifference, do not make _me_ your
confidante.
subQuotationList:
['That is a question which I hardly know how to answer. We all love to
instruct, though we can teach only what is not worth knowing. Forgive
me; and if you persist in indifference, do not make _me_ your
confidante.']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText: Next time you call, I hope we shall be more lucky.
subQuotationList: ['Next time you call,', 'I hope we shall be more lucky.']
speaker: Mrs. Bennet

quoteText: Can you come to-morrow?
subQuotationList: ['Can you come to-morrow?']
speaker: Mrs. Bennet

quoteText:
My dear Jane, make haste and hurry down. He is come--Mr. Bingley is
come.--He is, indeed. Make haste, make haste. Here, Sarah, come to Miss
Bennet this moment, and help her on with her gown. Never mind Miss
Lizzy's hair.
subQuotationList:
["My dear Jane, make haste and hurry down. He is come--Mr. Bingley is
come.--He is, indeed. Make haste, make haste. Here, Sarah, come to Miss
Bennet this moment, and help her on with her gown. Never mind Miss
Lizzy's hair."]
speaker: Mrs. Bennet
referringExpression: Mrs Bennet to her daughters room in her dressing gown and with her hair half finished crying out

quoteText:
We will be down as soon as we can, but I dare say Kitty is
forwarder than either of us, for she went up stairs half an hour ago.
subQuotationList: ['We will be down as soon as we can,', 'but I dare say Kitty is\nforwarder than either of us, for she went up stairs half an hour ago.']
speaker: Jane

quoteText:
Oh! hang Kitty! what has she to do with it? Come be quick, be quick!
where is your sash my dear?
subQuotationList: ['Oh! hang Kitty! what has she to do with it? Come be quick, be quick!\nwhere is your sash my dear?']
speaker: Mrs. Bennet

quoteText:
What is the matter mamma? What do
you keep winking at me for? What am I to do?
subQuotationList: ['What is the matter mamma? What do\nyou keep winking at me for? What am I to do?']
speaker: Kitty

quoteText: Nothing child, nothing. I did not wink at you.
subQuotationList: ['Nothing child, nothing. I did not wink at you.']
speaker: Mrs. Bennet

quoteText: Come here, my love, I want to speak to you,
subQuotationList: ['Come here, my love, I want to speak to you,']
speaker: Mrs. Bennet
referringExpression: she suddenly got up and saying to Kitty

quoteText: Lizzy, my dear, I want to speak with you.
subQuotationList: ['Lizzy, my dear, I want to speak with you.']
speaker: Mrs. Bennet
referringExpression: Mrs Bennet half opened the door and called out

quoteText:
We may as well leave them by themselves you know; Kitty and I are going upstairs to sit in
my dressing-room.
subQuotationList: ['We may as well leave them by themselves you know;', 'Kitty and I are going upstairs to sit in\nmy dressing-room.']
speaker: Mrs. Bennet

quoteText:
'Tis too much! by far too much. I do not deserve it. Oh!
why is not every body as happy?
subQuotationList: ["'Tis too much!", 'by far too much. I do not deserve it. Oh!\nwhy is not every body as happy?']
speaker: Jane

quoteText:
I must go instantly to my mother; I would not on any
account trifle with her affectionate solicitude; or allow her to hear it
from any one but myself. He is gone to my father already. Oh! Lizzy, to
know that what I have to relate will give such pleasure to all my dear
family! how shall I bear so much happiness!
subQuotationList:
['I must go instantly to my mother;', 'I would not on any
account trifle with her affectionate solicitude; or allow her to hear it
from any one but myself. He is gone to my father already. Oh! Lizzy, to
know that what I have to relate will give such pleasure to all my dear
family! how shall I bear so much happiness!']
speaker: Jane
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mrs. Bennet']], [['Mrs. Bennet'], ['Mrs. Bennet'], ['Mr. Bingley'], ['Mr. Bennet'], ['Elizabeth'], ['Mary', 'Elizabeth', 'Lydia', 'Mrs. Bennet', 'Kitty', 'Mr. Bennet']]]

quoteText:
And this, is the end of all his friend's anxious
circumspection! of all his sister's falsehood and contrivance! the
happiest, wisest, most reasonable end!
subQuotationList: ['And this,', "is the end of all his friend's anxious\ncircumspection! of all his sister's falsehood and contrivance! the\nhappiest, wisest, most reasonable end!"]
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText: Where is your sister?
subQuotationList: ['Where is your sister?']
speaker: Mr. Bingley

quoteText: With my mother up stairs. She will be down in a moment I dare say.
subQuotationList: ['With my mother up stairs. She will be down in a moment I dare say.']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText: Jane, I congratulate you. You will be a very happy woman.
subQuotationList: ['Jane, I congratulate you. You will be a very happy woman.']
speaker: Mr. Bennet
referringExpression: he turned to his daughter and said

quoteText:
You are a good girl; and I have great pleasure in
thinking you will be so happily settled. I have not a doubt of your
doing very well together. Your tempers are by no means unlike. You are
each of you so complying, that nothing will ever be resolved on; so
easy, that every servant will cheat you; and so generous, that you will
always exceed your income.
subQuotationList:
['You are a good girl;', 'and I have great pleasure in
thinking you will be so happily settled. I have not a doubt of your
doing very well together. Your tempers are by no means unlike. You are
each of you so complying, that nothing will ever be resolved on; so
easy, that every servant will cheat you; and so generous, that you will
always exceed your income.']
speaker: Mr. Bennet

quoteText:
I hope not so. Imprudence or thoughtlessness in money matters, would be
unpardonable in _me_.
subQuotationList: ['I hope not so. Imprudence or thoughtlessness in money matters, would be\nunpardonable in _me_.']
speaker: Jane

quoteText:
Exceed their income! My dear Mr. Bennet, what are you
talking of? Why, he has four or five thousand a-year, and very likely
more. Oh! my dear, dear Jane, I am so
happy! I am sure I sha'nt get a wink of sleep all night. I knew how it
would be. I always said it must be so, at last. I was sure you could not
be so beautiful for nothing! I remember, as soon as ever I saw him, when
he first came into Hertfordshire last year, I thought how likely it was
that you should come together. Oh! he is the handsomest young man that
ever was seen!
subQuotationList:
['Exceed their income! My dear Mr. Bennet,', 'what are you
talking of? Why, he has four or five thousand a-year, and very likely
more.', "Oh! my dear, dear Jane, I am so
happy! I am sure I sha'nt get a wink of sleep all night. I knew how it
would be. I always said it must be so, at last. I was sure you could not
be so beautiful for nothing! I remember, as soon as ever I saw him, when
he first came into Hertfordshire last year, I thought how likely it was
that you should come together. Oh! he is the handsomest young man that
ever was seen!"]
speaker: Mrs. Bennet
mentionTextsList: [['their', 'My dear Mr. Bennet'], ['you', 'he'], ['my dear, dear Jane', 'you', 'him', 'he', 'you', 'he']]
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Jane', 'Mr. Bingley'], ['Mr. Bennet']], [['Mr. Bennet'], ['Mr. Bingley']], [['Jane'], ['Jane'], ['Mr. Bingley'], ['Mr. Bingley'], ['Jane'], ['Mr. Bingley']]]

quoteText:
He has made me so happy, by telling me, that
he was totally ignorant of my being in town last spring! I had not
believed it possible.
subQuotationList: ['He has made me so happy,', 'by telling me, that\nhe was totally ignorant of my being in town last spring! I had not\nbelieved it possible.']
speaker: Jane

quoteText:
I suspected as much, But how did he account for
it?
subQuotationList: ['I suspected as much,', 'But how did he account for\nit?']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
It must have been his sister's doing. They were certainly no friends to
his acquaintance with me, which I cannot wonder at, since he might have
chosen so much more advantageously in many respects. But when they see,
as I trust they will, that their brother is happy with me, they will
learn to be contented, and we shall be on good terms again; though we
can never be what we once were to each other.
subQuotationList:
["It must have been his sister's doing. They were certainly no friends to
his acquaintance with me, which I cannot wonder at, since he might have
chosen so much more advantageously in many respects. But when they see,
as I trust they will, that their brother is happy with me, they will
learn to be contented, and we shall be on good terms again; though we
can never be what we once were to each other."]
speaker: Jane
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Ms. Bingley', 'Mrs. Hurst'], ['Bingley'], ['Mr. Bingley'], ['Ms. Bingley', 'Mrs. Hurst'], ['Ms. Bingley', 'Mrs. Hurst'], ['Mr. Bingley'], ['Ms. Bingley', 'Mrs. Hurst'], ['Jane', 'Ms. Bingley', 'Mrs. Hurst'], ['Jane', 'Ms. Bingley', 'Mrs. Hurst']]]

quoteText:
That is the most unforgiving speech, that I ever
heard you utter. Good girl! It would vex me, indeed, to see you again
the dupe of Miss Bingley's pretended regard.
subQuotationList: ['That is the most unforgiving speech,', "that I ever\nheard you utter. Good girl! It would vex me, indeed, to see you again\nthe dupe of Miss Bingley's pretended regard."]
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
Would you believe it, Lizzy, that when he went to town last November,
he really loved me, and nothing but a persuasion of _my_ being
indifferent, would have prevented his coming down again!
subQuotationList: ['Would you believe it, Lizzy, that when he went to town last November,\nhe really loved me, and nothing but a persuasion of _my_ being\nindifferent, would have prevented his coming down again!']
speaker: Jane

quoteText:
He made a little mistake to be sure; but it is to the credit of his
modesty.
subQuotationList: ['He made a little mistake to be sure; but it is to the credit of his\nmodesty.']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
I am certainly the most fortunate creature that ever existed! Oh! Lizzy, why am I thus singled from my family, and blessed
above them all! If I could but see _you_ as happy! If there _were_ but
such another man for you!
subQuotationList: ['I am certainly the most fortunate creature that ever existed!', 'Oh! Lizzy, why am I thus singled from my family, and blessed\nabove them all! If I could but see _you_ as happy! If there _were_ but\nsuch another man for you!']
speaker: Jane

quoteText:
If you were to give me forty such men, I never could be so happy as
you. Till I have your disposition, your goodness, I never can have your
happiness. No, no, let me shift for myself; and, perhaps, if I have very
good luck, I may meet with another Mr. Collins in time.
subQuotationList:
['If you were to give me forty such men, I never could be so happy as
you. Till I have your disposition, your goodness, I never can have your
happiness. No, no, let me shift for myself; and, perhaps, if I have very
good luck, I may meet with another Mr. Collins in time.']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText: I hope you are well, Miss Bennet. That lady I suppose is your mother.
subQuotationList: ['I hope you are well, Miss Bennet. That lady I suppose is your mother.']
speaker: Lady Catherine De Bourgh

quoteText: And _that_ I suppose is one of your sisters.
subQuotationList: ['And _that_ I suppose is one of your sisters.']
speaker: Lady Catherine De Bourgh

quoteText:
Yes, madam, She is my youngest girl but one. My youngest of all, is lately married,
and my eldest is somewhere about the grounds, walking with a young man,
who I believe will soon become a part of the family.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, madam,', 'She is my youngest girl but one. My youngest of all, is lately married,\nand my eldest is somewhere about the grounds, walking with a young man,\nwho I believe will soon become a part of the family.']
speaker: Mrs. Bennet
mentionTextsList: [['madam'], ['She', 'My youngest of all', 'my eldest', 'a young man']]

quoteText: You have a very small park here,
subQuotationList: ['You have a very small park here,']
speaker: Lady Catherine De Bourgh

quoteText:
It is nothing in comparison of Rosings, my lady, I dare say; but I
assure you it is much larger than Sir William Lucas's.
subQuotationList: ["It is nothing in comparison of Rosings, my lady, I dare say; but I\nassure you it is much larger than Sir William Lucas's."]
speaker: Mrs. Bennet
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Lady Catherine De Bourgh'], ['Lady Catherine De Bourgh'], ['Sir William Lucas']]]

quoteText:
This must be a most inconvenient sitting room for the evening, in
summer; the windows are full west.
subQuotationList: ['This must be a most inconvenient sitting room for the evening, in\nsummer; the windows are full west.']
speaker: Lady Catherine De Bourgh

quoteText:
May I take the liberty of asking your ladyship whether you left Mr. and
Mrs. Collins well.
subQuotationList: ['May I take the liberty of asking your ladyship whether you left Mr. and\nMrs. Collins well.']
speaker: Mrs. Bennet
referringExpression: Mrs Bennet assured her that they never sat there after dinner and then added
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Lady Catherine De Bourgh'], ['Lady Catherine De Bourgh'], ['Charlotte Lucas', 'Mr. Collins']]]

quoteText: Yes, very well. I saw them the night before last.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, very well. I saw them the night before last.']
speaker: Lady Catherine De Bourgh

quoteText:
Miss Bennet, there seemed to be a prettyish kind of a little wilderness
on one side of your lawn. I should be glad to take a turn in it, if you
will favour me with your company.
subQuotationList: ['Miss Bennet, there seemed to be a prettyish kind of a little wilderness\non one side of your lawn. I should be glad to take a turn in it, if you\nwill favour me with your company.']
speaker: Lady Catherine De Bourgh
referringExpression: Lady Catherine very resolutely and not very politely declined eating any thing and then rising up said to Elizabeth

quoteText:
Go, my dear, and shew her ladyship about the
different walks. I think she will be pleased with the hermitage.
subQuotationList: ['Go, my dear,', 'and shew her ladyship about the\ndifferent walks. I think she will be pleased with the hermitage.']
speaker: Mrs. Bennet
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Elizabeth']], [['Lady Catherine De Bourgh'], ['Lady Catherine De Bourgh']]]

quoteText: How could I ever think her like her nephew?
subQuotationList: ['How could I ever think her like her nephew?']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
You can be at no loss, Miss Bennet, to understand the reason of my
journey hither. Your own heart, your own conscience, must tell you why I
come.
subQuotationList: ['You can be at no loss, Miss Bennet, to understand the reason of my\njourney hither. Your own heart, your own conscience, must tell you why I\ncome.']
speaker: Lady Catherine De Bourgh

quoteText:
Indeed, you are mistaken, Madam. I have not been at all able to account
for the honour of seeing you here.
subQuotationList: ['Indeed, you are mistaken, Madam. I have not been at all able to account\nfor the honour of seeing you here.']
speaker: Elizabeth
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Lady Catherine De Bourgh'], ['Lady Catherine De Bourgh'], ['Lady Catherine De Bourgh']]]

quoteText:
Miss Bennet, you ought to
know, that I am not to be trifled with. But however insincere _you_ may
choose to be, you shall not find _me_ so. My character has ever been
celebrated for its sincerity and frankness, and in a cause of such
moment as this, I shall certainly not depart from it. A report of a most
alarming nature, reached me two days ago. I was told, that not only your
sister was on the point of being most advantageously married, but that
_you_, that Miss Elizabeth Bennet, would, in all likelihood, be soon
afterwards united to my nephew, my own nephew, Mr. Darcy. Though I
_know_ it must be a scandalous falsehood; though I would not injure him
so much as to suppose the truth of it possible, I instantly resolved on
setting off for this place, that I might make my sentiments known to
you.
subQuotationList:
['Miss Bennet,', 'you ought to
know, that I am not to be trifled with. But however insincere _you_ may
choose to be, you shall not find _me_ so. My character has ever been
celebrated for its sincerity and frankness, and in a cause of such
moment as this, I shall certainly not depart from it. A report of a most
alarming nature, reached me two days ago. I was told, that not only your
sister was on the point of being most advantageously married, but that
_you_, that Miss Elizabeth Bennet, would, in all likelihood, be soon
afterwards united to my nephew, my own nephew, Mr. Darcy. Though I
_know_ it must be a scandalous falsehood; though I would not injure him
so much as to suppose the truth of it possible, I instantly resolved on
setting off for this place, that I might make my sentiments known to
you.']
speaker: Lady Catherine De Bourgh
mentionTextsList: [['Miss Bennet'], ['you', 'you', 'you', 'your\nsister', 'you', 'Miss Elizabeth Bennet', 'my nephew', 'my own nephew', 'Mr. Darcy', 'him', 'you']]

quoteText:
If you believed it impossible to be true, I wonder you took the trouble of coming
so far. What could your ladyship propose by it?
subQuotationList: ['If you believed it impossible to be true,', 'I wonder you took the trouble of coming\nso far. What could your ladyship propose by it?']
speaker: Elizabeth
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Lady Catherine De Bourgh']], [['Lady Catherine De Bourgh'], ['Lady Catherine De Bourgh']]]

quoteText: At once to insist upon having such a report universally contradicted.
subQuotationList: ['At once to insist upon having such a report universally contradicted.']
speaker: Lady Catherine De Bourgh

quoteText:
Your coming to Longbourn, to see me and my family, will be rather a confirmation of it; if, indeed, such a report
is in existence.
subQuotationList: ['Your coming to Longbourn, to see me and my family,', 'will be rather a confirmation of it; if, indeed, such a report\nis in existence.']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
If! do you then pretend to be ignorant of it? Has it not been
industriously circulated by yourselves? Do you not know that such a
report is spread abroad?
subQuotationList: ['If! do you then pretend to be ignorant of it? Has it not been\nindustriously circulated by yourselves? Do you not know that such a\nreport is spread abroad?']
speaker: Lady Catherine De Bourgh

quoteText: I never heard that it was.
subQuotationList: ['I never heard that it was.']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText: And can you likewise declare, that there is no _foundation_ for it?
subQuotationList: ['And can you likewise declare, that there is no _foundation_ for it?']
speaker: Lady Catherine De Bourgh

quoteText:
I do not pretend to possess equal frankness with your ladyship. _You_
may ask questions, which _I_ shall not choose to answer.
subQuotationList: ['I do not pretend to possess equal frankness with your ladyship. _You_\nmay ask questions, which _I_ shall not choose to answer.']
speaker: Elizabeth
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Lady Catherine De Bourgh'], ['Lady Catherine De Bourgh']]]

quoteText:
This is not to be borne. Miss Bennet, I insist on being satisfied. Has
he, has my nephew, made you an offer of marriage?
subQuotationList: ['This is not to be borne. Miss Bennet, I insist on being satisfied. Has\nhe, has my nephew, made you an offer of marriage?']
speaker: Lady Catherine De Bourgh

quoteText: Your ladyship has declared it to be impossible.
subQuotationList: ['Your ladyship has declared it to be impossible.']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
It ought to be so; it must be so, while he retains the use of his
reason. But _your_ arts and allurements may, in a moment of infatuation,
have made him forget what he owes to himself and to all his family. You
may have drawn him in.
subQuotationList:
['It ought to be so; it must be so, while he retains the use of his
reason. But _your_ arts and allurements may, in a moment of infatuation,
have made him forget what he owes to himself and to all his family. You
may have drawn him in.']
speaker: Lady Catherine De Bourgh
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. Darcy'], ['Mr. Darcy'], ['Elizabeth'], ['Mr. Darcy'], ['Mr. Darcy'], ['Mr. Darcy'], ['Mr. Darcy'], ['Elizabeth'], ['Mr. Darcy']]]

quoteText: If I have, I shall be the last person to confess it.
subQuotationList: ['If I have, I shall be the last person to confess it.']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
Miss Bennet, do you know who I am? I have not been accustomed to such
language as this. I am almost the nearest relation he has in the world,
and am entitled to know all his dearest concerns.
subQuotationList: ['Miss Bennet, do you know who I am? I have not been accustomed to such\nlanguage as this. I am almost the nearest relation he has in the world,\nand am entitled to know all his dearest concerns.']
speaker: Lady Catherine De Bourgh

quoteText:
But you are not entitled to know _mine_; nor will such behaviour as
this, ever induce me to be explicit.
subQuotationList: ['But you are not entitled to know _mine_; nor will such behaviour as\nthis, ever induce me to be explicit.']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
Let me be rightly understood. This match, to which you have the
presumption to aspire, can never take place. No, never. Mr. Darcy is
engaged to _my daughter_. Now what have you to say?
subQuotationList: ['Let me be rightly understood. This match, to which you have the\npresumption to aspire, can never take place. No, never. Mr. Darcy is\nengaged to _my daughter_. Now what have you to say?']
speaker: Lady Catherine De Bourgh

quoteText:
Only this; that if he is so, you can have no reason to suppose he will
make an offer to me.
subQuotationList: ['Only this; that if he is so, you can have no reason to suppose he will\nmake an offer to me.']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
The engagement between them is of a peculiar kind. From their infancy,
they have been intended for each other. It was the favourite wish of
_his_ mother, as well as of her's. While in their cradles, we planned
the union: and now, at the moment when the wishes of both sisters would
be accomplished, in their marriage, to be prevented by a young woman of
inferior birth, of no importance in the world, and wholly unallied to
the family! Do you pay no regard to the wishes of his friends? To his
tacit engagement with Miss De Bourgh? Are you lost to every feeling of
propriety and delicacy? Have you not heard me say, that from his
earliest hours he was destined for his cousin?
subQuotationList:
["The engagement between them is of a peculiar kind. From their infancy,
they have been intended for each other. It was the favourite wish of
_his_ mother, as well as of her's. While in their cradles, we planned
the union: and now, at the moment when the wishes of both sisters would
be accomplished, in their marriage, to be prevented by a young woman of
inferior birth, of no importance in the world, and wholly unallied to
the family! Do you pay no regard to the wishes of his friends? To his
tacit engagement with Miss De Bourgh? Are you lost to every feeling of
propriety and delicacy? Have you not heard me say, that from his
earliest hours he was destined for his cousin?"]
speaker: Lady Catherine De Bourgh
referringExpression: Lady Catherine hesitated for a moment and then replied
mentionTextsList: [['them', 'their', 'they', 'each other', 'his', "her's", 'their', 'we', 'both sisters', 'their', 'a young woman of\ninferior birth', 'you', 'his', 'his', 'you', 'you', 'his', 'he']]
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. Darcy'], ['Mr. Darcy'], ['Mr. Darcy', 'Miss De Bourgh'], ['Mr. Darcy', 'Miss De Bourgh'], ['Mr. Darcy'], ['Lady Catherine De Bourgh'], ['Mr. Darcy'], ['Lady Catherine De Bourgh', 'Lady Darcy'], ['Lady Catherine De Bourgh', 'Lady Darcy'], ['Mr. Darcy'], ['Elizabeth'], ['Elizabeth'], ['Mr. Darcy'], ['Mr. Darcy'], ['Elizabeth'], ['Elizabeth'], ['Mr. Darcy'], ['Mr. Darcy']]]

quoteText:
Yes, and I had heard it before. But what is that to me? If there is no
other objection to my marrying your nephew, I shall certainly not be
kept from it, by knowing that his mother and aunt wished him to marry
Miss De Bourgh. You both did as much as you could, in planning the
marriage. Its completion depended on others. If Mr. Darcy is neither by
honour nor inclination confined to his cousin, why is not he to make
another choice? And if I am that choice, why may not I accept him?
subQuotationList:
['Yes, and I had heard it before. But what is that to me? If there is no
other objection to my marrying your nephew, I shall certainly not be
kept from it, by knowing that his mother and aunt wished him to marry
Miss De Bourgh. You both did as much as you could, in planning the
marriage. Its completion depended on others. If Mr. Darcy is neither by
honour nor inclination confined to his cousin, why is not he to make
another choice? And if I am that choice, why may not I accept him?']
speaker: Elizabeth
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. Darcy'], ['Mr. Darcy'], ['Lady Catherine De Bourgh'], ['Mr. Darcy'], ['Lady Catherine De Bourgh'], ['Mr. Darcy'], ['Mr. Darcy'], ['Mr. Darcy']]]

quoteText:
Because honour, decorum, prudence, nay, interest, forbid it. Yes, Miss
Bennet, interest; for do not expect to be noticed by his family or
friends, if you wilfully act against the inclinations of all. You will
be censured, slighted, and despised, by every one connected with him.
Your alliance will be a disgrace; your name will never even be mentioned
by any of us.
subQuotationList:
['Because honour, decorum, prudence, nay, interest, forbid it. Yes, Miss
Bennet, interest; for do not expect to be noticed by his family or
friends, if you wilfully act against the inclinations of all. You will
be censured, slighted, and despised, by every one connected with him.
Your alliance will be a disgrace; your name will never even be mentioned
by any of us.']
speaker: Lady Catherine De Bourgh
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Elizabeth'], ['Anne De Bourgh', 'Miss Darcy', 'Lady Catherine De Bourgh'], ['Elizabeth'], ['Elizabeth'], ['Mr. Darcy'], ['Elizabeth'], ['Elizabeth'], ['Anne De Bourgh', 'Miss Darcy', 'Lady Catherine De Bourgh']]]

quoteText:
These are heavy misfortunes, But the wife of Mr.
Darcy must have such extraordinary sources of happiness necessarily
attached to her situation, that she could, upon the whole, have no cause
to repine.
subQuotationList:
['These are heavy misfortunes,', 'But the wife of Mr.
Darcy must have such extraordinary sources of happiness necessarily
attached to her situation, that she could, upon the whole, have no cause
to repine.']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
Obstinate, headstrong girl! I am ashamed of you! Is this your gratitude
for my attentions to you last spring? Is nothing due to me on that
score?
subQuotationList: ['Obstinate, headstrong girl! I am ashamed of you! Is this your gratitude\nfor my attentions to you last spring? Is nothing due to me on that\nscore?']
speaker: Lady Catherine De Bourgh

quoteText:
Let us sit down. You are to understand, Miss Bennet, that I came here
with the determined resolution of carrying my purpose; nor will I be
dissuaded from it. I have not been used to submit to any person's whims.
I have not been in the habit of brooking disappointment.
subQuotationList:
["Let us sit down. You are to understand, Miss Bennet, that I came here
with the determined resolution of carrying my purpose; nor will I be
dissuaded from it. I have not been used to submit to any person's whims.
I have not been in the habit of brooking disappointment."]
speaker: Lady Catherine De Bourgh

quoteText:
_That_ will make your ladyship's situation at present more pitiable;
but it will have no effect on _me_.
subQuotationList: ["_That_ will make your ladyship's situation at present more pitiable;\nbut it will have no effect on _me_."]
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
I will not be interrupted. Hear me in silence. My daughter and my
nephew are formed for each other. They are descended on the maternal
side, from the same noble line; and, on the father's, from respectable,
honourable, and ancient, though untitled families. Their fortune on both
sides is splendid. They are destined for each other by the voice of
every member of their respective houses; and what is to divide them? The
upstart pretensions of a young woman without family, connections, or
fortune. Is this to be endured! But it must not, shall not be. If you
were sensible of your own good, you would not wish to quit the sphere,
in which you have been brought up.
subQuotationList:
["I will not be interrupted. Hear me in silence. My daughter and my
nephew are formed for each other. They are descended on the maternal
side, from the same noble line; and, on the father's, from respectable,
honourable, and ancient, though untitled families. Their fortune on both
sides is splendid. They are destined for each other by the voice of
every member of their respective houses; and what is to divide them? The
upstart pretensions of a young woman without family, connections, or
fortune. Is this to be endured! But it must not, shall not be. If you
were sensible of your own good, you would not wish to quit the sphere,
in which you have been brought up."]
speaker: Lady Catherine De Bourgh
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. Darcy'], ['Mr. Darcy', 'Miss De Bourgh'], ['Mr. Darcy'], ['Mr. Darcy'], ['Mr. Darcy'], ['Mr. Darcy', 'Miss De Bourgh'], ['Mr. Darcy'], ['Mr. Darcy'], ['Elizabeth'], ['Elizabeth'], ['Elizabeth'], ['Elizabeth']]]

quoteText:
In marrying your nephew, I should not consider myself as quitting that
sphere. He is a gentleman; I am a gentleman's daughter; so far we are
equal.
subQuotationList: ["In marrying your nephew, I should not consider myself as quitting that\nsphere. He is a gentleman; I am a gentleman's daughter; so far we are\nequal."]
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
True. You _are_ a gentleman's daughter. But who was your mother? Who
are your uncles and aunts? Do not imagine me ignorant of their
condition.
subQuotationList: ["True. You _are_ a gentleman's daughter. But who was your mother? Who\nare your uncles and aunts? Do not imagine me ignorant of their\ncondition."]
speaker: Lady Catherine De Bourgh

quoteText:
Whatever my connections may be, if your nephew does
not object to them, they can be nothing to _you_.
subQuotationList: ['Whatever my connections may be,', 'if your nephew does\nnot object to them, they can be nothing to _you_.']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText: Tell me once for all, are you engaged to him?
subQuotationList: ['Tell me once for all, are you engaged to him?']
speaker: Lady Catherine De Bourgh

quoteText: I am not.
subQuotationList: ['I am not.']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText: And will you promise me, never to enter into such an engagement?
subQuotationList: ['And will you promise me, never to enter into such an engagement?']
speaker: Lady Catherine De Bourgh

quoteText: I will make no promise of the kind.
subQuotationList: ['I will make no promise of the kind.']
speaker: Elizabeth

quoteText:
Miss Bennet I am shocked and astonished. I expected to find a more
reasonable young woman. But do not deceive yourself into a belief that I
will ever recede. I shall not go away, till you have given me the
assurance I require.
subQuotationList:
['Miss Bennet I am shocked and astonished. I expected to find a more
reasonable young woman. But do not deceive yourself into a belief that I
will ever recede. I shall not go away, till you have given me the
assurance I require.']
speaker: Lady Catherine De Bourgh

quoteText:
And I certainly _never_ shall give it. I am not to be intimidated into
